MUMBAI: The first Brand Equity Marketing Awards have been announced and the winners are: Asian Paints (Marketing Excellence), Bajaj V (Social Media Marketing), Carvaan from Saregama (Innovation), Durex (Digital Marketing), MakeMyTrip (Integrated Marketing), Rajasthan Tourism (Print Marketing) and Sonata ACT (Brand Launch).

The scope of winners was wide and varied. Bajaj V was a motorcycle crafted from the metal of India’s first aircraft carrier INS Vikrant, which put being social — both in terms of social good and leveraging the power of social media — at the heart of its communication. Carvaan brought an older audience closer to the songs they grew up on via an easy-to-use device. Durex effectively harnessed the power of digital and MakeMyTrip maximised the appeal of its celebrity brand ambassadors across all conceivable media vehicles.

The Rajasthan Tourism print campaign helped revitalise the appeal of an entire state among tourists. Sonata ACT was a watch targeted specifically at women and consisted of in-built safety features.

And finally, Asian Paints won for gaining phenomenal success in the market even as it reinvented the wheel on communicating what could have otherwise been a lowinvolvement b2b product.

The ceremony, held on April 20, was attended by some of India’s best-known personalities from the world of marketing and advertising.

Winners Chosen from Over 1,200 Entries
Those present in the event included Bharat Puri, MD, Pidilite; Sashi Shankar, chief marketing officer, Idea; Devendra Chawla, chief operating officer, Walmart; and Vikram Mehra, MD, Saregama, among others.

The ad business was represented by Ashish Bhasin, CEO, South Asia, Dentsu Aegis; Subhash Kamath, CEO, BBH India; Shashi Sinha, CEO, IPG Mediabrands; Arun Iyer, chairman, Lowe Lintas; and Sonal Dabral, chief creative officer, O&M. The awards were presented by Piyush Pandey, executive chairman, O&M South Asia; Falguni Nayar, CEO, Nykaa; Prasoon Joshi, CEO, McCann Worldgroup India; and Ramesh Chauhan, chairman, Bisleri. The awards were interspersed by performances by a capella band Raaga Trippin’, a game of Pictionary which saw sporting participation from ad and marketing folks and a short session by YouTuber Snehal Kumar.

The winners were selected from a longlist of over 1,200 entries that went through a gruelling round of judging: a preliminary session held across Mumbai and Delhi with 40 category specialist judges, and a final round judged by some of the country’s biggest names in marketing. All the rigour paid off with the entries being deemed worthy of top honours by all of those present at the event.

Bhasin said, “You can relate to the quality of the work as being good and genuine. I personally prefer advertising that makes a difference in the life of people. So I liked the Sonata ACT campaign.”

The event was also an opportunity for many marketing and ad folks to find common ground to meet, given that the rather contentious nature of creative advertising awards has resulted in one or the other agency or group staying away every year.

Apart from the winners, the two big topics of conversation were the ongoing IPL and the recent exit of WPP chief Sir Martin Sorrell — with the latter provoking many suppositions and conspiracy theories, considering Sorrell had been a boss, a rival, or an agency figurehead to many of those present.

The Brand Equity Marketing Awards will be back in a new, improved avatar in 2019. For full details on the winners, please remember to pick up the next issue of Brand Equity with The Economic Times.

India has been a major beneficiary of the fall in international crude oil prices over the past few years. But crude prices have been rising for some time and Brent crude has already touched a 41-month high of $75 dollar (Rs 5,000) per barrel. 

Depreciation in the rupee, though small, is also adding to crude oil’s rising cost. While international crude prices jumped 45% in dollar terms last year, the spike was by 49% in rupee terms. 

This rise will impact us in several ways, including the jump in our driving expenses. Hike in oil prices will also lead to inflationary pressure and force the RBI to hike interest rates. 

Stock market investors need to be careful because the impact of the rise in crude prices will be slightly complicated. It will both be positive and negative, depending on the sector. Interference by the government may complicate the situation further. For instance, there were reports that the government had asked oil marketing companies (OMCs) to absorb the impact of the rise in crude prices to the tune of Rs 1 per litre. Though this has been denied by the government and the OMCs, the market still fears that the government may attempt to do this discreetly.


Crude shock for markets
Any govt move to prevent passing higher costs to consumers will hurt oil firms.

Let’s see how the rise in crude prices will impact oil industry players.


Upstream firms may have to bear higher subsidy burdenThe subsidy worries in the oil sector, which seemed to have been relegated to the past are likely to be back. Though only liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and kerosene oil are subsidised now, this subsidy will balloon as the rise in LPG and kerosene prices won’t be passed on to consumers in an election year. “Government’s subsidy burden for 2018-19 may go up from the budgeted estimate of Rs 25,000 crore to Rs 40,000 crore now and as the government is not in a position to fund this, it is highly possible that it may ask upstream oil companies to bear it,” says Gagan Dixit, Oil & Gas Analyst, Elara Securities. 

But this does not mean that investors should totally avoid upstream oil companies— those involved in oil exploration and production. The added subsidy burden will not hurt them much as it will only marginally reduce their profit. “We are not bearish on upstream oil companies. We continue to be bullish on ONGC because of the new oil discoveries, increased gas production and increase in gas prices on half yearly basis,” says Dixit.


Price-caps will hurt OMCsStandalone refineries such as MRPL will not be impacted because they don’t share any subsidy burden. Central and state governments had raised excise duty and other levies when oil prices had fallen but it is unlikely that they will roll back these levies. “Since any cut in excise duty will have repercussions on the fiscal situation, the government is not in a position to cut excise duties now,” says Manish Sonthalia, CIO, Equity PMS, Motilal Oswal Mutual Fund. Since the state governments too are unlikely to roll back their hikes, raising prices is the only way out. But will the government allow OMCs to increase petrol and diesel prices in an election year? It is doubtful, because the required hike in prices is quite high. OMCs usually follow the 15-day average price, now placed around $70 (Rs 4,673)—$5 (Rs 334) below the current price. 

So, they need to increase prices to compensate this $5 dollar even if crude doesn’t go beyond $75. But OMCs may come under pressure, if the government imposes price caps. For each $1 increase in crude price, OMCs raise petrol and diesel prices by around 40 paisa—a hike of around Rs 2 for every $5 dollar increase in crude. If this increase is not allowed, their retail margin will suffer. Again, you don’t need to avoid all OMCs. “We are bullish on the refining industry and while we are bearish on OMCs such as HPCL and BPCL, we are bullish on IOC because of its higher revenue from refining and pipelines,” says Dixit.


Margins of crude oil users will come under pressureMargins of sectors that use crude derivatives as inputs will come under pressure. The paint industry will be among the worst affected because around 60% of its raw material is based on oil derivatives. While large players such as Asian Paints will be able to pass on higher costs due to their branding power, smaller players will come under pressure. Vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) is another crude derivative that is widely used by adhesive companies such as Pidilite Industries (VAM makes up 35%-40% of its raw material cost). Since most packing materials are now based on plastics, another crude derivative, FMCG companies will be affected. 

However, experts are not bearish on FMCG firms. “We are positive on consumer staples because of the rural demand and due to its under ownership now (most investors are bearish because these companies did not well in recent years). Companies with good pricing power will be able to protect their margin by passing on the increase in input costs,” says Manish Sonthalia.

NEW DELHI: The domestic equity market ended on a negative note last week, thus posting its first weekly loss in six weeks. Subdued global cues and heavy selling in IT and pharma stocks weighed on investor sentiment.

The S&P BSE Sensex ended 0.15 per cent lower for the week at 34,915, while the NSE Nifty settled at 10,618, down 0.69 per cent.

Here's a list of seven developments that may move the market in the coming week:


Next batch of earningsAmong notable names, ICICI Bank, Tata Chemicals and Tata Coffee are slated to announce January-March results on Monday, while ABB India and Jubilant FoodWorks will unveil their score cards on Tuesday. Eicher Motors and JSPL are scheduled to announce results on Wednesday.

Adani Enterprises, Asian Paints, Nestle India, Tata Communications, Titan Company, Union Bank of India and Zee Entertainment Enterprises will release their quarterly numbers on Thursday. Gillette India and Tata Global Beverages will announce January-March numbers on Friday.


Karnataka pollsThe Karnataka Legislative Assembly elections 2018 is scheduled to be held across the state on May 12. Results of the poll will be out on May 15. Leading parties, the ruling Congress and the BJP, have been campaigning aggressively in the state for the last few months to woo voters. Chief Minister Siddaramaiah will be fighting against BJP's BS Yeddyurappa for the CM's post in the upcoming polls. Market will keenly follow the developments from the state.


US jobs dataUS job growth increased less-than-expected in April and the unemployment rate dropped to near a 17.5-year low of 3.9 per cent, as some out-of-work Americans left the labour force, Reuters reported.

The report also showed wages barely rose last month, which may ease concerns that inflation pressures are rapidly building up, likely keeping the Federal Reserve on a gradual path of monetary policy tightening. Financial markets across the globe, including India may react to it when trading resumes on Monday.


All eyes on US sanctions against IranOil prices rose about 2 per cent on Friday, with US crude hitting its highest in more than three years, as global supplies remained tight and the market awaited news from Washington on possible new sanctions against Iran, Reuters reported. On May 12, the US President Donald Trump will decide whether to extend waivers on economic sanctions against Iran. If it doesn’t, the global market could lose about one million barrels of oil a day, says a Market Watch report.

The sanctions on Iran were lifted under a 2015 agreement among a group of world powers, including the US and Iran, aimed at curbing Tehran’s nuclear activities.


Tech ViewThe Nifty50 index on Friday formed a ‘Dark Cloud Cover’ pattern on daily chart, suggesting possible downside ahead. The pattern may have negative repercussions, which will be confirmed if the Nifty50 closes below the 10,600 level, said Mazhar Mohammad of Chartviewindia.in.

However, Gaurav Ratnaparkhi, Senior Technical Analyst, Sharekhan has a bullish outlook on the index for the short term with a target 10,910 and reversal placed at 10,500. "The short term trend will remain bullish as long as it does not close below 10,500. On the way up, 10,708 – 10,785 will be crucial resistance in the near term. The rise in the benchmark index can stretch towards 10,910, if it breaks the crucial resistance level of 10,785," Ratnaparkhi said.


Macro numbersThe government will release industrial production data for March on Friday. India's industrial output grew 7.1 per cent in February from a year earlier. This apart, the government will also unveil inflation data based on consumer price index (CPI) for April. Retail inflation stood at 4.28 per cent in March, slowing for the third straight month from a 17-month high, according to data released by the Central Statistics Office.


Global cuesThe big central banking event of next week is the Bank of England’s May 10 meeting, with market expectations overwhelmingly in favour of interest rates being held at the current 0.5 per cent. Interest rate bets have swung around sharply from early April when investors priced a 90 per cent chance of the BoE raising rates by 25 basis points, Reuters reported.

In addition, the Bank of Japan (BoJ) monetary policy meeting minutes will be unveiled on Monday, 7 May 2018.

The S&P BSE Sensex ended 0.15 per cent lower for the week at 34,915, while NSE’s Nifty settled at 10,618, down 0.69 per cent.

NEW DELHI: Asian Paints surged over 5 per cent in morning trade on Friday, a day after the company reported a 4 per cent YoY increase in its net profit at Rs 481 crore for March quarter. However, the numbers were much lower than ETNOW’s poll of Rs 542 crore.

The company had reported a profit of Rs 462.22 crore in the corresponding quarter last fiscal.

Total income of the company stood at Rs 4,531.52 crore against Rs 4,442.25 crore in the same period last year.

Basic and diluted EPS (earnings per share of the company) came in at Rs 5 against Rs 4.80 in the March quarter of FY2017.

Brokerage Kotak Securities in its research report observes despite a healthy headline EBITDA growth (+19 per cent) for the fourth quarter off a low base, Asian Paints ended FY2018 with a 7 per cent YoY EBITDA and 3 per cent YoY PAT growth. This forms the second consecutive year of the disappointing single-digit EBITDA and PAT growth for the company.

The brokerage house broadly retains its forecasts despite the Q4 miss and rising RM pressure. "Expensive valuation keeps us cautious. It has maintained 'Reduce' rating on the stock with an unchanged fair value target of Rs 1,100/share.

On the other hand, global brokerage Credit Suisse has upgraded the stock to 'neutral' from 'underperform' and raised the target price to Rs 1,220 from Rs 1,100. On a high base of around 14 per cent volume growth in Q4FY17, the company grew around 10 per cent in Q4, it says. The brokerage has upgraded the stock on improved visibility on both volumes and margins.

Santosh Singh, Head of Research, Haitong Securities, calls on investors to go stock specific rather than sectors. He told ET Now that impact of GST and demonetisation on consumption is thinning. And that's a major tailwind.Edited excerpts: 

The Karnataka Exit Poll results came by on Saturday. Could the reaction to the exit polls which are indicating a hung assembly be a little stark in the near term?
The exit polls appear confused. The market is also going to remain confused today. But tomorrow, when results come out, is more important. The macro trends are not looking so great and if tomorrow results are not so great for the ruling party at the Centre, then we will definitely see some amount of profit taking in the market. 


What are you advising clients to do at this point in time -- fresh positions or raising cash?
The micro trends are quite positive. In case of a lot of companies, there are earning upgrades. So, on a macro front we might see headwinds but on the micro front, we are seeing a lot of positive things happening. We would advise our clients to be stock-specific rather than buying the market or buying the sectors.


How should one read into commentary from US President Donald Trump on pharma. It is a mixed kind of feeler. On one side, Donald Trump is acknowledging that US healthcare costs are high and generic players have to increase their total presence in the US healthcare market, on the other hand he has not come out with anything specific to take the cost down or keep a check on insurance companies and the distributors. What does it mean for Indian pharma companies in the generic market? 

US generic is the key for Indian pharma companies and whatever we heard from President Trump appeared positive. At least talking about generics being important seems positive for the Indian pharma companies. For Indian pharma stock prices, there is a lot of negativity on the generic side. At this juncture, given the way rupee is moving, I would rather look at this sector because they have gone through a real tough times in last one year.


Sun TV has already done pretty well on year-to-date basis. The overhang of political uncertainty also is well behind it. Is there merit in buying the stock right now?
This is one of the strongest name in southern states. They have got really good franchise. The only problem has been the political uncertainty which keeps on coming. Although the numbers are really strong, given that next year is election year, you would not want to bet on something which is going to move on political uncertainties. I would rather look at it post elections when there is more certainty.


Ideally, paint companies should do poorly when crude prices or oil derivative prices are moving but Asian Paints has done the reverse. They have managed to report a volume growth and margin expansion at a time when oil and derivative prices have gone higher. What is your view?
The effect of GST and the DeMo are wearing off in the consumption sector. That is a positive, As such Indian consumption has been on a very strong footing for some time now. For the next one or two years, there will be a lot of focus or spending in this sector from the government side. So, whatever happens to the underlying inputs, demand is going to be very high this year and moving into next year. In this sector, we should not look at the second level derivative that is input prices. If the franchise is really strong, consumption as a story is going to play out very strongly in India.


How are you combing through the commodities basket for opportunities right now?
For last one, one-and-a-half month, we have been not much positive on the commodity stocks simply because the movement has been really sharp across the board in commodities and given the expectation of a revival of demand in Chinese economy and firming up of commodity prices globally, at this juncture. we are not big fans of mining, especially the metal side of the business. However, the only stock which we like for some time is Hindalco because non-ferrous is an area where we have been slightly positive on.



Are telcos really an avoid given all that is happening with part of the disruption?
Yes, for a long period of time, we have been talking about it. This is a matured sector which has been forced to become new entrant because a new entrant has come in and changed the rules of the game totally. Their profits are reducing and it does not seem like that competition is going to reduce from Jio. Also some of the rules are not really favouring the existing players. Clearly this is one sector I would not be buy into now.


Do you continue to steer clear of the PSU banks space?
One of the positives which is coming out is that we are seeing a peaking out of NPAs. If we are just going to look at that, then these companies might look interesting but my view has always been that leaving aside a State Bank of India or a Bank of Baroda, where is the franchise value lying in the PSBs? 

A lot of them are already into this PCR and then you have got hardly any franchise which is left with them. They are going to lose market share and I do not know for how much time they can keep the deposits because one of their biggest strengths has been that they did not lose deposit market share. They have been losing the retail loan market share. But I would think that if the things go on like this for some more time, then they might start losing deposit market share as well. 

That means they will lose franchise value as well. Within PSUs, we do not look at prices. The only buys we have or the only stock we like in this space is State Bank of India because that has been a totally different story within the PSU space. It is better run, NPL problems are not that high. They have not lost market share. They are competing with all other private sector banks. So, that is the only one. If we have to put a bet on PSU, that is the only one which we would like at this juncture.

ET Intelligence Group: India Inc is slowly overcoming its inertia despite turbulent politics, choppy markets and hardening oil prices. For a consumer economy plagued by supply overhang, promises of capital expenditure by several private sector companies after a year-long lull have stoked hopes of a rebound. Tata Steel, Ambuja Cements, Eicher Motors, Hero MotoCorp, Asian Paints, CEAT, Apollo Tyres and Jubilant FoodWorks are among the companies that have announced investments totalling Rs 50,000 crore in the past four months.

Jubilant FoodWorks, which paused store expansion in the previous fiscal, plans to open 75 new stores in FY19 following a six-year-high growth of 26.6% in the March 2018 quarter. High capacity utilisation and better demand visibility are major triggers for companies to commit — and in some cases even go ahead with — fresh capital investments. The growth in private capex in India slowed down to less than 7% annually between FY11 and FY17 for the BSE 200 companies (excluding banking and finance firms and IT). But this figure comes down to 2% if investments by Reliance Industries, which was largely driving the capex growth, are excluded.

Capex growth had risen at a rapid pace of 35% between FY03 and FY11. The gross capital formation of Indian companies, which reflects investments in assets, dropped to a decade-low 27% in the September 2017 quarter, according to the ministry of statistics and programme implementation.





‘Fund-Raise to Help Capex Cycle’ 
But industry trackers believe that the cycle is turning for the good and chances of a more evenly distributed capex growth are stronger.

“Uptick in housing cycle, revival in select industries and continued government support are the key positives. Also, companies are expected to raise $60 billion (around Rs 4 trillion) in the primary equity market in the next two years. This should help capex cycle,” said Amit Tiwari, Partner, Pineoak Capital, a wealth manager.

Morgan Stanley in a note a few months ago said, “We expect a positive inflexion point in the macrocycle in 2018. This will likely be marked by a synchronous recovery in domestic and external demand and, more importantly, a pick-up in private capex for the first time in six years.” And, in the customary chat with analysts, more and more companies are talking about capex plans — a conversation they refrained from in the past one year.

Typically, capacity utilisation of over 80% prompts companies to expand capacities. According to RBI data, capacity utilisation in the manufacturing sector rose to 74.1% in the December 2018 quarter from 71.2% in the June quarter. The capacity utilisation of several companies in the consumer discretionary sector has crossed 80% and some facilities are operating at the full capacity.

For Hero MotoCorp, utilisation reached 82% in FY18 on the current installed base of 9.2 million units. In the earnings concall after the March quarter results, the company announced it would spend Rs 2,500 crore to increase the capacity to 10 million by 2020. “The main objective of capacity expansion is to fulfil demand without facing capacity constraints,” said a company official of Hero MotoCorp.

Eicher Motors, the manufacturer of marque motorcycle Royal Enfield plans to increase the installed capacity to 1.2 million by FY21 from the current capacity of 0.95 million by investing Rs 800 crore. Analysts expect Royal Enfield to record 14% growth annually between FY18 and FY21, which will require the company to expand capacity.

In line with automakers, autoancillaries too are increasing capacities.

Subbiah Kumar, CFO at CEAT said, “We are increasing capacity since we expect demand to remain strong. We also anticipate increase in the wallet share from OEMs (original equipment manufacturers)”.

The capacity utilisation of CEAT is more than 80% and its truck and bus redial facility is at full utilisation. CEAT is investing Rs 4,000 crore in the next 2-3 years to increase its capacity to 1600 tons per day from around 1000 tons per day.

Its peer, Apollo Tyres is putting up a new greenfield facility inAndhra Pradesh by investing around Rs 1,800 crore.

Satish Sharma, president for Asia Pacific, Middle East & Africa at Apollo Tyres, said: “With the automotive sector being the shining star of the GDP growth, there is an increased demand for tyres. Amid the increased demand for tyres, our products, across categories, is getting a good traction. While the de-bottlenecking and brownfield capacity expansion will help us meet the demand now, the Andhra Pradesh greenfield, once ready, will cater to the increased demand for the next five years.”

The buoyancy in the disposable income is prompting multiplex operators to expand capacities.

PVR, India’s largest multiplex operator, plans to open 90 screens in the current fiscal with an investment of Rs 450 crore.

Nitin Sood, CFO of PVR, said the company is stepping up the pace of screen additions and upgrade of existing screen portfolio.

The other large multiplex operator, Inox plans to open 55 screens in FY19 by spending Rs 250 crore.

Here’s a lowdown on top macro triggers that may move market on Tuesday. This report was compiled from agency feeds.



Goyal to Handle Finance for Now, Smriti Irani Out of I&B 
In a major rejig of the Modi cabinet, the Union Railway Minister Piyush Goyal will now be given the additional charge of the Finance Ministry till Arun Jaitley recovers from a kidney transplant surgery. Smriti Irani, who had the extra charge of Information & Broadcasting Ministry, has been moved out and will now look after textiles ministry only. Sports Minister Rajyavardhan Singh Rathore has been given independent charge as Minister of State in the I&B Ministry. Union minister of state S S Ahluwalia, was relieved of his charges of Ministry of Drinking Water & Sanitation and was assigned the Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology, replacing Alphons Kannanthanam who continues as Minister of State for Tourism. 


Karnataka Results to be Out Today
The counting of votes cast in 222 Assembly constituencies in Karnataka on May 12 will be taken up on Tuesday morning. The ruling Congress and the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) fought in all 222 constituencies while the Janata Dal-Secular (JD-S) fielded candidates for 201 seats. Its ally Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) contested 21 seats. The market would possibly be happier with the JD-S allying with the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) instead of the Congress. 


Oil Cos Resume Raising Prices
State-run oil companies have resumed raising prices of petrol and diesel following the conclusion of voting in Karnataka. Prices of petrol and diesel have been raised by y 17 paise and 21 paise, respectively, resuming price revision after a 19-day rate freeze ahead of voting in Karnataka. No Units or Offices in India, Yet MNCs Slapped Tax Notices 
The I-T department's zeal to scoop up extra revenue continues. A US-based multinational company without a subsidiary or representative office in India received a notice by post asking it to file returns for assessment year 2011-12 for income that India’s tax department claimed had escaped assessment. Tax experts said many companies had been served similar notices for not filing returns. This could also result in transfer pricing compliance issues if the payer is a related party in India such as a subsidiary. The recent budget amendment enables authorities to initiate prosecution proceedings for not filing tax returns.This has many MNCs worried.


RBI Puts Deposit, Lending Curbs on Allahabad Bank 
The Reserve Bank has imposed restrictions on Allahabad Bank lending to risky assets and raising high-cost deposits in view of its deteriorating financial health. The directive has come within days of the RBI imposing similar restrictions on another state-run lender Dena Bank, which is under the Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) of the central bank. Meanwhile, the government today said it has initiated action for removal of Allahabad Bank CEO Usha Ananthasubramanian following the CBI's first chargesheet in the $2 billion fraud at PNBN detailing her role. Ananthasubramanian was the managing director of PNB till May 5 last year. 


Indians Send Maximum Money Back Home
With migrant workers sending home $69 billion in 2017, India was the largest remittance- receiving country in the world, says a report 'RemitSCOPE - Remittance markets and opportunities - Asia and the Pacific. India ($69 billion), China ($64 billion) and the Philippines ($33 billion) are the three largest remittance- receiving countries in the world in 2017. Pakistan ($20 billion), and Vietnam ($14 billion) are also in the top 10. About 70% of remittances sent to Asia and the Pacific come from outside the region and in particular from the Gulf States (32%), North America (26%) and Europe (12%). 


Metals to Drive Stability in Corporate Outlook for 2018-19: Ind-Ra 
Profitability improvement last year mainly in the metals sector is expected to keep corporate outlook for the new fiscal stable, but a broad-based recovery could take much longer, India Ratings said. A report by the ratings agency also said that even though EBITDA growth could could be between 8% to 11% in 2018-19, headwinds from rising oil prices, higher commodity prices, higher interest cost and a depreciation in rupee could limit the expected growth.

Investment rationale by JeffriesAPNT Q4FY18 revenue and EBITDA growth of 14.7% YoY and 18.7% YoY, respectively, came slightly ahead of our estimates but PAT growth of 4.9% YoY was lower due to higher than expected tax rate. 10% YoY decorative volume growth suggests some recovery and addresses concerns of market share loss to an extent. Mgmt calling out improvement in demand conditions is heartening, something that was not heard in the past three quarters. Maintain BUY with PT of INR1,385.


Topline: Decorative paint volumes saw double digit volume growth of 10% YoY post 5 quarters despite a high base of 9% YoY. Overall consolidated business grew 14.7% YoY also aided by improved performance in industrial JVs (largely driven by auto OEM and General Industrial). Performance of home improvement improved sharply during Q4FY18 and H2FY18. International business was impacted by currency fluctuations in Egypt and Ethopia and sluggish demand in Srilanka.

Margins: Consolidated gross margins dipped 47bps YoY while EBITDA margins expanded 62bps YoY with 76bps YoY improvement in other expenses. YoY dip in gross margin has been coming down each quarter since Q1FY18 and expected to come off as the same comes into base going forward. Standalone business saw 20bps YoY expansion in margins and 155bps YoY improvement in EBITDA margins. Higher input prices impacted the overall margins in the industrial, international and home improvement business.

Key highlights from analyst meet (details inside): Demand improved for the paint industry during H2FY18. Rural growth was higher than urban growth for the company. Mix improvement helped the overall gross margins. Not losing market share, not witnessing shift from unorganized to organised and vice versa. Demand for both Sleek and Ess Ess have picked by in H2FY18 with growth of 18% in Sleek and 32% in Ess Ess during H2FY18.

Valuation/RisksWe adjust our FY18 numbers to that of the full year leading to ~1% cut in topline; however, we increase our EPS estimates for FY19/20 by 3%/4%, respectively, as we built in higher margin expansion on the back of better mix, cost savings and improving demand environment leading to better leverage. While steep valuations limit potential for re-rating, we believe EPS growth trajectory of ~20% over FY18-20 should help sustain multiples. We maintain our target multiple of 45x Mar20E EPS (~10% premium to its five-year average multiple) to arrive at PT of INR1385 (INR1330 earlier). Key risks: 1) lower volume growth; 2) sharp rise in key inputs like crude and Tio2.

A day after paring 120 points from the high point of the day, the Nifty continued to remain weak on Wednesday, as it opened with a modest gapdown and drifted lower during the session.

The market made an attempt to recover from the day’s lows, but ended the trade losing 60.75 points or 0.56 per cent.

While keeping aside the prevailing uncertainties over Karnataka politics – even though it had short-lived sentimental effect -- the present technicals continue to point towards more consolidation.

We are likely to see a quiet opening on Thursday, and the previous day’s low and its range would be an important support to watch out for. The zones of 10,680-10,700 would be immediate levels wherein the Nifty might consolidate again. Thursday will see the levels of 10,745 and 10,785 acting as immediate resistance. Supports will come in at 10,680 and 10,625.



The Relative Strength Index (RSI) on the daily chart is 60.1660, and it continues to remain neutral showing no divergence against the price. The daily MACD stays bullish, while trading above its signal line. On the candles, a ‘Spinning Top’ was formed. It has a small real body and signifies a session full of indecisiveness on part of market participants. 

Pattern analysis reveals that the Nifty has stalled its upmove, which it had resumed after suffering a throwback. The index has broken out of a broad rectangle formation as evident from the charts. However, even after a throwback and subsequent resumption of the upmove, the Nifty still appears to remain under consolidation.

Overall, though we can expect some stability to come in, volatility is still likely to remain very much ingrained in the session. Though any structural breakdown may not happen, still oscillations within a given range are likely to remain volatile.

Also, the higher levels of Nifty PCR (Put to Call Ratio) still remain a concern.

We expect consolidation to continue, as the Nifty is likely to oscillate keeping the range of 10,785-10,930 as its major resistance area for the immediate short term.

Highly cautious and stock specific approach is advised for the day.

The billion dollar question on everybody's lip is if Narendra Modi is coming back to power next year. That narrative is going to be a driving force for market sentiment and price multiples for the next 12 months. Gautam Chhaochharia, ED and Head of India Research, UBS, spoke to ET Now. Edited excerpts:


Why is there such a selloff in mid-cap stocks? The fact that the tide has turned for small and mid-cap stocks is quite worrying?
For a few reasons possibly; one is the starting valuations were becoming almost frothy and not just rich for a few mid-caps and small caps. Secondly, macro headwinds are hurting local sentiments. People had made a lot of money in small mid-caps. The normal tendency would be to book profits there rather than keep hoping for more upside for valuations. 

The last thing is that the flows from foreign investors have been weak this year, both in absolute terms as well as in the context of global emerging market flows. That also adds to the negative sentiment for this asset class for local investors including HNIs and mutual funds.


Where are we headed from here? Do you feel that some of these mid-caps, which are falling for no reason and are fundamentally sound companies, are almost reaching that trough point where they could again be considered for a buy? Is there still some more pain to go for mid and small caps at large? 
It is always tricky to have a single view on Mid and small caps as an asset class. There are always bottom-up opportunities in the correction phase. There are mid and small caps which have done well in absolute terms also. But , if we want to stretch that argument, valuations in mid and small cap indices -- both in absolute as well as in relation to large caps -- is still not a level where we would say go overweight on mid-caps. We are still underweight in mid-caps from the broader market perspective. But yes, select opportunities always are there.


How are you approaching the markets post this earnings season especially, as there has been a big carnage in the broader markets?
It will be a mix of many signals. The global signals will still be the dominant driver possibly. The local signals are the earnings. The earnings season has been reasonably okay this time with many consumer facing businesses reporting positive surprise in volume growth.

On the other hand, in the next few months we will see if there is any potential support to rural economy from the government in the form of stimulus or fiscal expansion. The various models which we have elaborated and analysed in our recent note, including the model followed by MP or Telangana, would have a bearing on how the specific mid-cap and small cap stocks as well as the broader markets perform. 

Lastly, there is the narrative around 2019 elections. We are just a year away from the national elections. The narrative around whether Mr Modi is coming back or not next year will be a driving force for market sentiment and multiples for the next 12 months.


Do you think the Karnataka election was well priced in with that 1.5% volatility that we saw on the index and also the fact that mid-caps after having started off the day very well, fell pretty sharply from the top of the day?
The markets are pricing in that the BJP will form a government in Karnataka but beyond Karnataka. it is not about whether they form a government in Karnataka or not. The bigger narrative here is what it means for 2019 elections and that is what will drive the market reactions. 

So, if the Karnataka outcome starts showing up that the JD(S) and Congress are getting together, then it does add some level of discomfort around the Modi narrative for 2019. What is more important for investors to track is the fragmentation or unity among opposition parties and that will be the bigger delta in terms of the possibility of this government coming back in 2019. Markets clearly hope for and are pricing in Mr Modi’s return given the strong track-record of reforms over the last four years.


Are we done with the highs for the year and it is going to be perhaps very difficult for markets to a) go to the previous high and then b)stay above that?
Going above the highs is not too much from the current levels. It can definitely go there. You need four, five days of strong flows or strong buying and so that is not a big deal. But yes, fundamentally our base case for Nifty for December 2018 still remains 10500 and if I look at our upside downside scenarios also, the risk reward is definitely not attractive. 
Our recommendation to investors is not to get in or buy at these levels. They will get better opportunities later in the year.


When we started the year, nobody was pencilling in an uptick of 20% in crude prices. Nobody was pencilling in a 70, 80 or even a 100 bps uptick in bond yields, or a LTCG. Yet markets have been strong. The expensive stocks have even become bigger and the PE multiples for HUL, Asian Paints, even Maruti has only expanded. Why are markets getting more and more polarised?
As you said, it is a mix of rising macro concerns but still strong inflows. If you have inflows, you have to buy stocks. If you have concerns, then you try to hide in quality. Exactly that is what is playing out and as for the markets as long as the flows remain strong the markets may not correct in a big way.

Even with India’s rising macro concerns, over the last few months, the global macro backdrop has been quite supportive so that we have seen risk assets largely being okay. 

Emerging markets have seen more than $50 billion of inflows and that is why we have not seen any major outflows out of Indian equity markets despite some concerns on valuations and macro. The key here is the sentiment and flows. Sentiment has taken a back seat over the last two-three months given the macro concerns but the flows remains strong and we still have not seen any desperation amongst investors globally or locally to really start cutting down exposures in India.


 What should be the approach for the rest of the year? At a time of dwindling macros, there is still a little bit of a question mark on which way globally things are headed. Crude is a big cause of concern which is also weighing heavy on our macros and then there is the political uncertainty. Should one buy more of the same - more of HDFC Banks, Marutis, TCSs of the world or take a more bottom up approach?
I would say a mix of both. In this backdrop, the quality names will do well but there are select bottom up opportunities sectorally and stock wise, which investors should push because the long-term story for India still remains intact. 

There is debate on global growth outlook, about a synchronised recovery or lack of that. But nobody is saying we will see a big recession anytime in a hurry. The backdrop is still okay and we should not panic where you sell out and get out in a hurry. Look at the right stocks at the right levels. Bottom up always works in India and this year also should continue to work in India.


How would you approach the entire consumption theme and select stocks within that?
We are looking at two themes there. One is in general, the rural exposed businesses should do well whether we see a major policy support for rural or more rhetoric than actual money being spent. Any which way, the rural sectors will be supported this year ahead of elections and the commentary there should be positive.

Secondly, companies or specific companies on a bottom-up basis where we are seeing clear signs or normalisation of supply chain, gaining market share from informal sector as GST, e-way bill etc gets rolled out this year. Those would be the other opportunities from a bottom up fundamental perspective. And then we overlay that with where the stocks multiples are compared to recent history, medium term history and how the stocks have done and see what they are pricing in and that does throw up interesting bottom up ideas from that space and that is what we will stick to.


Where is value emerging in the mid-cap space now.
So, there is no space as such but yes bottom up there are opportunities in segments where the micro picking up is not broad-based but there are signals for sectors or stocks already visible. That would be an interesting area to look at. That is where the value is because the markets are not pricing in that recovery. Markets are reacting a lot more in terms of immediate numbers, not so much forward looking. That’s why it is reacting very violently in terms of the Q4 numbers on both positive and negative side.

NEW DELHI: It's a sweet and sour feeling the way March quarter earnings have panned out so far.

The short point is there were only a few positive surprises as the season enters its last lap. And the numbers at best are in line with market expectations. 

A few consumption-driven sectors continued with their recent volume-driven growth. But red flags are going up. Rising raw material costs could play a spoilsport for some of them, going ahead. PSU banks with record losses disappointed the most. 

Combined sales of 1,040-odd companies -- apart from PSU and private banks -- climbed 14.9 per cent while their net profit surged 37 per cent on a low base last year. The March quarter of 2017 turned out to be painful for India Inc because of the cash ban announced in November 2016.

Top line rose to Rs 11,55,547 crore compared with Rs 10,05,488 crore in the year-ago quarter. The bottom line for the universe swelled to Rs 1,06,437 crore from Rs 77,801 a year earlier. 

On a sequential basis, sales for these companies went up 7.62 per cent. Profit advanced 4.14 per cent, Capitaline data showed, as compiled by ETMarkets.com.

Banks, especially PSU ones, made jaw-dropping NPA provisions during the March quarter. The result: as many as 14 banks reeled under losses amounting to Rs 46,593 crore. This includes PNB's record loss of Rs 13,416.90 crore. SBI (Rs 7,542 crore), Canara Bank (Rs 4,860 crore) and Allahabad bank (Rs 3,510 crore) suffered huge losses too. 

To give you a perspective, these 14 PSU lenders had reported Rs 4,338 crore loss in the year-ago quarter. If private and public lenders are taken into account, the 1,070 firms reported a 15 per cent drop in net profit at Rs 71,072 crore for January-March.

"So far, the earnings season has been on expected lines. The upgrades and downgrades are by and large equal to each other following which the earnings estimate for the next year has only been marginally cut by about a per cent," said Neelotpal Sahai of HSBC Asset Management India.

From the Nifty bloc, Eicher Motors, Asian Paints, SBI, Axis Bank, ICICI Bank, Vedanta, HCL Tech, Wipro, Bharti Airtel and Bharti Infratel fell short of profit estimates. Others such as Bajaj Auto, UltraTech Cement, Hindustan Unilever, Bajaj Finance, HDFC, Lupin, Zee Entertainment, Hindalco, Tata Steel and Yes Bank came out on top.

"Consumer-oriented sectors from paints to consumer staples delivered not only good results, but very strong commentary on revenue and margin expansion. In some ways, that bullish guidance actually surprised me because I felt that commodity price spike would make them a little more circumspect about margins. Both consumer discretionary and staples are doing fine. Energy companies too performed well," Manishi Raychaudhuri of BNP Paribas told ET Now.

For the FMCG sector, what worked is the revival in rural growth, which has beaten the figure for urban areas for three quarters now. 

Metal companies have been putting up a strong earnings show, buoyed by a pick-up in metal prices. This partly hurt outlook for automakers though, which points to further impact of raw material inflation in H1 FY19. They may partially try to offset it by passing on the cost to consumers, said Motilal Oswal Securities. 

The squeeze was on the telecom sector, which saw ARPU downtrading due to renewed competition. That means Ebitda margin for the telcos may remain under pressure, going forward.

"Earning have been mixed bag so for, with IT , Cement , FMCG, Metal, Select private sector banks performing better on revenue, margin and net profit parameters. Some of the high frequency economic data-points such cement production, air traffic growth, petrol/diesel consumption, automobile sales among others, suggest a strong recovery in the economy. Revival in urban demand along with good monsoon led recovery in rural demand would augur well for the economy and corporate earnings," said Hemang Jani of Sharekhan. 

For the IT sector, FY19 should see an improvement on a low FY18 base, but the outlook is not exactly euphoric, the brokerage noted. According to Raychaudhuri, the currency depreciation has been a tailwind for software firms.

"In oil and gas space, refining margins have been good. Marketing margins have also been good after a tepid Q3 FY18. Outlook remains uncertain in light of high oil prices, a depreciating rupee, unwillingness of the government to cut excise duties on auto fuels, and the upcoming elections," Motilal Oswal Securities said.

Results of cement companies came in above expectations, led by lower-than-expected price decline and a better cost curve. The impact of higher petcoke and diesel prices was mitigated by better operating leverage and other cost efficiency measures, the brokerage added.

Jani said that the outlook for cement sector remains neutral as players across regions except eastern markets will continue to experience pricing pressure."Moreover high Fuel expenses & logistics cost will keep margins under pressure," he said. 

So, where does that leave us with? The market will continue to be more truncated in favour of companies that can grow with earnings visibility, said Dhananjay Sinha of Emkay Global Financial Services.

"A rise in crude prices which can put pressure on margins due to higher Input costs. It could havesome growth and revenue repurcusion for FMCG, Cement , automobile sector. A rise in metal prices can be dampaner for construction & automotive industry & electrical component industry. Most of the Managements have shown concern regarding higher commodity prices . However, they said they will take price hike if required to pass on the higher RM cost. But we believe price hike might be challenging," Jani said.

Krishna Kumar Karwa, Chief Executive and Managing Director, Emkay Global, spells out the art of making money from a three-year perspective. Other than putting 60-70% money in smallcaps, split the rest in midcaps and largecaps.Edited excerpts: 

A long-term optimist like you and me always try to look at the bright side. Buy today I am struggling, I am struggling because the core assumptions have got challenged on the interest rate front, on the oil front and also on the earnings front?
As you rightly said, macros are challenging and oil has gone up to $80 odd and that has had huge ramifications for a country like India which imports a lot of oil. On top of that, rupee at around 68.5 and hardening interest rates are adding to macro woes. My sense is we are in a cyclical upturn as can be seen by the performance of many of the domestic facing companies in Q3 as well as Q4.

There is this continuous mismatch between macro headwinds and micro. There is a lot of positives in micro and investors are caught in a dilemma. I believe that valuations are going to be the key trigger and that is what we are seeing of late in the last few months. Since valuations have been rich, people have been taking money off the table and liquidity seems to be strong. But let us see how that behaves. So, yes, very challenging environment from a short-term investor perspective but over a longer time frame, it all evens out.


In future, would all those who participated in the market in May 2018, be a happy lot or would those who do not participate and who hang on to their cash and capital have the last laugh?
A very short-term perspective is not the right way of looking at investing. Every investor has his own asset allocation strategy and risk return pay offs. But the fact remains that if you are looking from a short-term perspective, then returns are going to be challenging. Timing the market is always going to be a challenge. It is best to stick to your asset allocation strategy and accordingly have cash and equity or cash and other assets in your portfolio. Broadly keep an eye on valuations and your asset allocation strategy.


With the currency weakness, could there be a meaningful turnaround in the way one views IT and pharma?
From the last six months’ perspective, It stocks have already delivered stellar returns and that was not driven by rupee depreciation. It was primarily driven by attractive valuations. Even now, most of the companies have guided for a high single digit growth and some of them may have low double-digit growth. The question in the IT stocks or IT industry is basically about growth and opportunities in terms of the valuations. 

In order to invest in any sector or company on the basis of just one parameter, in this case currency, is not the right way to look at investing. A whole host of factors should be considered before investing but IT has done reasonably well. Most of the stocks are now probably quoting at very high valuations vis-à-vis the foreseeable growth in the industry. My judgment is that the run-up is over. 

As far as pharma is concerned, we are aware of the headwinds that pharma companies faced in last two years from their US businesses. Most of it is reflected in the stock prices but it is still a work in progress. May be the stocks have have bottomed out in terms of performances but valuations for the return ratios which are foreseeable in the next two years versus that valuations are still slightly expensive. May be one more year of pain is there before we can look to invest. May be, long-term investors can start accumulating at every decline but still some more time has to go as far as the US-focussed pharma companies are concerned.


The other interesting aspect of this market is that big is getting better, expensive is getting more expensive. Why is it that only 15, 20, 25 stocks are holding the market higher? If you knock off an Asian Paints, TCS may be a HUL, an ITC from the equation, the rest of the market is looking very hollow and this kind of a polarised market is never good news.
You have hit the nail on the head. Institutional investors tend to hide with each other in terms of in the stocks that they invest in. Currently the momentum seems to be with the name that you have mentioned and may be many of the institutional investors are not adequately invested in these stocks

The momentum seems to be there and they are hiding in these kind of stocks which are very expensive as you rightly said and I do not know how much return can investors make by investing in such expensive stocks, Ultimately you have to have an eye on valuations. It is going to catch up and we have seen that happening across market caps in the last 12-18 months. Wherever investors have ignored the valuations and have invested in momentum, it has never delivered returns. Then comes one small negative news and you lose the maximum over there. So, this is more of a hiding or a relative performance kind of a strategy than an opportunity which can help make absolute returns.


The earnings continue to be patchy. We do not know what banks would do. We do not know what pharma is doing. Cyclical companies are yet to go off the block. For someone who bought HUL or Titan three years ago, it was more expensive then. But frankly, in terms of returns they have managed to beat cyclical stocks hands down. This is a dilemma. Those stocks are expensive yet are making money. 
The stocks that you mentioned are all industry leaders in their respective segments. Their return and growth parameters and the way they have grown is obviously much superior than the rest. There will be paucity of floating stocks.

May be three-four-five years ago when you invested, they were expensive and today also they are making returns but there are intervening period when even such stocks do have their consolidation or relatively underperformance period versus the markets. The ability to stay invested in these stocks over longer timeframes is the key criteria which enables you to be able to earn the returns that you are talking of. 

As far as you are invested in top quality stocks across timeframe, they will deliver the returns despite some underperformances in the intervening period. It is all function of how you are positioning your portfolio and these kind of stocks do add lot of stability to your portfolios but you cannot only be invested in such expensive stocks. Somewhere valuations will catch up. 


How can one make money by investing the Krishna Kumar Karwa way?
First of all, let us look at the definitions of the market cap itself. As per the SEBI norms the top 100 companies become large caps which end at around Rs 30,000-crore market cap; then you have the next 150 companies which becomes the midcaps which ends at around Rs 9,000-crore market cap. All companies below Rs 9000 crore or Rs 8800 crore are small cap companies. 

If you go back Nifty, you see that over a longer timeframe it is the investing which you do in the smaller caps which gives you bigger compounding returns whether over a three-year timeframe or five-year timeframe. The first criteria according to me is that, based on your risk appetite, maybe 60-70% of your portfolio should be invested in good quality companies which are below this Rs 9000-crore market cap, today’s definition of small caps. That is the first segment that you look to invest in because those are the companies which will create multibaggers for you over a timeframe. 

I hope I have answered your question on where to put your money. 60-70% should go into the small cap sector and then maybe the balance can be split between your large caps and the midcap segments. That is my split as far as investing is concerned again from three-year perspective. 

As far as sectors are concerned, you need to be invested more in the leaders of these sectors that you are looking invest in. A leader in the sense the companies which you believe can become the leaders in the small cap segment. It is the same in NBFCs, consumption or auto ancillaries, Be amongst the top two-three companies which fall into this category.

That is why I believe that over a two-three-year period you should be able to perform significantly better than the markets.

The correct way to approach a stock is to have an internal reference of what the business is worth. If Mr Market is giving you that price, sell higher 
  to Mr Market. If it is below that, buy from Mr Market, Mohnish Pabrai, Managing Partner of Pabrai Funds, tells Tanvir Gill and Nikunj Dalmia of ET Now.Edited excerpts:

You have told earlier that a business which you like in India is Piramal Enterprises. The Piramal Enterprises balance sheet is pretty much like Berkshire Hathaway, balance sheet in terms of disclosure, in terms of what they indicate and what they communicate. Here is a business which has potential to be a great compounder. What would you do there?
In a case like Piramal, there is some uncertainty around the fact that Ajay is going into relatively new areas which he has not been before and the markets always wonder if he is he going to stumble. You are absolutely right, a business like Piramal is a bluechip business. It is a very high quality and relatively low uncertainty business but for me, it was not a low risk high uncertainty bet as much as it was a jockey bet. 

Ajay has a few strong traits. One is he is very driven to deliver shareholder value in a very ethical way. Another of those traits is that he is a compounding machine and he cares about those things. A lot of management teams do not understand capital allocation and compounding and taking care outside shareholders. Riding on Ajay’s Piramal Enterprises is not a bad idea.


There was a lot of drama that played out with Rain Industries. The day the stock sold out, the side talk in the market was check with Mohnish Pabrai, is he selling? How do you look at the business out there? What have they reported in terms of earnings in the last quarter?
 I am not into stock tips and I do not want people to take it as stock picks. If we discuss Rain, it will be from the perspective of getting educated on how to deal with markets. From my perspective, there is really no drama in Rain at all. This is a business that I invested in about two and a half years ago vis-à-vis the price today. There is a six to one difference in my favour and so I have no complaints. 

It used to be 10 to 1. Two and a half years ago, they delivered a 10x. It is in the nature of equity markets that we are going to have extreme swings. Rain Industries, at one point in 2015, was priced at Rs 35 a share. A few months ago, it was priced at over Rs 400 a share. Now, it is priced at Rs 200 odd a share. The market is there to serve us, it is not there to instruct us.

We are not going to look at the stock price and then try to figure out what is going on. That will be a wrong way to approach it. The correct way to approach it is to have an internal reference of what the business is worth. If Mr Market is giving you that price, sell higher Mr Market. If it is below that, buy from Mr Market. We have a higher position in Rain today than we had three months ago and I am almost pretty much at the limit of the amount I am allowed to buy. We have to stay below 10% and we are just under that. I wish I could buy more, but I cannot.


Where do you see this lethal combination of high uncertainty and low risk going because that is your hunting ground.
Rain was a great example of low-risk high -uncertainty in 2015 and even in 2016. At that point, the company was going for Rs 30 or Rs 40 a share and there was a high probability that in the next three-four years, earnings per share would be equal to the price of the stock PO1. If I am buying at Rs 30 or Rs 40 and the earnings in 2018 or 2019 are going to be Rs 30 or Rs 40, I do not need a calculator and I do not need excel sheet. I do not even need a high IQ. In case of Rain, from the time I first heard of it to the time I placed the buy order was three hours. It was a very obvious investment and today I would say that this is probably not as obvious as it was then, but I have a better understanding of the business.

I have owned it for a while and we had a similar situation 12 or 14 months ago in real estate in Mumbai and other places. So, low risk, high uncertainty shows up very frequently in option driven markets.


That is not your only investment philosophy. When we scan through your portfolio, you also have Repo Home which is in housing finance because it is not a cheap stock from price to book perspective. There is certainty of growth because housing finance companies have been doing really well. So how do you play that story, what is the conviction that drives you there?
I would say, one should be really careful of levered institutions. In general, there are some elements of bubble in housing finance, maybe not amongst the listed players but anyone with some money wants to start a housing finance company and we are starting to see some of them having difficulties. I think lending is a difficult business. One of the simple things to remember while lending is when you make a sale, the cash leaves, it is not good to be in a business like that. One has to have a really strong approach to make sure that cash comes back. 

I have looked at several of the housing finance companies. Repco is a little bit unusual in the sense that the demographics are servicing typically do not have any competition. The only competition they have is the usurious money lender in the village who is charging 30-40-50%. They are actually taking people away from that type of environment into a more sensible environment. So they are getting into rural geographies and the Rs 10 lakh ticket price type areas. They have a moat around that. 

The second more important thing with them is that in the last 10 plus years, the write offs approached zero. So they have had NPAs and all of that but they have always had write backs against that. The actual write offs have been rounding error and that is the most important thing. One of the things I do not know as an investor is we do not know what happens in the future. So, I am making an extrapolation that the lending discipline they have had in the past will continue in the future. I am in a business with the high error rate, 30-40% error rates is normal even for Warren Buffett. We will see how it plays out but I think the odds are good.


Buffett also says that we love bad news as long as it is temporary because that gives us an opportunity to invest. If I look at classic compounder in India, that has been HDFC Bank. It never gave bad news and for those waited for bad news, they have never got one. How does one identify classic compounders like Asian Paints or HUL or HDFC Bank because they do not give bad news?
We are not going to be able to understand probably 99% of the companies. I probably understand less than 100 businesses in India that are probable listed and it is perfectly fine. In baseball, it is three strikes and you are out. Warren always says that in the investing business, they are no call strikes and so I love to be HDFC Bank investor. I am not an investor in HDFC Bank. I can get myself to buy at present prices, perfectly fine. There are 100 other ways to invest. One does not need to do it by looking at the past grade compounders. The investing business is a very forgiving business. We can do really well in the business even if we do not understand 98% of the markets and the companies in the market.


If we get the 2% right?
 It is very important to stay within circle of competence.


What would you define is your circle of competence? In the past, you have bought auto companies, commodity convertors, a seed company, real estate companies. What is the starting point which gets you to say hello to a stock? How do you start analysing a business?
One, what happens in any of our minds is in the first 30 seconds when we first encounter a company, it has a huge long term impact on our net worth. In the first 30 seconds you have to make a decision. Do I spend 30 more seconds more, or and another 5 minutes and then do I spend another half an hour? You keep going. At what point do you say that this is out and this is in? The data set is too large. If we were to spend a month on each business, we would never get to, probably 99.99% of the opportunities.

The way I look at the investing business is to be a harsh grader. Being a harsh grader means we have no call strikes. It is perfectly fine to say no to a company that ends up being a 100 bagger later. That is perfectly fine but it is more important not to have too many errors in your portfolio. Basically, when we look at these companies, I just have to ask myself if this is something I am able to get my arms around, something within my competence? 

Take the auto industry. I hated the auto industry. I still hate the auto industry, but 30% of my portfolio is in the auto industry. I have had huge returns in the auto industry. I spent about two-and-a-half months studying the auto industry before we actually became significant investors in such but at the end of two-and-a-half month period, I had certain insights that I felt were correct and that the market did not understand them so in that case it took a while. 

In the case of other Industries, it took a very short period of time. So, that is the nature of investing, Sometimes you can get to the finish line really fast and sometimes it takes a while. When I look at Repco Home, one of the first things I asked when I looked at any lender is what is their track record on defaults? What is their track record on the ability to collect back and how does management internally view that aspect of the business that is a very fundamental part of the business? Everyone can talk about spreads and all that, but is that the main driver or not? That is how I try to go at it.

Neeraj Dewan, Director, Quantum Securities, explains to ET Now that in the good quality midcap and smallcap stocks, the selling could be over.Edited excerpts:

There has been a selloff in the smallcap index for the last couple of months. What would you attribute the selling pressure to? Would it be the rally that we have witnessed in 2016 and 2017 or is the outlook going forward looks bleak with all the headwinds in terms of elections?
Multiple factors. are responsible. You cannot attribute this to one factor. Of course, one factor which is more significant, is what we witnessed in February, March. A lot of froth was building up in the midcaps and the smallcaps. Investors were buying anything and everything which anyone was suggesting. As froth built up, all these stocks became very expensive and ran much ahead of valuations. 

Not only the good quality stocks, even bad quality stocks, were running ahead at that time. There were no fundamentals to back them but still there was a lot of buying activity in those stocks. 

That was one of the major reasons which led to this froth building up. After the capital gains tax news came in the budget and with crude prices going up, there was talk about political uncertainty as well. All these negative factors aggravated the fall which started in March. 

In between, in April, we did stabilise a bit but then again with the crude going up, the talk of macro picture getting bleak, all that led to this kind of a fall in the midcaps and the smallcaps. Now, the thing has reversed. Everyone is talking about running towards safety, running towards largecaps and avoiding midcaps. Investors are not just avoiding midcaps, they are in fact dumping midcaps. 

Selling across the spectrum -- whether it is good quality or bad quality midcaps, smallcaps -- is taking place.


A large part of the fall in the broader markets has already taken place. Do you think there is another 10-15% fall in store or are we at the fag-end of this selloff?
I do not think there is too much of a downside left in good quality midcap stocks, though another 10-15% downside can’t be ruled out. The 10-15% fall is the maximum limit because a lot of these midcaps have already fallen a lot.

I saw advanced decline. The Nifty and the Sensex fell because stocks like HDFC, TCS, Asian Paints and Hindustan Lever led the fall from the top today. You may get some correction in the index but a large part of the correction in the mid-caps and small caps, at least the good quality ones, would have already got over. 

People may still be realising that they have some of the junk stocks in their portfolio, which they were expecting to rebound and which they may still keep selling. But in the good quality midcap and smallcap stocks, the selling may be over.


Other than Q4 GDP data, the macro picture does not look very encouraging. How do you see the macro picture from here onwards and what direction would the markets take based on that?
There are factors like crude, pressure on the rupee, which are mostly dependent on global factors and for this, we cannot really take a call right now. There has been some correction in crude prices. One does not know whether that correction will continue.

One good pointer was the US payroll numbers. Our GDP numbers are growing. We saw good sales growth in automobile and commercial vehicles continuing. This is giving some sort of an indication that growth is there and it is improving though it may be improving slowly. 

Somewhere down the line, there has to be a balance where you may get some factors like inflation going up. You may have some interest rate hike also. You may have an interest rate hike as early as this week as far as the domestic market is concerned and next week as far as US markets are concerned. 

If that is coming and the growth is also there, that small increase will get absorbed in the markets. That is my understanding. After the correction, you will get opportunities. If inflation is going up further, and if people start talking about political uncertainty, there will be some volatility in the markets which may even give you better opportunity.

As far as domestic growth is concerned, the numbers that we have seen and the kind of NPA resolutions that we have seen and even in the large part of the market which is the PSU banks or the corporate facing banks, a large part of negative is already priced in and they are already visible. Incrementally, I do not see any further deterioration there.

In fact, going from Q1 or this year you may start seeing some improvement happening as far as the NPAs are concerned. The provisions that they had taken, was because of the February 12th circular in the last quarter of last year. Going ahead, the pressure of provisioning may start decreasing on those stocks also. Incrementally, I feel that negatives are more or less priced in and you may get some volatility because of global factors which or inflation going up which you cannot price in right now but I think those will only be opportunities.


Your top bets are Quantum and there is DCM Shriram as well. What is the rationale behind liking this one?
One, there has been a massive correction in the stock. The massive correction was because of two factors. a), they took huge inventory losses because of sugar prices coming down in the last quarter and there were some write-offs that they took on the bio-seed business.

That write-off was something which they have already taken and which may not get repeated. They have taken a major hit as far as fall in the sugar prices are concerned but major profit for them now over the last few years have started building up because of their chlorovinyl division which earlier used to be 30% of their business and which has now become 37-38% as of last quarter. Going ahead, it will go up to 40-42% of their business and that is where they are doing their capex also.

They are doing a planned capex of about Rs 1100 crore because there will be more cogeneration capacity coming in. Distillery capacity has also come in last quarter. All that capex is coming in 2019-2020 and it will keep on showing the growth on their top line and profitability will also improve based on chlorovinyl.

Sugar is one part where they have taken a hit but going ahead at least in this season 60% of the sales has already been accounted for in mark to market. Any fall from the levels which you have seen earlier may be a negative but that is something which has already seen some bounce.

Because of these negative factors, the stock has already corrected to Rs 260-270 and that is available at 4-4.2 times EV-EBITDA. It has a very decent valuation and our target comes to close to 400-420 based on 6 times EV-EBITDA.


ICICI Bank has corporate governance issues. The board has directed an investigation. Would that be an overbearing worry for ICICI Bank?
If that was not the overbearing factor, then the stock would have already reacted on the positive. They seem to have cleaned the restructured assets and everything has been booked as NPA. But because that overbearing factor is there and everyone is expecting the worst will come because of the inquiry. There will be a lot of corporate governance issues but a bank like ICICI Bank is not a one person-driven bank. It is an institution. 

As uncertainty over the probe continues, that is getting priced into the stock movement. That is why you see a huge difference between the other private sector banks valuation and ICICI Bank valuation. But on pure operating fundamentals, if you see growth coming back and as most of the NPA mess have been cleaned and NPA resolution has started with Bhushan Steel, all that incremental will only improve the fundamentals of the bank. Based on pure fundamentals, over the next one to two years, I am positive on the valuation front as far as the bank is concerned.

NEW DELHI: Stock market investors shrugged off first repo rate hike in over four years on Wednesday and instead cheered the ‘neutral’ stance of the Reserve bank of India, as equities jumped nearly a per cent to snap three-session losing streak.

The rally in rate sensitive stocks on the day validated that the market had already priced in the rate hike.

The six-member monetary policy committee of RBI unanimously hiked the repo rate - the short-term lending rate - by 25 basis points to 6.25 per cent -- but kept its policy stance as 'neutral' on Wednesday.

"Rate hike is pre-emptive and in line with the Reserve Bank of India's neutral-to-hawkish policy tone. The RBI has sounded more sanguine over growth prospects going forward, while flagging upside risks to inflation, particularly emanating from higher crude oil prices and the wage-price setting process due to the closure of output gap," said Sumedh Deorukhkar, Senior Economist, BBVA.

The 30-share Sensex jumped 276 points, or 0.79 per cent, to end the day at 35,179, with 27 stocks with gains.

The Nifty50 index added 92 points, or 0.86 per cent, to settle at 10,685, with 39 stocks in the green, 10 in the red and 1 remaining unchanged.

Broader BSE Midcap and smallcap indices acquired mire gains than benchmark Sensex, rising 1.28 per cent and 1.53 per cent, respectively.

Bharti Airtel, Tata Motors and Sun Pharma led the pack of Sensex gainers, rising up to 4.55 per cent.

Tata Motors on Tuesday said it is working on close to a dozen electric and hybrid vehicle solutions in the commercial vehicle space and is simultaneously moving towards a dedicated electric vehicle platform in the passenger vehicle front.

On the contrary, ONGC, Asian Paints and HDFC Bank stood among the top losers in the Sensex kitty of stocks, falling up to 0.47 per cent.

All sectors on BSE went home with gains, with telecom as the top gainer, surging over 3 per cent.

"With one-year T-bill at 7 per cent, the debt market has not only priced in this rate hike but also a couple of more rate hikes to come," said Nilesh Shah, MD, Kotak AMC to ET Now.

Global stocks also saw a rally on Wednesday as the worries of a trade war faded.
