A fair value of Indian markets is still 10-15% away, but there is value in IT, pharma and export-oriented auto stocks, 
Saurabh Mukherjea, Founder, Marcellus Investment Managers, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts: 

Do you really think that US equities are seeing a big trend reversal or is it just sentimental knee-jerk reactions? 
I really do not know that much about US equities. My reckoning is fair value for the Indian market. It is at least 10%, perhaps 15% away. I have been saying this for the last one year or so that the market is significantly overvalued. Yes, we have corrected meaningfully but I still think that the Nifty and the Sensex is overvalued. 

The biggest pocket of overvaluation in the Indian market was in financial services stocks. Their valuations made no sense at all a month or so ago. I still think there is a further derating to come in wholesale funded lenders in particular but there is still value in IT. There is lots of value in pharma and export oriented auto stocks are still worth buying. There are pockets of value in the Indian market but the overall market and especially wholesale funded lenders are very significantly overvalued.


At what point would you say India holds value?
I do not think anybody can invest by looking at the market day to day. That is just for getting stomach ulcers rather than getting rich. It is exactly for this reason that legends like Robert Kirby created the Coffee Can Portfolio where you buy your bunch of high quality stocks such as HDFC Bank, Asian Paints, Marico and you hold them through. There is no way on earth where you can buy stocks and react to events like last week or a day like today. You will never make any money. You just give yourself heartburn, blood pressure and stomach ulcers.


How do you get the conviction to buy at any price point? 
One of the key parts of our jobs -- whether you are on buy side, sell side, in the media or an investor, is to decipher the signal, the underlying structural trend from the noise. The signal in our country is that the Indian investor has given up the ghost of making money from real estate and land and so on and has decided that financial assets is the way forward. 

There might be a temporary lull in that because of what we are seeing in the stock market and the bond market at the moment but the structural trend towards financial assets is not going to go away in India. 

Secondly, our stock market is fortunate and the economy is fortunate that there have been a dozen and a half companies in the Indian market who over the last decade have shown that they can systematically allocate capital and generate solid results. The names that I mentioned, Asian Paints, HDFC Bank, Marico are three of examples but I will say there are dozen-and-a-half strong portfolio of great companies which consistently allocate capital in good times and bad times. So you focus on the underlying signal, the signal is real estates’ days are behinds us. 

Whatever is left of residential real estate as an asset class will be turned into rabble over next six months as our housing finance companies face funding challenges and hence the shift towards financial assets is here to stay. 

Secondly, we do have high class companies in the Indian stock market with high class management teams, great capital allocation and the focus has to be on investing in them. It could be TCS in the IT sector. It could be Marico in FMCG. It could be HDFC in the banking sector but you have to focus on quality rather than trying to time market and figuring out what will happen with the Fed and in America and with our own policies.


TCS is slated to come out with its numbers today. How much of the good news is already priced in? 
In October-November last year, exactly a year ago, I started banging the drum on IT. My reckoning is the sort of currency tailwind that the IT sector has, will lead to business wins. It is impossible to believe that given the sort of currency tailwinds the Indian IT sector has got, they will not see sharply higher business wins in the coming quarters. 

Secondly, unless a miracle saves India, the rupee is likely to fall further. If you had to look at one sector in the Indian economy where there is a complete competitive reset, it is Indian IT. 

Within Indian IT, focus on the scale gorilla, focus on a company with 30% ROCE almost a 100% dividend payout ratio. In times like this, let us not try to second guess its PE multiple and say whether it is fully valued or not. There is enormous competitive tailwinds to Indian IT sector and it will be sort of a second guessing of a very high order to say TCS is fully valued at this juncture. 


Is midcap IT likely to match up with the performance of some of the frontline names considering secord quarter is traditionally a strong quarter for IT?
You are right. This is in a way the analogue of midcap stocks in the broader economy where they do not have any tailwinds anymore. Midcap stocks in the broader economy, excluding IT and pharma, have negative tailwinds as their margins get crunched and as they lose top line growth as well. Midcap IT is likely to do well. If I had to choose one player in the middle segment of IT, I would go for L&T Infotech. All these guys will get currency tailwinds but L&T Infotech is a well managed firm and I think there is good reason to believe beyond producing good results L&T Infotech will use this currency tailwind to strengthen its competitive position over the next three, four quarters.


The RBI paused on rates this time around and that kind of unnerved the markets as well. They are going to do calibrated tightening but they are also concerned about inflation.
Let us break it into two parts; our authorities both in Delhi and in Mumbai deserve a lot of credit. There is a lot of work going on behind the scenes to ensure that the Indian economy and the financial market get a soft landing. After all, once interest rates start rising and the economic cycle starts decelerating, there will be trouble for wholesale funded lenders. 

Our authorities deserve a lot of credit for working very hard behind the scenes to ensure a soft landing for the financial system. That being said, I am still not sure that investors how they have recognised just how big a reset the NBFC valuations deserve to become aligned to reality. 

Almost every wholesale funded lender in India can give up the ghost of growing its balance sheet over the next 12 months. It is not going to be possible. At best, well run wholesale funded lenders can keep their loan book at broadly the same level as it is today but they will become an ex-growth sector and I do not think valuations reflect that as yet. 

The incredible runup in the stock prices yesterday suggests that investor in wholesale funded lenders are still on cool aid and have not come to recognise the fundamental reset that valuations for this sector deserves. Our authorities are doing their job, it is the investors that need to come to their senses with regards to this very large sector of in the Indian stock market.


The consumption theme always finds favour in the market despite high valuations as we step into an extended festive season. Is Zee Entertainment’s numbers telling you that the consumption story is far from done?
I agree with you. Wherever consumption is not funded through credit, by taking loans from banks and NBFCs, we will be in a pretty good shape. Whether it is FMCG or electricals, that element will hold up quite nicely. Where the challenge will kick in obviously is the consumption sector where the spend is heavily financed by borrowings from banks and NBFCs. So, car and truck OEMs look vulnerable from a top line growth perspective. But electricals, the broader aspirational consumption play FMCG, are still in a decent shape and will hold up nicely through the festive season.

In an interaction with ET NOW, Sanjiv Bhasin, IIFL, talks about the stocks and sectors that look poised to bounce back; offers his view on IT, pharma and FMCG and reveals where he is putting his money at going into 2019. Edited excerpts:


ET Now: Do you think that the worst of the fall is behind us or do you sense a further weakness dependent on how much the US equities fall?

Sanjiv Bhasin: The markets were underperforming of late more due to local issues like the IL&FS fiasco, oil rally and rupee weakness. The much needed Dow correction is now telling you that there is a lot of uncertainty and the oil bulls is where you are seeing a lot of weakness. For the Indian markets, it only means good news as the dollar is weakening. Now the emerging markets, particularly India, should see a lot of constructive buying and we are positive on this fall and have rather used this fall to buy. 

Another 500-600 points on the upside are definitely on the cards and if I can stick my neck out I would say Nifty could climb to even 10,800 to 11,000 by Diwali.


ET Now: Focussing on IT sector at large, how much of the optimism, do you think is already baked in into the prices? Should good number in earnings be used as opportunities to profit take?

Sanjiv Bhasin: Over the last two-three weeks we have been saying that use all rallies in IT to exit. TCS has come out with the excellent numbers but they also indicated that this weakness in rupee just aided margins of about 1% or so in this quarter where the rupee has fallen around 12 per cent. It tells us that it is a myth that weak rupee is going to give IT companies large income on the treasury side. 

I think most of the IT companies are well hedged and are fully priced. If we want to play the weak rupee, we would rather play it through pharma. But there are a plethora of stocks and sectors which are beaten down fairly. To name a few, we have are positive on - Maruti, Bajaj Finance, Eicher Motor, UltraTech - the real hardcore India where we think the pessimism was overdone. 

IT will rightly take a back seat, all rallies will be used to sell and if rupee strengthens more then the local cyclical should do relatively well for the remainder of this month and next.


ET Now: How are you reading into Hindustan Unilever’s performance and what indication does it give to you for FMCGs at large?

Sanjiv Bhasin: The numbers were highly impressive given they have been able to maintain margins at 21 per cent and overcome the double whammies of rising interest rates and oil. They have hedged themselves perfectly. These numbers tell you that the consumption part, particularly the one on personal care, is doing extremely strong. HUL has indicated strong numbers on the cream side and on the hair shampoo side and it will only start to get a bigger fillip given they have a better period coming ahead after the shraad. HUL’s numbers tell you that the correction in some of the FMCG stocks may have been overdone and this is a good time to buy some of these names. 


ET Now: What do you think should either be bought or avoided in near-term?

Sanjiv Bhasin: I would advise staying away from IT. You may see a decline in some IT stocks post the Q2 results as the best of IT has played out. Focus on sectors and stocks where pessimism has given an opportunity to buy and be with some of the bellwether stocks. Some of the names like I said earlier are - Reliance, UltraTech, Asian Paints, Bajaj Finance, Maruti and Eicher. Some of these names are showing a lot of strength. They have been resilient in this fall but the other pedigree names on the consumption side are likely to bounce back very fast after this one-quarter hiatus. We are underweight on IT and overweight on pharma as a rupee proxy but cyclicals is where we are putting our money going into 2019.

Elections, high crude oil prices, weak rupee and tradewar concerns make the outlook for the stock market hazy. But the likely weakness in the market may make share valuations cheaper over the next few months. Analysts say the best strategy for retail investors will be to spread out their investments over the next few months to reduce the risk of committing money at higher prices when the sentiment is wobbly. While the most popular way of doing it is systematic investment plans, or SIPs, through mutual funds, those who want to hold shares in their demat accounts could do these staggered investments through stock brokers. “While doing this there is no burden of making lump sum investments at one time. This works in both bull and bear markets, as the average cost of holdings improves if one sticks to the strategy,” said Deepak Jasani, head of research at HDFC Securities. ET spoke to four brokerages for their stock picks to build a portfolio through SIPs and the strategy investors need to follow.


HDFC SECURITIESDeepak Jasani of HDFC Securities advises a stock SIP portfolio of better-known medium-risk stocks and lesser-known high-risk stocks. Jasani advises investors to opt for a better-known stocks SIP if they have a lower risk appetite and opt for a lesser-known stocks SIP if their risk appetite is higher. He advises keeping ratio equal in terms of value of stocks in both the stock SIP options. Jasani said one should be invested in these stocks for a period that coincides with trend cycle of stocks, which is 15-18 months, but added that one should review the portfolio every six months. Investors can choose as many stocks from the list as they wish or add the stocks out of the list that they have tracked and want to accumulate over time, he said. Ideally one should do SIPs in 4-6 stocks. At the end of the 15-18 months, they may extend the SIP period or stop the SIP and wait for an opportune time to sell the stocks if they are in good profit, he said.



GEOJIT SECURITIESIn the current market environment, it would be wise to start with a stock SIP with a mix of high-quality sectors and stock ideas available at cheaper valuations compared to the averages of the past three years, said Geojit. Given the risk-taking ability, 15-30 per cent can be spread on opportunities in auto, pharma and NBFCs, with a view that equity market will stabilise over the next two quarters. Vinod Nair, head of research at Geojit Securities, recommends a portfolio for defensive as well as aggressive investors. He advises equal ratio of investment in UPL, Titan, IndusInd Bank, HCL Technologies and Asian Paints in defensive-stock SIPs. For aggressive investors, Nair recommends allocating 20 per cent in Tata Motors, 15 per cent each in Can Fin Homes and Capital First and 25 per cent each in Inter-Globe Aviation and Ashok Leyland. One can go on to hold these SIPs for 2-3 years.


IDBI CAPITALThe brokerage advises doing an SIP investment spread over the next 12 months given that the market is still showing a bearish inclination. The elections are coming in the next 6-8 months, while depreciating rupee, rising crude oil prices and global trade war tensions are posing other concerns, said IDBI Capital. “The SIP can be done as a basket investment with 14 to 20 stocks with a periodicity of a month or fortnight,” said IDBI Capital. The brokerage’s list of beaten-down and deep-value stocks includes Aditya Birla Capital, Ashok Leyland, BSE, Bharat Electronics, NBCC, Sun TV, YES Bank and Federal Bank.




IIFL
IIFL is focusing on stocks more from the large cap space, which are not likely to get impacted by liquidity crisis and which will continue to see strong growth going forward. “Our focus is on quality companies which have been beaten down. We are focusing on stocks more from the large-cap space, rather than telling people to bottomfish in midcaps,” said Abhimanyu Sofat, head of research at IIFL. The investing ratio in each stock should be 25 per cent. He advises an SIP portfolio of Bajaj Finance, RIL, IndusInd Bank and Bajaj Finance.

Going by the buzz on Dalal Street, here is a list of five factors that are dragging the market.


Fed worries: Subdued global cues

Double whammy of trade deficit & rupee fall

Among others Infosys (down 3 per cent) and YES Bank (7 per cent) also lost significant weight. HDFC, ITC and Asian Paints capped some of the downside. However, its gross refining margin, or profit earned on each barrel of crude processed, fell to a three-and-a-half-year low at $9.50 a barrel.


Domestic growth worries
Sentiments were dampened after CLSA signalled an impact on economic growth due to current tightness in the credit market, though the impact is unlikely to remain way beyond the next two quarters, notwithstanding the cautious view on the domestic equity market.

The quarterly earnings season has begun in full swing. However, price behaviour of certain companies seems illogical. The trend of analyst expectations and comparison of results with such expectations post the actual announcement has fooled the majority.

It is presumed that analyst expectations are godsend and if those expectations are meet, then it means a company has performed well during the quarter. But the reality of Mr Market is totally different.

For example, Reliance Industries’ Q2FY19 numbers were as per analyst expectations and the company delivered a bottomline growth of 17.4 per cent YoY and topline growth of 54.5 per cent YoY on a consolidated basis. Post the result, majority of the brokerages also raised price targets for the conglomerate by 20-30 per cent. Nonetheless, the stock substantially cracked 5 per cent, immediately after the results announcement denuding analyst estimates.

TCS reported a consolidated Q2FY19 net profit of Rs 7,901 crore, up 7.6 per cent QoQ, along with a healthy Ebitda growth of 13.3% compared with that in the previous quarter. The numbers were in line, in analyst terminology. Yet, the stock fell some 12 per cent in the ensuing period. Mindtree is another such example, which fell despite a 30 per cent QoQ profit growth.

From these facts we can infer that investors should read the results without any bias by comparing the QoQ and YoY numbers. In addition, if valuations itself are very high from a historical perspective, then no matter what, the prices will fall irrespective of good numbers. There is no point giving too much attention to analyst estimates or poll numbers.


Event of the Week
Nifty faced a tumultuous week even as a number of companies announced their earnings. Banking and housing finance companies such as DCB Bank reported a 25 per cent rise in PAT, whereas Federal Bank clocked 3.15 per cent lower NIMs than 3.31 per cent report for the year-ago period. But profits were slightly better.

Indiabulls Housing Finance on the other hand reported a 21 per cent YoY increase in PAT; Crisil posted 29% YoY PAT growth and NIIT a whopping 59 per cent YoY PAT increase. Technology companies have posted strong growth this quarter mainly due to rupee depreciation, but in spite of all these, stocks have corrected and will continue to correct as valuations are still high in the IT sector.


Technical OutlookThe Nifty 50 has turned very volatile with gaps visible on the daily charts. Previous week’s hammer formation and this week’s shooting star formation indicate confusion in the market. It looks like bullish and bearish tendencies are balancing out. The market is, therefore, expected to enter the consolidation phase till expiry. Downside is capped in the 10,000- 10,100 zone on the Nifty50 and on the upside, there is resistance at 10,900.

Traders are advised not to take positions till volatility reduces to normal levels, else stop losses will have to be wider and chances of whipsaw losses are very high.

Others

Expectations for the Week
The current phase of range-bound movement in the market is expected to continue in the following week. With the froth in some stocks beginning to be washed away, going forward we believe no new low prices will be reached, at least in the short term till expiry. However, volatility will remain high due to the macro uncertainty and rising fear of trade wars and oil price impact globally.

With the earnings season gaining momentum, it would be important to keep an eye on Asian Paints, Can Fin Homes, Bajaj Finance, Ambuja Cements, Bajaj Auto, Indigo, Kotak Bank, Bharti Airtel, Maruti, Piramal Enterprise, YES Bank, Dr Reddy’s and a few others for directional clues for the market.

The short-term mood will be mainly guided by corporate results. Therefore, investors are advised to be very selective in purchases and avoid any leverage at this juncture.

NEW DELHI: The week gone by induced further pessimism in the market, as the benchmark indices saw deep cuts amid concerns over financial health and liquidity crisis in the NBFC sector, rising oil prices and a fast weakening rupee.

The BSE Sensex dropped 417.95 points, or 1.20 per cent, for the week to settle at 34,315 on Friday, while the Nifty50 tanked 168.95 points, or 1.61 per cent, to end at 10,303. Friday’s selloff wiped off Rs 1.60 lakh crore of equity investors’ wealth.

Even some solid earnings numbers from blue chip firms like Reliance Industries and Infosys failed to lift the mood. Sustained capital outflow has created a gloomy atmosphere, dealing a body blow to risk-appetite. Every rise in market is meeting with a wave of profit-booking. Overseas investors have pulled out roughly over Rs 20,000 crore from the domestic markets so far in October.

Going into a new week, things do not look any better. Going by analyst observations, here is a list of factors that will influence market movement next week.


Liquidity and NBFC issuesA perceived liquidity crisis in the non-banking financial companies (NBFCs) has made investors wary despite a slew of measures from the government and RBI to address the issue. After the IL&FS crisis, even the slightest indication of problem in an NBFC has led to a selloff. “RBI is trying to inject liquidity, but confidence needs to be restored in the system to ensure that it continues to function,” Sudip Bandyopadhyay, group chairman, Inditrade Capital, said in an interview with ET Now. “If the liquidity crunch is allowed to continue unabated, it may lead to solvency issues and that will be disastrous. We will have to see how that gets handled over the next 10-15 days,” he said. The efficacy of RBI’s decision to relax liquidity norms and allow more bank lending to NBFCs will be assessed in the coming days. 


F&O rolloverOctober series futures and options will expire on Thursday and rollover of positions will dominate proceedings through the week. “Friday's data showed maximum Put open interest was at 10,000 followed by 10,200, while maximum Call OI was at 11,000 followed by 10,600,” said Chandan Taparia of Motilal Oswal Securities. “There was meaningful Call writing at 10,400 followed by 10,600, while Put writing was seen at 10,200 followed by 10,100. The option band signified a trading band between 10,200 and 10,500 levels. On Friday, Nifty futures closed in the negative at 10,314 with a loss of 1.24 per cent,” he said. F&O rollovers may increase volatility in the market.


Rupee remains a big worryThe rupee settled 29 paise higher at 73.32 against the dollar on Friday, amid selling of the US currency by exporters and foreign fund inflows. The domestic unit has been on a bumpy track of late owing to unstable crude oil prices, a stronger dollar, capital outflow and rising bond yields in the US. The rupee will remain a key factor to watch in the coming days. 


The course of crude oilCrude oil prices rose in international markets on Friday. Brent crude futures rose 49 cents to settle at $79.78 a barrel amid a surge in demand in China. The market is now focussing on US sanctions on Iran, which will come into force on November 4. Crude has a direct impact on the rupee’s health and ultimately it influences the mood of the market, as higher crude oil prices raises worries of a spike in current account deficit and fiscal deficit, distorting country’s macroeconomic mathematics. As per RBI estimates, every $10 a barrel rise in oil price reduces country’s GDP growth by around 0.15 per cent. 


Key Q2 earnings aheadThe earnings season is on in full swing now. ITC, Asian Paints, Adani Ports, Ambuja Cements, Kotak Mahindra Bank, YES Bank, Maruti Suzuki, Bharti Airtel, Bharti Infratel, Wipro, HCL Tech, Bajaj Auto, Bajaj Finance and Bajaj Finserv are among the heavyweights that will release their September quarter numbers during the week. The earnings numbers have been mixed so far. Any positive surprise should prove a booster dose for the market. 


ECB’s rate decisionThe European Central Bank (ECB) will announce its interest rate decision on Thursday amid chaos around Brexit. While no change in monetary policy is expected as of now, the ECB will have to calculate the risk that Brexit poses to eurozone economy. “Brexit is the big elephant in the room for the euro area’s economy. A lot of people are trying to guess the nitty-gritty of interest rate increases that are still about a year out, but are ignoring one of the region’s key economic risks,” Karsten Junius, chief economist at Bank J Safra Sarasin in Zurich, told Bloomberg. 


Global macro-meterThe Bank of Japan’s core CPI will be out on Tuesday. The US new home sales report for September will be out on Wednesday. Besides, markets will closely watch third quarter GDP growth numbers of the US on Friday. On the same day, data on US’s real consumer spending will also be released. Italian budget will also be in focus this week. 


Technical outlook weakOn the technical charts, the bears appear on the driver's seat. “As per the weekly timeframe chart, Nifty has formed a negative candle with a long upper shadow, which indicates a sharp negative reversal from the recent highs. The weekly RSI is also sending out negative signals,” said Nagaraj Shetti, Technical Research Analyst at HDFC Securities. Technical indicators still show more scope of downside, though in between a short bounce cannot be ruled out. The support for Sensex/Nifty during the week is seen at 33,350/10,000 and resistance at 35,100/10,550. Bank Nifty would have a range of 24,150-25,860, said Vaishali Parekh, senior technical analyst at Prabhudas Lilladher.

AHMEDABAD: Ebix, Inc, a Nasdaq listed international supplier of On-Demand software and E-commerce services to the insurance, financial, healthcare and e-learning industries, acquired 67% stake in Routier, a Delhi-based B2B marketplace for trucking logistics. Routier is the first start-up where Ebix has made a strategic investment. 

The deal has been done by one of its India-based EbixCash a subsidiaries. Routier is a cloud based technology to change the way people move and receive inland goods in India.

Founded by first generation entrepreneurs and operating team senior executives Ankur Dahiya and Adwait Vikram Singh from the Indian Institute of Management (IIM) and Harvard Law School, respectively; Routier seeks to revolutionize trucking logistics in the same way taxi logistics have been transformed by Uber, Ola and others. Routier aims to drive efficiency for all marketplace stakeholders, using an innovative blend of data analytics, artificial intelligence and end-to-end streamlined functionality available over the cloud.

Routier Co-Founder Adwait Vikram Singh said, “Routier has the potential to rationalize the logistics sector not only in India but also for the global markets. Currently, Routier operates only in inland logistics but eventually aims to become a key player in streamlining cross border freight movement on a single enterprise marketplace platform. Routier has the vision to become an end-to-end supply chain network, that can handle freight movement to last mile delivery, for transportation across country borders.'

With clients like Coca Cola, Asian Paints, and Samsung. Routier’s marketplace is already proving its ability to add efficiency to freight movement. The EbixCash investment was driven by Routier’s desire for a strategic investor who could provide added technology expertise, financial strength and brand recognition to accelerate its penetration of major trucking logistics. Routier is the first start-up where Ebix has made a strategic investment, points out a company’s statement. 

“Exchanges and marketplaces are meant to provide a network effect that drives efficiency for all concerned and are best targeted at industries that are highly inefficient and lack technology savvy. India’s trucking industry is a perfect example of such an opportunity to deliver tremendous value and efficiency, and thus we are quite excited to be partnering with Routier in its mission to redefine the trucking logistics industry” said Robin Raina, Chairman, President and CEO, Ebix. 

Robin further added, “Routier recently secured multi-million dollar commitments from a few large multinational corporations, and thus needed the backing of Ebix in terms of technology expertise, manpower and working capital to implement and scale these and other opportunities. We are excited to invest in this pioneering effort at an opportune time, and look forward to building what could be a large marketplace for the trucking industry.”

With a market opportunity expected to reach $300 billion by 2020, Routier looks to drive productivity and transparency through a transportation sector long considered one of the most inefficient, claims the company’s statement.

Early in the new year, we will get an opportunity to buy super real estate developers at super cheap prices, 
Saurabh Mukherjea, Founder, Marcellus Investment Managers, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts: 

How worried are you about the global market rout this morning and would you say that there is a slight chance that we may fall less because we have already fallen so much?
Could well that we correct less than the brutal correction in the S&P 500 yesterday but overall, if you look ahead over the next 12 months, whether you look at the American or the Indian market, we are facing a similar set of circumstances of rising interest rates, rising cost of capital, a slowing economy and hence just as corporate profit seem to be topping out in America, in India also it is reasonably clear that in the second half of the year, earnings growth will conk off again as the broader economic slowdown around the NBFC funding freeze kicks in. 

So, there are a similar set of circumstances in the big markets around the world, rising cost of capital, slowing economies, expensive stocks and corporate earnings suggesting that they have topped out. 


What should investors do? Should one just sit tight and fasten the seatbelts because better days are coming or is this the time to take a serious cash call and protect your capital?
There are two sets of action that one should rationally take. The first is there are three large sectors in the Indian market which have reasonably low correlation with our macro economy, with our broader economic construct. These are; a) FMCG which has low correlation and is almost like an economy onto itself. b)The IT sector which is linked to the rupee more than the Indian economy and c)the pharma sector which is similarly linked to the rupee and the Indian economy. 

People like me have been cheerleading for 12 months. I think there is still juice in IT. Results are healthy, the weakness in the rupee is so profound that it will continue to give tailwinds and firms like TCS or an L&T Infotech give you perfectly sensible ways to make money there. 

In pharma, there are significant bargains to be had both in the front line pharma stocks and perhaps in the mid tier as well. 

FMCG results would be sound. It will be an island of safety. So, that is one way to deal with slowdown, one way to deal with the economic circumstances. The other is to pull back from wholesale funded financials. 

I know I have been saying this like a broken record for 12 months but there is still very little rhyme or reason for the price to book multiples that many of the NBFCs and HFCs trade at. Dewan is the only one which has pulled back to some sort of sanity in valuations. There is still sort of fantasy type valuations that most of housing finance companies and NBFCs trade at and if you have those in your portfolios, you really have to rethink your exposure to wholesale funded financials. 

The well-run CASA funded banks will have a good three-four year run in India It is not just an HDFC Bank or Kotak which has good CASA franchises. I would look at even smaller banks like DCB or City Union Bank carefully as valuations come off in the market.


TCS and Bajaj Finance numbers were great. At the top, bluest of the blue chip largecap stocks numbers’ have not been great but the minute I start coming down the ladder, numbers start getting weaker -- be it IT, banks or consumers. Are markets telling you something here?
Yes, markets are giving the message I suppose. The last five years gave us the hope that this will be the year when Indian earnings grow at double digits. But that is likely to be belied again. You are seeing softness in earnings now and remember that in the first two quarters of the ,year the NBFC slowdown had not yet hit. 

If the first two quarters earnings are turning out to be softer than many of us expected them to be, then almost certainly we are going to have the disappointments in Q3 and Q4 as higher raw material costs and a jump in funding costs hit economy sectors like auto, consumption in Q3, Q4. Earnings expectations will get pulled back partly because of what we are seeing in Q2 earnings and partly because people will do a little bit of forward looking thinking and say that consumption will slow down there.


Do you keep the powder dry and wait for the froth to settle down or do you start hunting for bargains in the current market?
For many of us, market timing remains a real challenge . Given that construct, I outlined one framework on your show two months ago. Say I am creating a 20-stock portfolio. In that 20-stocks, 10 of them are Robert Kirby’s coffee can type stocks where I buy high quality franchises and sit on them for extended periods of time. An example being Asian Paints. I know Asian Paints pulled back by 20% this year but it has had an incredible 25 years. It is a super company and nobody can second guess when one should buy and sell Asian Paints. So franchise like in Asian Paints or HDFC Bank is in my 10 structural holdings.

Then I have the other half of my portfolio, 10 other holdings where I try to play the economic cycle by toggling my micro outlook. Year ago, I started believing that IT was oversold. So in that other 10 of my portfolio, I had three or four IT stocks. I still believe IT is undervalued but I also believe pharma is undervalued. Pharma is in my cyclical side of the portfolio. Break your portfolio into two parts, 10 structural holdings which you buy, sit back and forget, letting them compound; and 10 holdings where you toggle with the cycle by moving into cash, out of cash, back into cash. Those sorts of calls are very hard for most of us to make and I tried avoiding timing the market in its totality. 


Is it time to really start diversifying? What is the prudent strategy for a sensible investor who wants to use the power of market dynamics and cycles and enjoy the benefits of asset allocations?
If you want to use the power of asset allocation, one sensible strategy to consider is building a broader portfolio beyond India. What has happened in our country because of the real estate pullback over the last four-five years has been that money has been furiously pumped into the stock market. This created by and large a structurally expensive market. Smart HNWs are using the $25,000 that they are allowed to take abroad to purchase good companies in Singapore, Australia and United States. Indians building worldwide equity portfolios is something that will happen over the next four-five years as people try to diversify their wealth beyond just the Indian stock market.


How would you look at the pockets which are not being fancied by the market -- aviation and metals? They are much cheaper than some of the beaten down names in the quality space?
Let us throw real estate into that pack as well because there is a bunch of industrial sectors where there has not been a lot of fresh capacity addition in the last three four years as we have gone through the capex slowdown. And as capacity utilisation is hitting 75-80%, some of these sectors are beginning to look very interesting. 

In metals, Arcelor Mittal’s entry is quite a big deal. It is something we should cheer as a country that Arcelor Mittal has finally found a bit of grip on the Indian market. Hopefully, it steps up competitive intensity in the steel market and gives us as consumers steel at better prices. I would not jump into the ferrous companies just yet. I will wait for Arcelor Mittal’s entry to fructify into more competitive intensity.

One space which is looking very interesting is residential real estate. There is a good chance that in the next three-four months, we see the final lurch downwards in residential housing as funding dries up for real estate developers. They were supported heavily by the NBFCs and the housing finance companies. As the real estate developers lose their final lifelines of funding, we can see another 20-30% correction in residential real estate house prices.

Early next year, residential real estate could be a sector where buying stocks might finally make sense. This is a sector worth looking at very carefully. RERA will lead to massive consolidation in residential real estate. We will probably end up with no more than 10 to 12 large pan India builders who dominate the landscape. Several of them are listed and following them closely over the next three four months as the funding freeze intensifies will be a very worthwhile exercise. This is a mega sector and large companies will be created in the next 10 years. Several of them are listed. We might get a really tasty opportunity early in the New Year to buy super developers at super cheap prices.


It is still a little early and still got two to three weeks to gauge, but what has been your reading so far of the earnings season?
The opening week was alright but over the last week, it is reasonably clear that raw material price intensification has led to meaningful margin erosion. Even a champion franchise like Asian Paints has seen meaningful margin erosion. As the quarter wears on, we will see results getting progressively weaker. 

Q1 was broadly in line with expectation, Q2 looks to be a tad softer than people expected it to be and in Q3, Q4, results will start softening as economic growth starts feeling the pressure of the funding freeze. IT results will be altight, banks barring IndusInd will be still alright but wherever raw material prices are kicking in, you are seeing operating margin pressure kick in which in turn suggests pricing power is very weak. This in turn suggests that the economy as it is in Q2 was not super strong. . So the 15-20% earnings growth that consensus had pencilled in for the current year for FY19, once again looks likely to be pulled back to 8-9-10%.

NEW DELHI: Severe selling pressure threw investors off-balance today as domestic stocks suffered more losses.

The benchmark Sensex plunged 481 points to 33,553 and the Nifty broke below 10,100 as most sectors felt the heat on the last day of October futures and options contracts.

Weak leads from Asian markets following a sell-off in US stocks did not help matters. Rupee's slide despite softening crude oil prices hit sentiment hard. 

Weak prospects of economic growth and worries about corporate earnings were other major overhangs. Uninspiring earnings have done little to lift market mood, which is grappling with the NBFC mess and the liquidity crisis.

The NSE Nifty was 125 points down at 10,100 around 11:10 am while the BSE Sensex plunged 410 points to 33,624. Barring, Wipro, Asian Paints, TCS and ONGC, all scrips of the Sensex were in the red. 

Wondering what all caused the market downfall today? Here are the factors in detail.


Lacklustre earnings: September quarter earnings have failed to meet market expectations, dealing a blow to investor sentiment. So far, 209 companies have declared their second quarter results and cumulatively, they have reported a fall of 4.86 per cent in profit to Rs 45,943 crore. The profit numbers for the same quarter a year ago stood at Rs 48,288 crore. 


F&O rollovers: F&O rollovers have also injected a sense of caution. On the options front on Wednesday, maximum Put OI was at 10,000 followed by 10,200 strike while Call OI congestion was seen at 10,300 followed by 10,400 strikes. Call writing was at 10,300 followed by 10,250 strike while Put writing was seen at 10,000 followed by 10,200 strike. Option band signified an immediate trading range between 10,138 and 10,333 levels. Volatility index India VIX stood at 4.39 per cent. 


Weak Asian peers: Asian stocks took a beating on Thursday after a strong sell-off in the US technology stocks made Wall Street see its worst fall since 2011. Wall Street erased the entire gains of the year and a volley of factors, including rate hikes, trade war worries, higher equity valuation and concerns on corporate earnings played their role. 


Geopolitical uncertainty: Geopolitical concerns too spoiled market mood. While the worries of trade war still pinch, the conflict between the US and Saudi Arabia has brought fresh troubles for investors. The impending US sanction on Iran is another issue the world is tracking. All these factors have a say in equities and the oil market across the globe. Oil prices have been on a wobbly pitch of late, putting pressure on emerging market economies. 


Rupee's prolonged weakness: The rupee fell again on Thursday even as oil prices eased in global markets. The rupee dropped by 19 paise to 73.35 against the dollar early Thursday amid unabated foreign fund outflows. Traders said increased demand for the US currency from importers and a lower opening of domestic equity market weighed on the local unit. Despite steps taken by the government and the RBI, the rupee's slide remains unabated, posing a threat to India's macroeconomic mathematics.


Technical outlook weak: Although the Nifty reversed its four-day losing streak to form a ‘Hammer’ candle on the daily chart, the index remains vulnerable to selling pressure on every rise. “The index is witnessing a tug of war between the bulls and the bears near the 10,200 level. It needs to hold above 10,200, with a follow-up buying interest to head towards 10,280 and eventually 10,333-10,350 range,” said Chandan Taparia of Motilal Oswal Securities.


Sustained FII outflow: Uninterrupted FII capital outflow in the wake of a falling rupee and rising bond yields in the US gave the bears more fodder. In October so far, FIIs have pulled out over Rs 35,000 crore from Indian equity and debt market. On Wednesday alone, the FII outflow figure stood at Rs 2,046.54 crore, as per provisional data available with the NSE.

Out of the 51 companies on the BSE-500 index which have come out with their second quarter results so far, profits of 28 have missed analysts’ expectations, heightening worries about further delay in the muchawaited earnings recovery and sharp cuts in forecasts.

Several blue-chips, too, have disappointed investors. Analysts said increase in input costs, lower volumes due to aggressive pricing or additional provisioning in case of some banks resulted in many of their profits falling below estimates.

With rising crude prices, weaker rupee and rising funding costs, analysts are likely to cut earnings estimates for FY19. “We expect sharp cut in earnings estimates in near term because of the poor show in the September quarter” said Gautam Chhaochharia, head of India research, UBS. “Hope of earnings recovery in the second half of FY 2019 looks bleak now with the new developments like increasing rates, rising crude and liquidity crunch.” Top companies that did not meet earnings estimates include IndusInd Bank, ACC, Bajaj Auto, Reliance Industries, Asian Paints, Ambuja, UltraTech Cement and Wipro. The tightening liquidity conditions, which is weighing down non banking finance companies, have contributed to the uncertainty.

“The fear of tight liquidity and higher interest rates is adversely impacting several domestic oriented sectors, which were the key to FY19 earnings recovery” said Gautam Duggad, head of research, Motilal Oswal Securities. “NBFCs will see downgrades after many years of strong growth”.

Analysts said further delay in earnings recovery could result in investors losing patience. Investors have been waiting for an earnings recovery for the last two years.

Market participants are now analysing the impact of the liquidity squeeze in NBFCs on the economy.

BENGALURU: Bengaluru By Design will organise the first edition of the design festival to transform the city of Bengaluru from November 23 to December 2. The festival will feature large-scale temporary installations in different parts of the city to celebrate creativity, encourage design thinking and explore the innovations in design in cities.

The festival aims to cover three key themes: Design and Public, Design and Education and Design and Business. The event will promote public participation, education, innovation, sustainability and creativity via design.

The Festival focuses on demystifying design and making it more accessible to the public through installations, exhibitions, workshops, conferences, events, screenings, pop-ups, talks and more. The 9-day design programme, will shine the spotlight on India’s design talent while also functioning as a platform for global creative dialogue, featuring a strong participation from design professionals from across the world.

Some of the installations that will take over the city include creating green spaces with a group of arches at St Marks Circle, a video installation featuring the story of colour Indigo, installation of Polish chandeliers by integrating local flowers.

"India is entering a new era when it comes to design. By 2025, there will be a requirement of a minimum of 20 lakh designers in the country. In such a climate, Bengaluru ByDesign aims to influence key decision makers in education and policy, turning India into one of the leading countries in design thinking and technology, and bring in investment to boost the economy. We envision Bengaluru ByDesign as the next destination for design, in Asia, in the near future,” Suprita Moorthy, Founder, Bengaluru ByDesign has said in a press release.

The Festival is organised in collaboration with TVS, Asian Paints, Colour Partner and WeWork.

NEW DELHI: Consumption, often touted as the biggest investment theme in the domestic market, has let investors and fund managers down this festive season.

There are clear signs of a slowdown in consumer demand, both in urban and rural India, and fewer investors are buying this theme on Dalal Street.


What went wrong?The premise for consumption as a preferred investment theme was based on hopes that rural demand would jump after MSP hikes, farm loan waivers and election-related spending in the runup to the 2019 general elections. But southwest monsoon ended up below normal this year, affecting farm output and food prices have remained sluggish, hurting farmer incomes.

Some analysts say MSP hikes are unlikely to aid demand due to poor procurement and infrastructure facilities. Among sectors , FMCG players are yet to pass on the recent hike in input costs. Their volumes might have peaked. 

Urban demand for consumer durables and automobile has slowdown down as many consumer-focused NBFCs are facing liquidity issues. Recent interest rate hikes and inflationary concerns due to rising crude oil prices have also dented outlook for consumption plays.


Data confirms slowdownNomura’s proprietary heat-map of high-frequency data is confirming early signs of a demand slowdown. The moderation is spearheaded by consumption – both rural and urban, the brokerage said.

“Traditional bellwethers of rural consumption – two-wheeler and tractor sales – have moderated to 5 per cent YoY in Q3 from 16-25 per cent in Q2. Higher fuel prices are also starting to bite urban demand – September witnessed a 3.6 per cent YoY contraction in passenger vehicle sales,” the brokerage said.


Q2 numbers & margin risksConsumer-linked firms have so far reported mixed numbers for September quarter. While Hindustan Unilever and ITC managed to meet Street expectations, Asian Paints disappointed the Street on the margin front. Risks on margins are elevated given the rising input cost dynamics, Motilal Oswal Securities said in a note.

Data showed sectors such as consumer discretionary and consumer staples have seen a cut in FY19 price multiples. Consumer staples commands the highest valuation at over 40 times despite the expected price-to-earnings multiple for 2019 contracting 15 per cent since August 28. 


Unhealthy returnsAmong the consumption-linked equity indices, BSE Auto index has lost one-fourth of its 25 per cent of market value this calendar. The BSE consumer durables index is flat, while the FMCG index has delivered 6 per cent return since last Diwali.

Among mutual fund schemes, Sundaram Rural and Consumption Fund, which managed Rs 2,400 crore assets, has seen its NAV drop 12 per cent in last one year, compared with a 4.55 per cent fall its benchmark NIFTY 500 TRI. ITC, M&M, HUL, UPL and Britannia Industries were some of its biggest holdings of the fund as of September 30.

“Rising interest rates, short term issues on the liquidity front for NBFCs and rising cost of fuel were recent issues which could’ve had a toll on near-term demand viz., in discretionary segments such as auto. Oil inflation which flows into raw material cost of companies using the downstream products, could create pressure on profitability margins in the near term. Historically, consumer companies have demonstrated the ability to pass-on material cost inflation with a lag,” Sundaram Mutual Fund said in a written reply to ETMarkets.com query.

The mutual fund noted that its rural and consumption universe has a larger skew towards mid and small-sized companies where valuations have softened and have now moved to their long-term averages. The volume improvement and earnings growth trends across consumption categories, including staples and discretionary, continue to remain healthy all along, the mutual fund noted.

Among others, Reliance Consumption Fund, Quant Consumption Fund, UTI India Lifestyle and Canara Robeco Consumer Trends, too, have offered negative returns and failed to beat their benchmarks.

Mail sent to Canara Robeco Mutual Fund did not elicit any response.

“While we are not worried about a sharp slowdown in consumption demand, tapering is likely. Rural demand may remain stable to weak. State election spending and MSP implementation won’t be effective in raising demand. Urban and semi-urban demand may be dented due to limited NBFC lending,” said Phillip Capital.

This brokerage is factoring in weaker volume growth for automobiles (two-wheeler and commercial vehicles), consumer durables and FMCG firms in the second half of the financial year.

Consumer durables volume growth is expected to remain modest for at least a year. Auto volume growth is now seen at 8-9 per cent in H2FY19 against 13-14 per cent last year. FMCG volumes are already at peak, Phillip Capital said. 


No Diwali booster this time?There are lights and discounts everywhere, but showrooms are empty, making analysts wonder whether e-commerce onslaught or lack of demand is hurting retail sales this Diwali.

“It is no fun for retailers and businesses this Diwali. The festive demand has been underwhelming. There are the usual lights and offers splashed across windows, but (without exception) crowds are sparse. There aren’t any queues and there’s little or no buzz; most retailer conversations indicates as much,” said Edelweiss Securities.

Offline retailers are hopeful of a pickup in demand over the next weekend when the most auspicious shopping day of dhanteras falls.

Edelweiss Securities noted that among various segments, luxury apparel is taking big hit while mid-market apparel is doing just about okay for offline stores. This could be due to e-commerce discounts and easy financing. 

“Car sales have been slower than that of two-wheelers. But consumer durables stores are ready to outprice e-com offers and are seeing strong sales. Most retailers are optimistic (desperately hopeful?) about the next (last) and big weekend,” the brokerage said.


Marketmen still hopefulNilesh Shetty of Quantum Mutual Fund said the festival season has not gotten off to a great start, but his meeting with companies recently versus a year ago suggests the pricing power coming back for them. 

“Demand on the ground seems to be a lot better than it was a year ago. We are somewhere close to in the early stage of a pickup in consumer demand. I am not too sure about the second half of FY19, but it looks like we are at the cusp of a pickup in consumer demand from where we were a year ago,” he told ET NOW. 

Sundaram MF said that the near-term macro-led issues is expected to be transitory and its impact on market sentiments should get mitigated as confidence on consumption growth gathers pace in the coming quarter.
“Structural factors such as increased farm mechanisation, favourable demographics, increasing income levels and working population, premiumisation within categories, should help household consumption spending in the long run. Added to this, initiatives on financial inclusion have been the fulcrum to bring large strata of rural population into mainstream finance and increase institutional credit and create long-term drivers for consumption growth,” it said.

More than three dozen firms in the portfolio of the country’s biggest institutional investor, Life Insurance Corporation of India (LIC), reported more than 50 per cent year-on-year (YoY) increase in net profit for the quarter ended September 30.

These companies are from across sectors such as paints, financials, cement, defence, pharma, paints, metal, insurance and PSUs.

Analysts have turned bullish on some of them post Q2 numbers. 

Stocks up the pecking order in LIC portfolio are the country’s biggest mortgage lender HDFC, biggest lender by assets managed SBI and major power players NTPC and Power Grid. These companies posted between 50 per cent and 400 per cent rise in profit during the quarter.

HDFC Securities has a ‘buy’ rating on SBI with a price target of Rs 389. “Positive surprises on asset quality can trigger a re-rating,” the brokerage said in a report. On a year-to-date basis, SBI shares advanced 7.57 per cent to Rs 322 till November 15.

On the other hand, power majors NTPC and Power Grid each dented LIC’s portfolio by over 5 per cent so far this year. 

Edelweiss Securities said the recent corporate tax cut would not majorly impact the power sector, as it will be a pass-through for companies following the regulated business model. 

“Taking a cue from the weakness in power demand, we are pruning our FY20 and FY21 demand forecast to 3 per cent and 5 per cent from 5 per cent and 6 per cent earlier,” it said. In an October report, the brokerage maintained its preference for NTPC.

Kotak Mahindra Bank, Bajaj Finserv, Dr Reddy’s Laboratories, Adani Ports, Adani Transmission, Asian Paints, UltraTech Cement, Indraprastha Gas, GSK Pharma and The Federal Bank are among other top stocks in the portfolio.

Only those LIC stocks which reported over 50 per cent increase in Q2 profit along with a rise in net sales were considered for this report. The screener threw up 37 companies from largecap, midcap and smallcap segments as of November 18. LIC held 370 stocks in its portfolio as of September 30 and out of them only 287 have announced September quarter number till date.

Garden Reach Shipbuilders, which delivered nearly 145 per cent return to LIC year to date, reported more than 300 per cent rise in profit on over 100 per cent increase in net sales in Q2.

The warship builder posted a net profit to Rs 59.02 crore for the second quarter of this financial year, on the back of higher revenue. It had posted Rs 12.78 crore profit for the corresponding period of 2018-19. The company had as many as 22 projects are at various stages of construction, with an order book of Rs 27,400 crore.

Bengal & Assam Company, Bharat Dynamics, Adani Transmission, Caprihans India, Chambal Fertilisers, Hudco, Gateway Distriparts, Indian Bank, ABB India, Hindustan Aeronautics and Granules India were among the companies that posted more than 100 per cent YoY rise in net profit for the quarter.

Among other midcaps and smallcaps, Aditya Birla Capital, Pfizer, The New India Assurance, Dalmia Bharat Sugar, Torrent Power and Mishra Dhatu Nigam and Granules India posted between 50-110 per cent YoY rise in net profit on up to 50 per cent increase in net sales.

In the financial space, Aashish Agarwal, Executive Director, Head of Research, CLSA has a preference for banking and non-lending financiers over NBFCs.

“A few trends would continue to play out in the banking sector; a) banks will gain market share at the cost of NBFCs, b) savings will continue to go towards insurance and asset management companies. So, these companies are in a sweet spot of high growth and decent profitability,” he said.
