Jio is adding more fancy for Reliance rather than oil and gas segment which has a muted outlook for FY20, Yogesh Mehta, Vice-President, Motilal Oswal Securities, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts: 

What has changed for Reliance that in last two days it has added Rs 35,000-crore market cap?
Nothing as such. But the ongoing outlook for almost 28 crores of Jio subscribers is now turning positive. They are very much optimistic and the layout of the capex is still on; plus the outlook on the oil and gas sector, especially refining margin is very stable as is crude oil in terms of dollar.

Overall, Jio is adding more fancy for Reliance rather than oil and gas because the outlook seems to be muted for next financial year so far. One needs to watch out how it turns out in the second half. But Jio is the one which is providing the strong outlook.


I agree that Jio is looking strong but what came out in the numbers which has given a Rs 100 move to Reliance? They have not said anything new on Jio. Your institutional team also feels that Reliance is fairly valued.
Overall, it is fairly valued. Gross refining margins in dollar terms is $9.5-10.5. But the valuation front on the global comparison is the one where it is still quoting at a not so premium but slightly discounted price to global peers. That way we are comparing it and on the EV to EBITDA front, with the margin in place and profitability grew by 25% YoY to Rs 10,000 crore for first ever time in a quarter. That 25% growth rate is still sustaining and that is why the largest market-cap company is still available at a reasonable valuation.


Do you think the market would be convinced by Sun Pharma reactions to whistleblower allegations?
Prima facie, the way stock price has reacted from Friday and yesterday, it seems that prima facie it has not been taken as a positive, even on the clarification which needed to be made public before any third party raised issues. It will not be viewed so positively by the investors even after that clarity which is coming. It is not that 100% justification needs to be there and it is not available at this point in time. Investors would like to avoid further addition but would have preferred more clarification.


While we are expecting sequential margin recovery in Asian Paints, would a delayed festival season act as a dampener when it comes to volumes?
 
 
 
 The numbers for Asian Paints are due today and delayed festive season impact probably would be there. But crude prices were not so volatile and variation was 10% on YoY basis. If we compare it sequentially, it was not much. So volume growth needs to be watched out for. PAT numbers will not be so exciting. It will be plus/minus 3% to 5% on YoY basis. 

Overall, we believe that crude price fluctuation was not there and festive season was in November this time, but there is not going to be so much of difference because October, November both fall under Q3. We are expecting muted numbers from Asian Paints.

“The decorative business segment in India registered a high double digit volume growth and delivered strong performance across regions. The Automotive coatings JV (PPG-AP), witnessed subdued growth in the Auto OEM segment while the Industrial Coatings JV (AP-PPG) continued to witness good growth in the Protective coatings – dealer segment and the Powder segment. Japan's Nikkei gained 0.2 per cent, helped by a recent pullback in the yen.

Oil prices edged lower on Tuesday as concerns over global economic growth stoked fears over future demand, Reuters reported. International Brent crude oil futures were down 10 cents, or 0.2 percent, at $62.64. 


US markets closed on Monday
US markets were closed on Monday. Trading in generally subdued overnight. However, equity prices in Europe and Latin America were hit after data showed a slowdown in growth in China, the world’s second biggest economy, Reuters reported.

The International Monetary Fund on Monday cut its world economic growth forecasts for 2019 and 2020 due to weakness in Europe and some emerging markets and said failure to resolve trade tensions could further destabilise a slowing global economy, Reuters reported.

India will further build its lead as the world’s fastest-growing major economy as it picks up pace next year while the global economy is forecast to slow, the International Monetary Fund said. Investors should look at increasing exposure to a whole range of consumption oriented companies not necessarily 
  
  
  just FMCG, Dipan Mehta, Portfolio Manager, Founder Director, Elixir Capital, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts:

What is on your radar? Are you convinced that the slowdown in auto is just an aberration because if consumer companies are coming up with strong volume growth? 
Yes, of course. I would say that a lot of consumption-oriented companies, be it in FMCG, auto, building materials, home improvement or appliances, have all been increasing their end product prices by 3-8% on account of increase in input costs. 

And now that commodity prices have started to cool off, we are seeing a slight reduction in margins for consumer companies like Asian Paints or Havells India. But this is certain to get reversed over the next couple of quarters.

These are great tidings for consumption-oriented, domestic-focussed companies. The high valuation may act as a bit of a barrier but at corrections, investors should look at increasing exposure to a whole range of consumption oriented companies not necessarily just FMCG. There are many other sub-sections within the consumption space.


Why did Reliance add Rs 100 post numbers?
The quarter’s performance was very well received by the market. Now, there is a growing expectation that the telecom and retail businesses have reached scale and at some point of time, value unlocking will take place where minority shareholders will get shares of these two entities in the form of splitting of the company.

The last time that happened was when the two Ambani brothers parted ways. Tha twas a huge value unlocking opportunity from Reliance Industries when the other companies got divested. At that time also, it was telecom and some of the other minor businesses which got divested. Something similar will happen this time around and I think that should be a great value creating exercise. 

However, one should keep in mind that valuations are on the higher side for Reliance Industries and the size is just too huge for the company to keep on delivering significant double digit type of earnings growth rate. It is best to price in high single digit growth rate for the entire company as a whole on a consolidated basis and keeping that in mind I think it is more or less fully priced unless there are some surprises on the performance front. 


What do you make of the consumption story going forward? So far, we have good numbers and the demand outlook remains quite intact. Do you believe that that will be the case for all the consumer majors including ITC?
ITC is in a different bracket and it is not really an FMCG company, it is a tobacco company and it has got some FMCG and hotel and other businesses. But all these have a very small contribution to the overall profitability and the earnings of the company. Tobacco broadly is a pretty much mature segment. The volume growth rates are low single digits and it is hampered by a lot of government taxation and there are other challenges as well in terms of imports of cigarettes, the indirect channel. So I am not that positive on ITC and have not been so for many years. The stock has underperformed to that extent. But ITC could have a trading bounce based on results, base effect may be favourable and you could have a few positive numbers coming through from their other divisions.

By and large, real FMCG companies like HUL, Britannia, Godrej Consumer and Jyothy Laboratories are the companies where maximum value will get created going forward. I would like to focus on those pure play FMCG companies rather than ITC.


But on the valuation front, ITC is available at a sharp or a steep discount to what other companies are commanding. Post GST, the uncertainty on tax front has got sorted out.
That is true but the underlying growth is not there in cigarette consumption. While we are extremely bullish on liquor companies and breweries, the same kind of growth rates do not get translated into tobacco.

It could be because of sort of regulations, the warnings which have been given, demographic trends but the underlying volume of its largest business remains extremely low single digit.

It is not that the market is now classifying it as a FMCG company because FMCG companies are trading at 50 times plus and ITC is available at a 40% discount as far as PE multiples are concerned. And the real difference is because it is not truly an FMCG company, it is a tobacco company and its growth rate is amongst the worst as far the consumption oriented business is concerned. 

Unfortunately, despite decades of trying to diversify away from tobacco, the company management has not been able to do so and even up to this point of time, the FMCG business does not contribute significantly to its bottom line, the hotel business has been languishing and the agro business also has not shown consistent growth. Compare ITC’s FMCG business to Godrej Consumers or Britannia’s FMCG business or Jyothy Laboratories or Nestle. Those companies have grown in size and scale and improved on their operating profit margins and created fabulous brands and value for their shareholder. On the other hand, ITC’s FMCG business has just about been trying to breakeven. Their return on investment is also amongst the lowest in the industry and that is the reason for a kind of a long-term avoid on ITC. 

The stock could see a trading bounce and go up by 25-30%. But it is not a great long term story compounding story.

Phillip Capital (India) has a buy call on Asian Paints with a target price of Rs 1,575.

The current market price of Asian Paints is Rs 1,405.70.

Time period given by the brokerage is one year when Asian Paints price can reach the defined target.


Investment rationale by the brokerage-
Volume growth of 20 per cent+ was pretty impressive and was much ahead of consensus expectations, which led operating performance beat on all fronts. APNT delivered a fourth consecutive quarter of double-digit volume growth on the back of 1) strong festive season, 2) GST reduction improving price competitiveness vs unorganized sector and 3) premiumization trends sustaining. Management highlighted performance was broad-based across segments/regions.

We expect healthy domestic demand to continue at least for next couple of quarters on the back of market share gains across segments (particularly distemper) on account of improved price competitiveness vs unorganized sector and higher fiscal spending ahead of general elections, 2019 shall aids growth. However, management cautioned that consumer demand environment remains uncertain ahead of General election.

Industrial coatings (particularly automotive coatings) continue to remain subdued on back of weak auto sales. Challenging macroeconomic environment (Egypt, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh), high RM costs (APNT lacks pricing power since it is not a leader in most of the markets) and partial availability of forex to buy raw materials (Ethiopia) has been denting International business performance. We expect performance for Industrial and International business to improve in FY20 as pre-buying ahead of BS-VI Implementation (from FY21 onwards will aid auto demand) and RM correction coupled with price hikes in foreign markets are likely to improve operating performance respectively.

We increase our EPS estimates for FY20-21 each by 6 per cent as most of the concerns relating to input cost inflation (crude down 27 per cent from its recent peak) are behind us and improving demand scenario. Our optimism is based on: (1) improving consumer sentiment, (2) reducing re-painting cycle, (3) focus on distribution expansion in tier 2/3 cities, and (4) government focus on creating physical/social infrastructure in rural areas ahead of 2019 general elections shall give a boost to volume growth. We believe that the recent reduction in GST rates on paints to 18 per cent from 28 per cent shall improve the organised sector’s competitiveness and accelerate the process of premiumization for the organized paint industry. We maintain BUY and increased our target price to Rs 1,575 (45x FY21 EPS) vs Rs 1,430 (45x Dec-20 EPS).

Brokerages have retained their bullish view on Asian Paints following its December quarter result, which saw the company surprising the Street on the volume growth front which grew in double digits. Target prices have been revised up by 7-34 per cent, with many brokerages rolling forward valuations.

Asian Paints on Tuesday posted a 14.6 per cent increase in consolidated profit from the year ago level at Rs 635.6 crore. Consolidated revenue increased 24 per cent to Rs 5,293.99 crore.

Shares of Asian Paints ended down 0.7 per cent at Rs 1,397.10 after gaining as much as 1.7 per cent intraday. The stock has gained 22.7 per cent in the last three months.

Macquarie, which revised up target price the most among brokerages, also upgraded the stock to 'outperform' from 'neutral'.

Citigroup, Credit Suisse, Jefferies, Kotak Institutional Equities, and Morgan Stanley revised target price higher by 7-25 per cent. CLSA retained the ‘outperform’ rating with a target price of Rs 1,565. Both Jefferies and HSBC retained ‘buy’ ratings and target price at Rs 1,600.



“Asian Paints reported one of the strongest quarters in eight years with volume growth of 20 per cent YoY, much above our and consensus estimate of 14 per cent," said Deutsche Bank.

“Although APNT’s (Asian Paints) robust volume growth of 20 per cent in 3QFY19 was largely driven by festive sales, its four-quarter moving average volume increased to 13 per cent YoY, much above the industry growth of 10 per cent YoY,” the bank added.

Morgan Stanley said price hikes and the benign input cost environment increase the visibility of over 20 per cent earnings growth for FY20-FY21.

Some brokerages such as Citi, Kotak Institutional and Credit Suisse have increased target prices but retained ‘neutral’ or ‘reduce’ rating. “We believe medium-term upsides are well reflected in stock valuations, particularly post the run-up in the last 3 months," said Citigroup.

NEW DELHI: Key equity indices Sensex and Nifty traded flat in the opening deals on Thursday, tracking lacklustre global cues as political uncertainty in the US and worries about weakening global economic growth weighed on investor sentiment.

Asian shares were subdued this morning with major indices trading marginally lower. 

The rupee traded with a nominal gains against the US dollar which failed to give any fillip to market. The domestic unit opened 7 paise higher at 71.26 against the US dollar on account of some selling in American currency by banks and exporters. 

After jumping about 70 points in the opening deals, Sensex gave up gains soon, falling over 40 points. 

Around 9:30 am, the 30-share Sensex was 31 points, or 0.09 per cent, down at 36,077.41, while Nifty was 11 points, or 0.10 per cent, down at 10,820.90. 

The BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices were up 0.08 per cent and 0.03 per cent, respectively, at that time.

Tata Motors, Infosys, Tata Steel, Mahindra & Mahindra and Coal India were among the top losers in the Sensex index, each falling over 1 per cent.

ITC, on the other hand, climbed over 1 per cent and was leading the pack of Sensex gainers around that time. 

Shares of Power Grid, NTPC, Asian Paints and Hero MotoCorp also traded with gains.

Among the sectoral indices, BSE Realty climbed over 1 per cent on gains in shares of DLF, Oberoi Realty, Sunteck Realty, Prestige Estates Projects and Indiabulls Real Estate.

BSE Metal index, on the other hand, fell over 1 per cent, with all components in the red. Jindal Steel & Power, Coal India, JSW Steel, Tata Steel and Nalco were among the top losers in the index. 

Foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) sold Rs 775.82 crore crore worth of domestic stocks on Wednesday, data available with NSE suggested. DIIs were net buyers to the tune of Rs 583.77 crore, data suggested. 

YES Bank, Biocon, Ultratech Cement, Colgate Palmolive, Reliance Power, Jindal Saw, ICRA, PVR, NIIT, Mphasis, Pfizer, Quess Corp, PNB Housing, Sintex, Zee Media and Sharda Corp are among the companies that will announce their December quarter results today.

Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive VP-Markets & Corporate Affairs, IIFL Securities, tells ET Now that one should look at 
  

 Bharti Airtel, Bharat Forge, Ujjivan and IDFC Bank First now. Edited excerpts:

The extraordinary volume growth reported by FMCG companies have been surprising. If FMCG companies are reporting such strong set of numbers, why are auto companies suffering?
It is just a one-month or a two-month hiatus since there was this talk of GST deadlocks and secondly, there was some problem with insurance premium and so on. But it is something which had a huge base effect and that is causing the slowdown. 

However, like you rightly pointed out, the consumer sector is driving growth and yesterday for the first time in almost one year, ITC showed a 10% growth on cigarette volumes. So, yes volumes are back and it is just a matter of time before auto is be up and running. 

Yesterday TVS Motors results were way ahead of the Street. The pessimism is overdone. If you are a slightly longer term investor and are looking for good bargains, then you are getting a whole hog of those in the autos. I would be relatively bullish after the budget and the other combined twin event of the election which could spur a lot of growth on the rural side, where again autos would be the indirect beneficiary.


What are some of your top bets? We know you are big on paints.
Yes, we have been very bullish on Asian Paints all the way from Rs 1,150 and we think that this is a unique stock where the market share decorative painting is getting stronger. They have indicated that the best effect of the price rise will also be met within this quarter. 

We have been bullish on Reliance, Asian Paints, Axis Bank and also a midcap called Mindtree at around Rs 800 level. It has seen a lot of interest given that L&T Tech is now trying to buy a stake. A whole host of stocks have done well. One of my top picks is ITC and I can reiterate that yesterday’s fall should be a buying opportunity. The cigarette volumes have pleasantly surprised on the upside and once we get a price hike, other businesses which are doing exceeding well will add up. So ITC becomes a star for 2019.


When old timers real performers start selling out some of the core holdings in and around quality names, one wonders why. Is this redemption or this is an indication that they are looking at changing their portfolio orientation?
I cannot speak for the fund but definitely some churning may be on the cards. It could be some sort of lightening of positioning ahead of valuations and so on. I cannot comment on certain stocks because they are under our institutional coverage. 

Look at Airtel, Sunil Bharti Mittal says the worst of pricing maybe over, it is time for prices to come back. They are divesting a lot of their assets to improve return on equity. Look at Bharat Forge which is now a global player and where again you have seen valuation weaken because of the North American crisis. Look at Ujjivan where again you have seen very strong NIMs and asset quality improvement. Look at IDFC Bank First, again a marquee idea, where Vaidyanathan is going to lead from the front. 

So, there is a whole host of sectors where blue chips or midcaps can emerge as huge wealth creators and that could be the churn which is going on. We know that impact cost in some of the marquee names have a huge effect on entry and exit and hence the market will be looking at some of the weakness getting prolonged.

We are relatively very bullish on some of these ideas. Davos has told us that a couple of large entrepreneurs are seeing extreme bullish signs in the near future.

The circumstances are such that a rate cut is the most likely outcome in RBI's February policy review, Saurabh Mukherjea, Founder, Marcellus Investment Managers, told ETNow. His advice: Invest in companies where accounts are clean, the management is competent and are generally well run. Edited excerpts:


For me, the surprise this earning season is not IT and banks, it is actually consumer names. Double digit volume growth from ITC, Asian Paints and again from HUL. Autos are slowing down, but consumer companies are doing exceptionally well.

It's a question of consumption not being financed by borrowing. Obviously for auto and to some extent electrical items, consumption is financed by borrowing. Wherever consumption is not financed by borrowing, I think things are in a pretty reasonable shape in our country. FMCG is an obvious beneficiary. I would even say for things like apparel, you can see volumes are brisk. There is enough juice in the economy. Those who do not need to borrow money for small ticket consumption are going out there and buying things and hence, the bumper FMCG numbers.


Do you think at a time like this, when you already have high price consumer names delivering that one on the back of growth, visibility continues to invest more in those stocks versus the investment-led themes where again there is a bit of uncertainty. The Budget push is expected to drive interest in those stocks or themes as well. But given the volatility the portfolios might face, it is better and safer to still be with the high price names that are delivering.

With the obsession about valuations, we might get the wrong end of the story here. Begin by asking yourselves what is the outlook for India over the next one or two years. The outlook is of an economy which is decelerating since Q1 where cost of capital is gradually inching up even if the RBI cuts rates in February. Generally, cost of capital, the 10-year bond yield and the 3-month CP are pushing upwards amid a currency which will stay with the 70 handle potentially pushed towards 75. 

That is the broad picture for the next one or two years and I am not so sure elections really are that relevant in this picture. Whichever government wins, you end up with this gradual economic deceleration due to rising cost of capital and a weak currency. In that context, export-oriented sectors, well-run private banks, small-ticked consumption, FMCG consumption, to some extent elements of consumption such as apparel where you do not have to borrow to buy, are in a good place to be. 

We will see a revival in the capex sector one day, but that revival in the capex sector comes after the election and that comes after there is some sign that cost of capital might start trending down in our country. As yet, there is not any sign that cost of capital in India will suddenly start trending down.


Time and again, you have made a case that you should buy exporters. As of now, IT companies are not admitting that there is a problem. But pharma companies have started admitting that the generic pricing power pressure is here to stay. Against the backdrop of a global slowdown, a little bit of pricing power going away for key sectors like pharma, what happens to exporters as a category? 

There are two elements to consider. Yes, you are right. The global economy is not sort of roaring away anywhere. If anything, global growth is decelerating and you are right in highlighting that. What is clear, however, is our export sector is very currency sensitive. We do not really have a very tech heavy export sector. Even our IT services are actually low tech exports. We have already seen in the last couple of quarters the benefits of the currency slide help the IT companies. 

Pharma companies with say Dr Reddy’s, the Vanguard are already showing signs of finding their former competitive spirit. If the rupee does not slide which it did not, that punishes Indian pharma globally. India pharma is a price sensitive export and the rupee staying at Rs 64-65 for four years was deeply damaging for Indian pharma. The slide to 71 of the rupee will help pharma. 

There are first signs that help will come through. Domestic demand for pharma obviously continues to hold up pretty well, given FDA's attack on Indian pharma. There is long overdue revival there. Beyond that, beyond IT and pharma, it is selective smaller companies say Balkrishna Industries and LG Equipment where you could see competitive Indian company with world class products benefiting from a weak rupee. IT's and pharma's front line names will benefit from the slide in the rupee. IT benefits are already evident. Pharma benefits will come.


Address all the curious questions which haunted the stock on corporate governance or once bitten twice shy investors will not come back in a hurry.

Well, corporate governance in India is not really a sector-specific problem, unfortunately. For decades now, minority shareholders have borne the brunt of the fact that promoters are able to get away with doing things which could not have been possible in other countries.

That remains one of the big issues in Indian investing. Which is why for as long as I have been on your channel, I have emphasised that invest in companies where the accounts are clean, the management is competent and is generally a well run high quality company. Regardless of the sector, look for comfort on governance and accounts because it does not matter what the guy is making, what the promoter is making. If he wants to steal money from you, you are not going to make any money buying those shares.


Advocating a 50 bps rate cut by the RBI in one shot would mean that would be a complete U-turn in a matter of about 4-5 months.

I am not advocating that the RBI should cut rates, my reckoning is that the RBI will cut rates given everything that has transpired in the final six months of 2018. It will be surprising if we do not see some degree of easing from the RBI. 

I am not so sure cutting rates by 25 bps is going to bring some enormous relief to the Indian economy at this juncture because what is happening is the money market is tightening up as risk aversion kicks in both in the 10-year bond yield. In the short term money market, you can see things are tightening up, FII investors in the bond market and domestic investors in the bond market are becoming more apprehensive and in that context, the central bank cutting by 25 bps will not have a huge impact on the economy.

But the circumstances are such that a rate cut looks like the most likely outcome in the February policy review.


I do not have any data to prove that there is a turn in insurance or ULIP, but is this something which markets are not prepared for because now we are taking domestic liquidity for granted. The general view on Street is that domestic institutional investor will always get money, they will never get redemptions and ULIP money is permanent?

Well I think, it is ULIP or indeed the MF flows. December was a wake-up call for everybody and I agree with you that the notion that the Indian retail investor will keep pumping money into MFs or ULIPs. I think the notion has got overplayed a little bit. 

Yes, there is a structural trend towards financialisation in our country as people realise that putting their life savings in real estate and gold is not a particularly clever idea but obviously that structural trend will have rounded cycles and to that extent, a lot of people did enter the stock market because they had belief in Prime Minister Modi. 

As we approach the elections, that sort of investment sentiment around a specific political personality is obviously bound to be shaky. 2019 could well be the year where we realise that yes, there is a structural trend towards financialisation but it does not mean it is a one way bet of high inflows into MFs and ULIPs month after month.


What is your sense on the range for the market into the elections? I know the immediate focus is the Budget, but if you take the bird’s eye-view, you scan through CY2019, how would you divide the first half performance versus the second half?

I will stick to what I have been saying on your channel for the last 12 months or so. Fair value for the Nifty is around 9,500, given the still weak earnings outlook. 

Whether we get to that number in the run-up to the election or say after the July budget, which I think will be a contractionary budget regardless of which government is in power, is a slightly secondary question, what it suggests is that we have a market which is 10-15 per cent overvalued. Therefore, buying the market in totality I do not think is a particularly good idea at this juncture. 

You are better off doing selective buying of high quality companies, the consistent compounders, clean, well run companies. If you want to play sectors, then play the sectors which can thrive in a weak economy like IT, pharma, small ticket consumption and private sector banks.

No broad-based sharp uptick in private capex cycle is seen in foreseeable future, Gautam Chhaochharia, Head of 
  
  
  India Research, UBS Securities, tells ET Now. At a top-down sector level, industrials, infrastructure midcaps are a total avoid.Edited excerpts:


The new buzz on the town is that whenever there is a new CEO in a private bank, the stock gets rerated. We saw that happen to Axis Bank, ICICI Bank and now Yes Bank. From an institutional investor standpoint, should one buy private banks now because the PSU banks are losing market share and the top three private banks now have new CEOs?
We have been overweight on private corporate banks and we still remain overweight there. CEO change is just one factor, the fundamental factors matter a lot more. Within the broader private corporate banks, we are emphasising those banks which have a retail liability franchise. 

So, while we are overweight in the overall space, the focus is on the ones which have retail liability franchise. The banks which do not really have a retail liability franchise are more wholesale funded in our view and remain vulnerable. That is the differentiation we are emphasising to investors and one has to look at what is priced in into individual stocks etc.


Are you bullish, are you bearish, are you in a wait-and-watch mode? What is your house view for 2019?
We are still cautious on the broader markets. We have looked at different scenarios of markets post elections. We have also analysed and tried to see what kind of policy environment will be there post elections in different scenarios and then look at what the ranges could be in that environment.

Looking at those scenarios, the risk reward still seems unattractive. Our base case for Nifty is 10,000 by December 2019 which suggests about 7-8% downside from the current levels. The risk-reward is still not supportive for us to get constructive and there are two simple reasons for that; first, the first half of the year is obviously the politics part which will keep uncertainty high; second, looking at various policy options, we are seeing an increase in populism narrative ahead of elections. It could also mean the policy space is constrained for the first six to 12 months for any new government to really kickstart the economy. 

So, that is the other thing to keep an eye out on from a market’s perspective. And keeping both in mind, we would also remember the valuations. While the markets have corrected a bit, the de-rating has not been that dramatic at the Nifty level, though we have seen some de-rating at the midcap level. That keeps us cautious on the markets here.


The word on the street is populism and how the budget is likely to be doled out this time around. How do you think the overall political scenario is going to impact the equity markets? What are your expectations?
This is likely to be a vote-on-account as it always has been because irrespective of whatever the budget talks about, it is a finance bill. It has to be passed by the parliament, but obviously the government can talk about the policy scenarios going ahead. So, they could talk about what they might do post the elections but largely it will be a vote on account. 

Secondly, the political scenario as we said is uncertain as of now. We do not know what will happen, but it is important to think about how markets react to different government formation scenarios. I will give you two simple examples; In the last four, four-and-a-half years, we have seen earnings growth being muted, But the markets have rerated strongly and have done very well because the narrative on policy, reforms, macro stability has been very strong and positive for the markets.

In the late ‘90s, during the Third Front government, the policy was actually fine. They did not really do anything stupid on fiscal deficit. The reforms trajectory was largely continued. We had some bold tax measures also, but the Indian markets derated and underperformed the regional market because the markets worried about uncertainty on both political as well as policy part. So that narrative also is relevant. What kind of government we get post election, may or may not necessarily mean a dramatic shift in the real policy environment but the market sentiment and narrative may get hurt depending on who forms the government. Therefore, that matters for the markets.


We talk about high valuations in FMCG companies, about overcrowded trades in some of the consumer staple stocks. Looking at the volume growth, 10% for HUL on that large base, 20% for Asian Paints on that large base, 7-8% from ITC which is now a behemoth and also in the FMCG space, it just makes me wonder whether it is time to remain bearish on staples? They may be expensive but that is where the growth is?
So again, valuation reflects the lack of options in the broader markets. While we still have strong inflows and liquidity and this is a phenomenon globally, not just in India. 

Having said that, the volume uptick in staples has not been a surprise at least to us. Our evidence lab work, in the middle of the last year ahead of the festive season had suggested that while we might see volume disappointments in automobiles and the staples, we should see an uptick as volume trajectory normalises for most of the companies. But one to be stock selective and not take a broad-based staples approach. The focus on rural India from the government side has been inching up over the last year, year-and-a-half so that is also possibly helping the staples deliver good volumes.


Do you think FY20 would be a better earnings year for corporate India than what we have seen in FY19? 
Earnings obviously matter because returns are a mix of earnings and multiples. When we talk about narrative, it hurts multiples negatively and obviously theoretically, earnings can make up for that but FY20 will definitely be a better year than last six years. As for FY19, for corporate India and for the Nifty, it will be back to double digit earnings growth finally. We are forecasting top down around 15-16% growth for the Nifty but again, a large part of it would be driven by normalisation in the financials NPL cycle. 

If we strip out the financials NPL driven recovery, then the underlying growth is still in single digits. Optically, it will be good for the markets but even at 15-16%, we will see roughly 9% cut to street estimates. So earnings cuts will still be quite sharp in the next few months but at a top down level, it would still be supportive for the markets.


What is you view on the overall capital goods space? Could we see the overall private capex cycle benefitting a lot of capital goods companies in the quarter? Do you expect some more reforms doled out in the upcoming budget which could benefit this space
So, that is one sector where we have a contrarian view. We do not see any uptick of a private capex cycle. Small uptick of a low base, normalisation yes but no beginning of a private capex cycle as such. 

When the populism narrative is rising ahead of elections, the space left for helping capex obviously gets constrained. We are already seeing signs of that in various government infrastructure initiatives already. 

Secondly, our capex analyst has done some interesting bottom-up work, which suggests that the signs of capex recovery either in terms of capacity utilisation, news flow or commentary by corporates actually represents roughly 20% of private capex. 

So if you break up private capex into different sectors, roughly 20% of that is likely to see an uptick and roughly 50% to 60% of the private capex is in sectors where we do not see any visibility of capex cycle recovering anytime soon. So yes, the 20% will help optically private capex coming off from a low base to recover a bit, but no broad-based sharp uptick in private capex cycle is seen in the foreseeable future.


Fundamentally what could go wrong this year? 
Fundamentally, it is not elections but the populist narrative going into elections that could become overbearing and take away the policy space. We have already seen parties talking about pan-India farm loan waivers, other doles, etc. All of this could help or may not help politically but it definitely means the space left for policymakers to drive a stronger economic recovery post election becomes constrained. 

That is really a worrying point from my perspective for markets because otherwise India was quite well set post elections. All the pain of GST, DeMo is behind us. The banking sector finally seems to be coming back on track and would have been supportive of growth. If we had a conducive policy environment post elections, we could have seen at least some form of cyclical recovery in India but this populism narrative is a dampener and could dampen that recovery for the first year for the government at least.


How should investors approach the broader end of the market? Should one go stock specific in mid and smallcaps?
Absolutely. As an asset class, we still remain underweight on midcaps just like last year because while we have seen valuations correct, relative valuations of midcaps to largecaps do not really give us comfort enough to jump in at this level. Even if we strip out the loss-making small and midcaps, related to largecaps, they remain more expensive than they were in 2007-08. So, risk-reward is still not attractive for the broader asset class of small and midcaps. But yes, stock specific opportunities are there definitely.


What would you avoid in this market? What are the themes that you would be bearish on or underweight on?
We are underweight in general cyclicals, given the policy space being constrained and the uncertainty around the elections which includes capex, industrials, etc. Definitely we are underweight midcaps and still avoid them. There the risk reward is still not attractive. Also, while we have neutral stance on various sectors like autos, etc, there are enough stocks there where the correction or derating has not happened enough or we do not see any visibility of recovery to get positive yet, At a top-down sector level, avoid industrials, infrastructure midcaps.

ET Intelligence Group: Several companies catering to retail consumers have reported higher sales volume growth for the December 2018 quarter reflecting a sustained demand across various segments of consumption.

Asian Paints, Kajaria Ceramics, Reliance Retail, Hindustan Unilever, Bajaj Consumer Care, and Interglobe Aviation are some of the prominent companies that have shown strong volume growth. In addition, some of the companies increased product prices by 2-5 per cent sequentially.

Asian Paints, which commands over half of the market share in the paints business, recorded volume growth of 20 per cent. This was not only better than the 14 per cent growth estimated by analysts but also the strongest in any of the quarters in eight years. The festive demand during Q3 and reduction in GST rates on paints were key growth factors. It hiked prices by 7.3 per cent in the past nine months.



In the building-products segment, Kajaria Ceramics posted volume growth of 16 per cent, the highest in the last 16 quarters. The company’s management expects double-digit growth to continue in the coming quarters. It hiked prices of ceramic tiles by 2-3 per cent.

The passenger growth of Interglobe, India’s largest aviation company, was above 20 per cent for the fourth consecutive quarter. Its average ticket prices improved by 6 per cent year-on-year to ?4,176, the highest rate in five quarters. The company has guided for 30 per cent capacity addition in the March 2019 quarter. Its capacity in terms of available seat kilometres rose by 29 per cent and 33 per cent in the September and the December quarter.

HUL recorded double-digit volume growth for the fifth consecutive quarter supported by rural growth, which was 1.3 times the growth in urban markets. Its average realisation grew by 3.8 per cent year-on-year. Bajaj Consumer Care reported volume growth of 9.4 per cent in almond hair oil segment, the highest in the last 15 quarters.

The volume momentum in consumer goods has also resulted in advertisement growth of media companies. For example, Zee Entertainment’s advertisement growth was 22 per cent in Q3. Nearly 60 per cent of ads came from the consumer oriented companies.

Reliance Retail, the country’s largest retailer by revenue, reported 89 per cent growth in revenue for the December quarter and 108 per cent growth in the past nine months.

The festive season sales and new store openings resulted in high revenue growth and its operating area rose by 42 per cent to 20.6 million square feet in the first nine months of FY19.

The domestic equity market continued its whipsaw movement with a downward bias and shallow depth during the week gone by.

Secular sectors like FMCG have delivered good numbers, but cyclicals have disappointed the market.

Moreover, retail players have surprised everyone by delivering double-digit growth. Organised players have indeed gained at the cost of SMEs and MSMEs, which can be seen from their quarterly numbers.

This was also the vindication that GST and demonetisation have impacted a large population, which is also what is worrying the government since elections are around the corner. Hopefully, the Union Budget next week will assuage such concerns of the middle class. However, being a populist Budget, it might not be welcomed by the market given the effect it might have on corporate profitability. Nonetheless, all eyes will be on it for clarity on policy initiatives.

The political fever is hitting a high day after day, wherein economics has taken a back seat in all the decision-making processes of the government, which will further keep the market under pressure. In addition, very little has come out on the efforts to settle the trade dispute between the US and China, which has cast doubt on the resolution.

 “We are not completely under the bear grip, but yes investors have lost money in the last one year because of various uncertainties both from domestic as well as from global factors” said Raamdeo Agrawal, joint MD, Motilal Oswal Financial Services. “Only few stocks are performing which holding back indices and this trend would continue till earnings across the sectors bounce back”

The Sensex and Nifty have lost 1% and 3% respectively in the last one year compared to 18% fall in MSCI Emerging Market Index. During year 2016 and 2017, Indian benchmark rallied 30%.

“The surge in the market seen through 2017 was based on hope, not fundamentals. The expectations reached such staggering levels that when they were not met, things came crashing down” said Raamdeo Agrawal.

The effect of a crash in the Zee group companies, including Zee Entertainment and Dish TV shares, was visible in the stocks of companies where promoters have pledged their holdings. Zee Entertainment and Dish TV lost nearly 30 per cent on Friday due to the sale of the pledged promoter shares in Dish TV.

The biggest losers on Monday were the shares of Adani Group companies – Adani Power and Adani Ports and SEZ. Promoter holdings across Adani group companies are pledged. A high debt in the group companies led to panic in the two group company shares, which fell 19 per cent and 13 per cent, respectively. Shares of Indiabulls group companies – Indiabulls Real Estate and Indiabulls Housing Finance, Reliance ADAG group companies and DHFL reported similar falls. Shares of these companies were down 5 per cent to 12 per cent.



In some cases, the promoters have raised money in the unlisted holding companies through which they hold shares of the listed companies. The underlying collateral is mostly the shares of the listed companies. Any likelihood of the holding company not able to meet its debt obligations may lead to selloff in the counters of the listed companies. For instance, Wadhawan Global Capital, Cyquator and Geetanjali Trading and Investments the holding companies of DHFL, Zee Entertainment and Asian Paints, respectively, have raised money from mutual funds.

If investors on Dalal Street are jittery about share pledges, they have good reasons to be so. India Inc promoters had shares worth Rs 2.50 lakh crore pledged with their lenders at the end of December quarter.

That works out to about 2 per cent of total market capitalisation of BSE500 stocks at current market prices and was higher from Rs 2.40 lakh crore worth of share pledges recorded as of December 31, 2017.

Among Nifty50 companies, promoters of Zee Entertainment had pledged 59.40 per cent of their holdings as of December 2018. It was followed by Adani Ports (45.50 per cent), JSW Steel (43.60 per cent), IndusInd Bank (26.40 per cent), Indiabulls Housing Finance (12.70 per cent) and Asian Paints (11.90 per cent). 



Zee Entertainment, JSW Steel, Sun Pharmaceutical and YES Bank saw promoters increase share pledge levels between September and December quarters.

Zee Entertainment last week hogged limelight after lenders sold some of the pledged shares. 

An elevated level of shares pledging is not considered good as a downturn in market can lead to invocation of such shares, leading to oversupply and severe correction in stock prices, while in extreme cases, it can even trigger a change in a company’s shareholding pattern.

Promoters of 50 BSE500 companies had pledged over 25 per cent of their holdings by the end of December quarter, data available with Ace Equity showed. At the top, promoters of CG Power & Industrial Solutions had pledged 100 per cent of their holdings, whereas those of Sterlite Technologies and Gayatri Projects had pledged over 90 per cent of holdings. 

For a lay investor, share pledging does not necessarily imply that a company or a promoter is in financial distress. Banks (lenders) could have sought additional security in the form of promoters’ shares to advance loans.

Among other companies, whose promoters have pledged more than 80 per cent of holdings with their lenders were Jindal Stainless (Hisar), Jindal Stainless, Reliance Infrastructure, Reliance Power, GMR Infrastructure, Dish TV India and Max Financial Services. 

In the case of Coffee Day Enterprises, Suzlon Energy, Max India, Apollo Hospitals, Reliance Capital and Bajaj Consumer, promoters have pledged between 70-80 per cent of their holdings. 

In a bull market, share pledging may not be that important a factor for investors to consider. But when market sentiment turns risk off, it does. A high level of share pledging is undesirable and may signal a situation of distress. A decline in the level of share pledging may suggests a drop in stress. 

Among BSE500 companies, Eveready Industries, Indiabulls Real Estate, Coffee Day Enterprises, Jain Irrigation, Infibeam Avenues, and Jindal Steel and Power saw promoters increase share pledge levels by 13-45 percentage points in Q3 on a quarter-on-quarter basis.



The extent of pledging is definitely a matter of concern for an investor. Pledging in a capital-intensive company is highly risky. Promoters generally pledge for a mix of both for their personal needs as well as for reinvestment in their businesses. Pledging should always be a matter for concern. In a bull market, no one sees the level of pledging. Technically, promoters only know everything about their companies. Investors should always be wary of promoters’ share pledge levels. Temporary pledging of 10 per cent or so or for the first time is okay, but if it is a habit to pledge shares quarter after quarter, then that is definitely a warning sign, says Hitesh Agrawal, Head of Retail Research, Religare Securities.

Companies like Fortis Healthcare, Suzlon Energy and Advanced Enzyme saw a drop of over 10 percentage points in promoters’ share pledge levels during December quarter.

 “Generally, share pledging cannot be taken as a good sign. Promoters pledge shares either for their personal use or for the company’s needs. So, the objective of pledging is crucial,” said Sanjeev Jain, AVP, Ashika Stock Broking.

In some cases, banks normally ask promoters to pledge their shares as margin in case they are doubtful about the health of their businesses. “Investors need to watch the size and period of holding of such share pledges. Pledging in large volume is not a good sign. In a bad market, lenders may sell the pledged shares if the promoter does not meet the margin shortfall, which may mount pressure on stock price,” Jain said.

Investment rationale by the brokerage-

Solid volume traction; pricing provides strong revenue visibility: APNT’s volume growth over the last 10 years has been an average 11 per cent, which is one of the highest in consumer space. It also has a consistent price hike history with an average price hike of 4 per cent the in the last 7 years. We expect APNT to witness 13 per cent volume growth in FY19E following solid traction in 3QFY19, which saw 24 per cent YoY revenue growth with the decorative segment registering nearly 20 per cent YoY volume growth. APNT hiked prices by 4.1 per cent in 3QFY19 to offset higher input prices. With these price hikes, the weighted average price hike for FY19 is seen at nearly 5 per cent with nearly 2.5 per cent flowing into FY20E. Thus, revenue visibility will continue to remain very strong in FY20 as well. We believe APNT will continue to register solid double-digit volume growth in FY20E/FY21E on the back of highly diversified portfolio and a healthy demand environment.


Significant capacity addition in FY19; operating leverage gains to follow: APNT’scapacity addition in FY19 is 0.6mn KL/year, which translates into a capacity enhancement of 53 per cent, which is quite significant. Further, its operating cost and depreciation expenses significantly increased in 3QFY19 with operation of Mysuru plant, which added 300,000KL/year capacity in September 2018. Notwithstanding significant capacity addition, APNT’s EBIDTA,PAT and Sales grew by 17 per cent YoY, 12 per cent YoY and 24 per cent YoYin 3QFY19. Strong revenue traction is expected to continue in FY20E and FY21E, which will aid will be 18 per cent CAGR in earnings growth through FY19-21. APNT incurred Rs10bn capex in FY19 out of which Rs8bn capex was towards capacity enhancement. However, capex is expected to decline in FY20E/FY21E.


International & automotive segment sluggish; industrial segment seems encouraging: APNT’s international segment delivered a sluggish performance in FY19 owing to challenges in countries like Sri Lanka, Egypt & Bangladesh, as it does not enjoy market leadership to exercise pricing power. Ethiopia is witnessing raw material challenges because of lack of forex availability. Though its domestic automotive segment is seeing sluggish growth, industrial segment is seeing good traction. Home improvement business is still a small segment contributing 2 per cent to APNT’s revenues but has the potential to add significant value in the long-term.


Outlook & valuation: At CMP, the stocktrades at premium valuation of 45x FY20E earnings. However, it has the requisite pricing power to deliver sustainable revenue growth, going forward. On reverse DCF valuation basis, the CMP implies 13 per cent CAGR in revenue for the next 20 years, which is lower than the last 15/10-years CAGR of 16 per cent/15 per cent, respectively. We value APNT at 45x FY21E earnings.

Midcaps and a large part of select PSUs can be huge outperformers but it is going to stock specific. There is scope 
  
  
  to be contrarian in a number of sectors, Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive VP-Markets & Corporate Affairs, IIFL Securities, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts: 

At the beginning of the year, the view was that US markets will remain under pressure, emerging markets will come back and the rally would be led by India. But now, everything has gone up and we are feeling left behind. Why is India underperforming the world with such good macros?
Consensus generally tends to get proved wrong. Now, we were of the view that the Dow is due for a very strong rally and the dollar should weaken. Yesterday bond yields hit 2.68%, which tells you that Donald Trump has won over the Fed chairman and now there is dovishness which seems very good news for emerging markets. 

For India, there is this overhang of NBFCs and disclosures by DHFL, Zee. but being an Indian, we know this is part and parcel of all market moves. We are extremely positive. We think the results from select largecaps and midcaps have been extremely flattering and this could prove to be a lull before the storm. We will go up from 11000 to 11200 in February and I can reiterate that by 15th of April, you should be close to new highs. 

That aside, the midcaps and a large part of select PSUs can be huge outperformers and so it is going to more stock specific, but I do not rule out a 500-700 point rally in February.


A 500-point rally, did I hear you right? What could be the trigger, what will take us 2-3% higher on the Nifty?
Two things; a) you will get over the budget where there could be some surprise packages in the form of tax exemption and b) the RBI turning extremely dovish and a rate cut coming. We know that we are in the realm of low inflation, low yields and the RBI trigger, liquidity and foreign flows on a strong rupee will all be the caveats for February being a very good month. 


Let us talk about some of the policy sensitives. You highlighted how the accommodative stance from RBI would help the policy sensitive or the rate sensitive sectors. Could there be a contrarian opportunity in real estate?
Yes. Real estate assets have never been cheaper and stocks have actually been underperforming miserably. Once we get through these elections and see stability, it is a given that real estate prices as fixed assets should get a lion’s share of the money rather than gold. I am very bearish on gold. I would say that fixed assets will do well including real estate. 

Our top pick continues to be Godrej Properties followed by Sobha and maybe a Prestige Estate. These are three stocks where we can actually put a lot of money and be confident because the churning has separated men from the boys. Real estate can stand to gain by the middle of this year and later from there. 


The ICICI Bank numbers are good. The ADR shot up by about 8-9% overnight but the stock has also moved 40% in this fiscal itself. How much scope does it have to move forward from here?
That is a good point. Smart money has been buying ICICI right from the time both the two agony aunts of Axis and ICICI left and if you were contrarian there, you have really made a lot of money. I still think we are headed much higher. Rs 700 is something which I do not rule out in the next one and a half years on ICICI and Rs 800 on Axis Bank. These are going to be prime plays on the corporate lending side and we have seen a cleansing of balance sheet. 

I can even add that State Bank should be a big outperformer in this trio of stocks. Another stock which I am very bullish on is IDFC First Bank. That will be the star of 2019 and Mr Vaidyanathan will see that bank is a huge outperformer in the next one year.


What is the call on IT, especially the bigwigs?
We have had two stocks as contrarian plays; MindTree and HCL Tech. We stand by that and Wipro is the dark horse which has out beaten all. We think these three should be the best combination to play on the IT side. 


You have advocated Maruti but what is the view with some of the two-wheeler names in the wake of the expected big allocation for the farm sector? Will that trickle down into consumption numbers for autos, the two-wheelers?
We have seen autos go through the proverbial problem of competition like in telecom. Bajaj Auto stands out and they have given away part of the margins to get market share and that seems to be working. But I think this is just the lull before the storm, this has been a very strong sector for the last three years and this quarter we have seen problems because of insurance overhang of NBFCs.

I still think that both Bajaj Auto and Hero are looking very good on the two-wheeler side. You even have Eicher and TVS. So, if you bought a basket of stocks and went for a SIP. rather than one outright purchase, you can make a fair amount of money. 

Consumption is going to come back once you get lower rates. Following the NBFC fiasco, most of the other banks started to lend very aggressively and insurance is now on the back burner. So. I am relatively bullish on autos. 

As a contrarian one of my top picks is Ashok Leyland. It is the third largest bus maker in the world. It will have 50% market share in India and you have seen state governments now get on the prologue of electric vehicles where Ashok Leyland has a first over there. Also in the LCV, MHV side. I think they are going to show strong numbers March quarter onwards. So at Rs 80-82, this is a very good bargain buy with a target of 125 to 135 by next Diwali. 


What has gone wrong for Godrej Consumer? HUL is growing at 10% plus, ITC is growing at 8-9% plus. Other companies which have reported numbers so far, are not bad including Asian Paints. Why is Godrej Consumer the odd one out?
It could be a one quarter hiatus and I do not see that lasting. I think they will be back. We have seen the strong numbers in durables particularly the likes of Havells, Bajaj Electrical, Voltas and like you mentioned, the discretionaries and the sales of Asian Paints, ITC. 

Godrej Consumer definitely deserves to be bought. It is a pedigree name, the brand is doing extremely well and it is just a matter of time where higher costs will start to reduce and margins will expand. I think this quarter onwards you should start to see much better traction on volumes.


But the management has said that 2019 will be a bad year for them! Do you think this is an indication of what is happening to the sector per se or this is isolated to Godrej Consumer?No, it could be isolated to them because there is competition which has brewed up over there and like I said, they are a very conservative management. They under promise and over deliver and that is what stands out for Godrej. 

However, consumption is a mixed bag. We have seen autos weak but we have durables doing extremely well. A company-specific move may be on the cards but definitely the broader band of peer groups are doing extremely well. So ITC continues to be our top pick over there and we think that they are going to just expand much more on the other businesses which is evident in the numbers on paper, hotels and the FMCG.

If you managed to make money in equities since last Union Budget, consider yourself super lucky. As many as 86 per cent of BSE-listed stocks wiped off up to 97 per cent of wealth between February 1, 2018 and January 30, 2019. BSE Sensex fell 315 points, or 0.88 per cent, to 35,591 in the same period.

At the same time, 31 stocks – all smallcaps – managed to more than double investor wealth with Vikas Proppant & Granite rallying 708 per cent, followed by Darjeeling Ropeway (up 572 per cent), Dolat Investment (up 515 per cent), Orient Tradelink (up 376 per cent), Bullish Bonds and Holdings (up 349 per cent) and Tiaan Ayurvedic & Herbs (up 302 per cent). 

Among others, Bio Green Papers, Responsive Industries, Punjab Alkalies, Merck, Sukama Exports, Kilitch Drugs, IOL Chemicals, Scan Steels, Birla Cable, Dalal Street Investments and Sadhana Nitro Chem surged between 100 and 225 per cent.

The past 12 months was highly volatile for the Indian equity market amid global trade war, winding up of soft money policy by central banks, wild movement in crude oil prices, rupee depreciation, default by a leading NBFC player, sustained outflow by foreign institutional investors and state elections. Second-run stocks witnessed severe selling pressure all through this phase. 

The BSE Midcap index has cracked 16 per cent, while BSE Smallcap index plunged 26 per cent since last Union Budget. Among top losers, Global Infratech, Ashapura Intimates Fashion, Sunstar Realty, Yamini Investments, Tara Jewels, Kwality, Rolta India, Sunil Hitech Engineers, IL&FS Transportation, LEEL Electricals, Punj Lloyd, Talwalkars Better Value Fitness and Vakrangee are down between 85 per cent and 97 per cent in this period.

In the 30-share Sensex pack, 11 stocks created wealth for investors since February 1, 2018. Bajaj Finance rallied the most at 50 per cent, followed by Infosys, Reliance Industries, Hindustan Unilever, Tata Consultancy Services, Asian Paints, Axis Bank , Kotak Mahindra Bank, ICICI Bank, HCL 

Technologies and HDFC Bank, which rose between 2 per cent and 27 per cent. 

With a fall of 56 per cent, Tata Motors was the worst loser in the Sensex pack. Other prominent losers included YES Bank, Vedanta, Tata Steel, Bharti Airtel, Maruti Suzuki, Hero MotoCorp, ONGC and Bajaj Auto, which cracked over 25 per cent each.

NSE’s Nifty plunged 3.31 per cent to 10,651 on January 30, 2019 from 11,016 on February 1, 2018.

Inflows from domestic investors capped the downside over the past 12 months as foreign portfolio investors offloaded shares worth around Rs 5,000 crore. DIIs infused over Rs 1,10,000 crore in the same period.

Sectorwise, the BSE Telecom index has tanked the most at 34 per cent since last Budget. The BSE Realty, Metals, Auto, Power, Capital Goods and Oil & Gas indices lost 32 per cent, 30 per cent, 30 per cent, 20 per cent, 17 per cent and 17 per cent, respectively. 

BSE IT, TECk and FMCG indices advanced 19 per cent, 8.28 per cent and 6.37 per cent, respectively.
