IMF lowered GDP growth forecast by 30bps for 2019 based on weak domestic demand outlook which fuelled a sell off in a market where sentiment is already hurt due to tax concerns. Mixed Q1FY20 results, outflow of foreign funds and weakening rupee to weigh on investor sentiments going ahead-Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Service

By Chandan Taparia

NSE Nifty fell for a fifth consecutive session on Wednesday and broke below its crucial support at the 11,300 level. The index formed a bearish candle on the daily scale and drifted towards 11,230 as every bounce was being sold into at higher levels.

The 50-stock pack traded in the 11,230-11350 zone. Immediate structure of the index is weak and till it holds below 11,320, weakness could extend further towards 11,200 and then 11,111. On the upside, hurdle is seen at 11,365 and then 11,400. 

On the options front, maximum Put open interest was at 11,300 followed by 11,200 strike while maximum Call open interest was at 11,400 followed by 11,300 strike.

We have seen Put writing at 11,150 and 11,250 strike while Call writing was seen at 11,300 followed by 11,350 strike. Option data suggests a shift in lower trading range between 11,200 and 11,400 levels.

India VIX fell down up 4.99 per cent to the 12.76.

Nifty Bank continued its weakness for a fifth session and drifted towards 28,871. The index, which made a bearish candle on the daily scale, has been forming lower highs lower lows from the last five sessions. Resistances are gradually shifting lower, and now, till it remains below 29,350, weakness could continue towards next support of 28,888 and then 28,550. On the upside, major hurdle is seen at 29,350 and then 29,500.

Nifty futures closed with a loss of 0.48 per cent at 11,279. Builtup of long position were seen in Asian Paints, HUL and HDFC while shorts were seen in NMDC, Maruti Suzuki, Tata Power, Havells and M&M Finance.


(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at MOFSL. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)

NEW DELHI: Equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty fell for a fifth consecutive session on Wednesday as investors continued their selling spree in Indian equities in the absence of any decisive trigger while concerns over weakening economy and higher tax surcharge seem to have refused to fade away.

"Investors turned sellers on concerns that the economy is moving through a slowdown phase. IMF lowered GDP growth forecast by 30 bps for 2019 based on weak domestic demand outlook, which fuelled a selloff in a market where sentiment is already hurt due to tax concerns," said Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services.

Mixed quarterly results, outflow of foreign funds and weakening rupee will keep weighing on investor sentiment, he added.

Sensex fell 135 points, or 0.36 per cent, to finish at 37,847.65, with only six stocks up and 24 in the red.

Nifty ended the day at 11,271.30, down 60 points or 0.53 per cent. Among the 50 stocks in the index, 12 settled with gains while 38 suffered losses.

In the last five sessions of losses, Sensex has lost 1,368 points or 3.5 per cent, while Nifty has retreated by 416 points or 3.6 per cent.


We bring you the key highlights of Wednesday's session:


Investors lose 6 lakh crore in five daysThe five-day selloff has dragged the cumulative market capitalisation of BSE-listed firms to Rs 1,43,27,797.54 crore from Rs 1,49,13,806.42 crore last Wednesday, making investors poorer by Rs 5.86 lakh crore. 


410 stocks at 52-week lowsAs many as 410 stocks, including Mahindra & Mahindra, Vodafone Idea, Apollo Tyres, Ashok Leyland, Aurobindo Pharma, Eicher Motors, Escorts, JSW Steel, L&T Finance Holdings and TVs Motor Company, hit 52-week lows on BSE. 


Stocks above & below 200-DMAsBPCL, Havells India, Ambuja Cements, Majesco, Mangalam Cement, Grindwell Norton, Syndicate Bank and ABB India were among the stocks that witnessed negative breakouts and traded below 200-DMAs.

On the other hand, Avenue Supermarts, Cholamandalam Financial Holdings, Sasta Sundar Ventures, SIS and Swan Energy were among those stocks that traded above their 200-DMAs.


63 stocks show potential for riseMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 63 counters on BSE, signalling these stocks may witness gains in the coming sessions. Among these stocks were DHFL, Indian Oil Corporation, Balrampur Chini, Nectar Lifesciences, Mauria Udyog and Jyothy Labs. On the other hand, Tata Motors, HPCL, Biocon, Lupin, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Hindalco Industries, UPL and Jubilant Foodworks were among the 59 stocks that showed bearish crossovers.


Jubilant FoodWorks plunges 6%Shares of Jubilant FoodWorks cracked over 5.92 per cent to close at Rs 1,155.95 following June quarter results. The profit figure came in flat at Rs 74.8 crore. Analysts in an ET NOW had estimated a profit of Rs 86 crore. The company said its operating revenues stood at Rs 940.1 crore, up 9.9 per cent. 


Asian Paints extends gainsRising for a third successive day, shares of Asian Paints ended with a gain of 3.42 per cent at Rs 1,477.15 after it posted 17.70 per cent YoY rise in profit at Rs 655.44 crore for the June quarter. In the last three days, the stock has gained 8 per cent.


Zee jumps 5%Shares of Zee Entertainment Enterprises jumped 5.07 per cent to Rs 379.25, a day after the media firm reported a 62.56 per cent rise in profit at Rs 529.76 crore. ICICIdirect maintained ‘Buy’ call on ZEEL with a 12-month target price of Rs 425. “Signing of a binding term sheet for stake sale with one of the bidder is a key positive,” the brokerage house said. 


Mahindra Finance plunges 10%Extending the losses into the sixth straight session, shares of Mahindra & Mahindra Financial Services (Mahindra Finance) plunged 10.52 per cent to Rs 304.35, a day after the company said its profit declined by 75 per cent to Rs 68 crore against Rs 269 crore last year due to increase in provisions for stressed loans and elevated cost of financing owing to tight liquidity conditions for nonbanks. The stock has come off by 21 per cent in the last six sessions.


TaMo falls on Fitch downgradeShares of Tata Motors declined 3.17 per cent to Rs 151.25 after Fitch downgraded the auto major's rating to ‘BB-’ from ‘BB’ with a negative outlook. Fitch cited the automaker’s profitability and free cash generation as reasons for the downgrade, ET NOW reported.


IndiGo shares jump 5%Shares of the aviation firm closed 4.69 per cent higher at Rs 1,594.45 after media reports suggested that the company's Chairman M Damodaran is said to have brokered a truce between co-promoters Rahul Bhatia and Rakesh Gangwal. Sources told ET NOW that Bhatia’s InterGlobe Enterprises group will get to nominate five board seats, including that of CEO’s. Gangwal will have one nomination on board of IndiGo.

The next two quarters you should have a hunting list and just buy good businesses whenever there is a fall in the stock., says Devang Mehta, Head, Equity Advisory, Centrum Wealth Management. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.


The earnings season was kicked off by IT with a bang, particularly on TCS, but midway through, we see That some of the mid-tier banks for are seeing a little bit of pressure. Will pain persist for another couple of quarters? What is your takeaway from the earnings?The pain would probably last for a couple of quarters more. Why I say that is because the earnings were not as bad as people were expecting. It was more or less predicted to be a washout quarter but the numbers did not disappoint the Street though the commentaries are surely disappointing the street. 

Largecap as well as the mid-tier banks have all been talking about a demand slowdown -- right from HDFC Bank to even RBL Bank. The SME sector is slowing down, the problem of credit which has struck the economy since the last seven, eight months, all have been deterrents for the economy and market. Plus, in consumer names, Dabur numbers were excellent, A 9.7% volume growth is an aberration in this type of an environment.

But if you listen to the commentary of this management. there was not much optimism for the next couple of quarters. So yes, there can probably be pain. If you ask me whether it is a blue sky scenario, no. But is it an opportunity in adversity? The answer is yes. The next two quarters you should have a hunting list and just buy good businesses whenever there is a fall in the stock. 


We are expecting some amount of a decline in volumes this time. Even though cement has been looked at favourably lately, in terms of earnings we are expecting to see revenues as well as PAT a little lower for Ambuja. What are your expectations and what is your view on the cement names right now?Clearly we have been quite positive on cement names. A few like UltraTech or Shree Cement has been bought into the portfolios in the last six, nine months. And yes, what a run it has had during this trying times. 

Clearly the budget which laid down a little bit of impetus on infrastructure plus housing for all -- is one segment. Low-cost housing or housing for all which still keeps on growing in an overall pessimistic segment. 

Our sense is that cement demand, cement realisations as well as capacity utilisations in the last couple of quarters has been trending upwards. So, cement probably merits a place in the portfolio. It looks more a cyclical story but for the next three years, it looks to be a structural story. We would probably consider cement with the more frontline names rather than the midcap names.


What about Yes Bank? On the back of the fund raising exercise that they are currently undergoing, there are still some concerns that given the state of the bank, the valuations will completely go out of the window and it might actually be difficult. On the other hand you got news coming in that some of these PE funds are just lining up to be part of that QIP. Would you still buy into a Yes Bank in case they are able to raise those funds or would you be completely averse to the story?We have been avoiding accidents at this point of time because as I said, quality has commended some premium in the market. I would not be able to comment on individual stocks but the sense here is that when your largecaps or market leaders also start to fall, buy the market leaders. If these stocks are too expensive, buy the next big one. If you feel that Asian Paints is costly, and that there are companies like Berger Paints, go in for Asian Paints and Berger Paints. We tend to remain with a couple of more market leaders rather than going into the space where we feel there will be difficulties in terms of not only losing market share but also losing business while you get into your balance sheet issues and sort those out.


Just when the sector dynamics were beginning to look up for telecom and most of these companies were beginning to deleverage, and the Street was also turning pretty bullish in the prospects of Bharti Airtel. Now comes this dampener in the form of big fines on Airtel and Idea Vodafone.We remain very cautious on this sector. In fact, we have not bought this sector in the last two-three years. My sense is though the debt equation was getting lower and the market was divided into three companies which are ruling the roost, it is still a crowded trade. Lots of people buy it as a contra trade but we would still avoid it. As you said, there are lots of such issues which can creep up and whenever the auction comes up, debt issues will come to the fore. Avoid this sector. There is so much of fall happening in the broader markets. The best stocks have started falling in the last 8-10 days. There are better opportunities to be in this type of businesses rather than being in the telecom sector at this point. 


Canara Bank and quite a few other banks have come out with numbers. Today it is the turn of Bank of Baroda. We can’t compare the numbers to last year’s because of the overall merger, but what is it that you are expecting?The earnings growth of a lot of these banks would be fair and watched into. In the last couple of quarters, there have been a lot of recoveries. The NPA has come down for a lot of PSU and corporate banks as well and the mettle of taking the earnings growth of Nifty or Sensex of the benchmark indices has been more or less done by all these banks. 

I think there would be a recovery at least in terms of sentiment for a lot of these banks. Probably PSU banks would not be in the hunting list but there seems to be enough evidence that with interest rates heading downwards, with inflation also trending down and probably a little bit of a boost or sentiment booster from the government or from the RBI would go a long way in giving the banks that extra zig. 
I can say that the BFSI sector which has been the darling of the market before the big fall, could continue and banks again probably could lead the rise whenever it starts.

In the current environment it is difficult to expect very aggressive infusion of funds in PSU banks by the government, says Hemang Jani, Senior Vice President, Sharekhan. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.

In an interview with The Economic Times, Aditya Puri seems to be saying that the worst of the NBFC crisis over and the doom is over,we can only move up from here. Do you agree?In the selloff that we have seen in the last couple of months, most of the sector and stocks are affected and yes we have been debating about the intensity of the slowdown and whether the worst is over or not. But looking at the ground level situation, it would be a bit early to decide that the worst is over because in the current environment there is a confidence issue and at the ground level, businesses are not looking up. People are in a cost control mode and it may so happen that the stock prices bottom out before the actual businesses bottom out. 

As far as NBFC sector is concerned, I do not think the worst is over because there are a lot of NBFCs where the provisioning has not been 80-90% and only over the next couple of quarters, will we get some clarity on that. I would stay cautious on NBFCs.


What are you making of these earnings in paints businesses and what is your view on Asian Paints in that light because even though some brokerages are still citing weak outlook, perhaps the worst is over Asian Paints as it has been steadily performing?If we look at the quarterly numbers, a very few companies have really surprised in terms of volume growth and overall outlook because even in companies in the FMCG or consumer discretionary space, we have hardly seen better than expected growth and the management outlook remains quite muted. So Asian Paints definitely stands out though the last two or three quarters were a bit muted on a YoY basis. On a muted base, the performance may look good but a 16% volume growth in the current environment is commendable by any standards. 

Also, on the EBITDA front, there has been a fair degree of margin stability and the company has been consistently gaining market share. So, there are very few companies which are displaying this. I do not think there is a broad trend and one should be a little selective and cautious rather than feeling that Asian Paints has reported good numbers, so there is no slowdown. I definitely think that one needs to be selective.


How are you looking at expectations for Tata Motors in trade? We were discussing it just a short while ago saying that be it the JLR kind of concerns that we have seen in China or across the globe, it is definitely been a slowdown. We are not going in with very high expectations. Just yesterday there was a second downgrade coming in for Tata Motors. Is that already baked into the price or is there going to be some further deceleration in the stock?Tata Motors has been a laggard and given the slowdown that we have witnessed in the global markets for the JLR products, even the automotive sector overall is not really showing any kind of an improvement. Plus JLR has its own set of issues -- be it US markets or UK or China for that matter. The expectations will continue to be muted for Tata Motors and in the current environment, one should not really take an aggressive positioning just because the stock has corrected. It may remain thus for an extended period of time. We have a neutral view on Tata Motors given the uncertainty around growth, currency risk and the fact that even the domestic market the CV cycle part because of the slowdown that we are seeing is going to take a while to reflect in the numbers. Definitely stay away from Tata Motors at this point of time. 


The Bajaj Finance management commentary on what they see ahead is going to be critical. What would you be looking out for?The numbers are going to be good as you said. We are looking at about 45%-46% kind of a growth but more importantly, given the high expectations that the market is working with in terms of the AUM growth and in terms of the overall NII and profitability growth. Is there any kind of an indication from the management about a lower growth given the slowdown and given the fact that the digital component of the overall business Bajaj Finance is facing some competition where HDFC Bank and some of the other banks are gaining market share. 

In the wake of that, market would be watching whether we are looking at a lower growth than 40% or 35%. We have been liking Bajaj Finance. It has corrected and may be a part of the upside that we had seen in earlier was because HDB Financials was to be listed and there is going to be some sort of a comparison between Bajaj Finance and HDB Financials. A part of this correction is also because of that but I definitely think that a serious correction in Bajaj Finance in the range of Rs 3,000 or thereabouts would present a great opportunity for investors.


Some of the PSU banks have continued to see pressure. We have not necessarily seen an alleviation of those NPA woes yet, even if they have stalled for the moment?We have seen decent bounce back in PSUs, particularly in State Bank of India. But if you look at the overall scenario, from a lower base after providing for a lot of NPLs, we are not really seeing any positive traction when it comes to pre-provisioning profits or the loan growth.

In the current environment to expect that there is going to be a very aggressive infusion by the government is also looking quite difficult. so in that environment we are not very positive on BoB. We are looking at a 15% kind of a growth in the net interest income but a sharp cut in the net profit on a quarter on quarter basis from 52 odd crore to almost about 8.8 crore. So overall numbers wise things are not looking too great so we are not recommending buying into the PSU banks per se. State Bank of India has remained quite good so selectively one can definitely look at buying into it but otherwise stay away from the PSU stocks.

Global as well as domestic brokerage firms maintained their bullish view on Asian Paints after the company reported a 17.90 per cent increase in consolidated net profit at Rs 672.09 crore for the first quarter ended June 30, 2019.

It had posted a net profit of Rs 570.02 crore in the year-ago period.

Morgan Stanley maintained ‘Overweight’ on Asian Paints with a target price of Rs 1,600 per share, while Macquarie retained ‘Outperform’ call with a target price of Rs 1,530.

Macquarie said that the management has indicated channel stocking led by innovative schemes. The foreign financial firm marginally raised EPS by 4.5-5 per cent for FY20-21 and expects Asian Paints to remain aggressive in channel push. 

The scrip was, however, trading 0.45 per cent down at Rs 1,476 at around 9.52 am (IST), while the benchmark BSE Sensex was up 286 points, or 0.75 per cent, at 38,133 at around the same time.

According to Edelweiss Securities, Asian Paints (APL) reported higher-than-expected financial results for Q1FY20. A double-digit volume spurt too came in ahead of estimates in spite of the high base of 12.5 per cent YoY. 

The brokerage house maintains ‘Buy’ on Asian Paints with a target price of Rs 1,649, indicating an upside of nearly 12 per cent from current market price.

“We believe the product mix has slightly improved QoQ—a healthy sign. Benign raw material costs led to gross margin expansion of 198bps QoQ. Cost control managed to offset the initial factory set-up costs, leading to comparable EBITDA margin expansion of 136bps YoY. We continue to estimate double-digit volume growth in the decorative business as well as margin expansion (operating leverage benefit in new plants). Capacity expansion of 600,000KL bodes well for revenue growth,” Edelweiss said in a report.

While the market is volatile, there are pockets of opportunities in the mid and smallcap segments. This would be the time to invest in good quality companies with a two to three year time horizon, says Shibani Sircar Kurian, SVP & Head-Equity Research, Kotak Mahindra AMC. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.


We have kick-started the first quarter earnings season and while a lot of the market direction was received from the earnings cues, the market once again shifted the focus to the budget announcements over the surcharge for FPIs, the auto slowdown, the entire FII sell off as well. July has seen a lot of FII selling off. Do you believe that would gain prominence as opposed to quarterly numbers and fundamentals?The budget caused its own volatility but now the market has clearly shifted focus to earnings. From an earnings perspective, it is a slightly challenging quarter, given the kind of growth and demand outlook that we are facing at this point in time. 

If you look at it for a year as a whole, we still believe that we are fairly on track to report mid teens earnings growth and therefore coming off almost three years of no earnings growth. This would possibly be a year where you start seeing better earnings growth trajectory. 

However, it has been a mixed bag across sectors. There have been some good ones, some bad ones and some earnings downgrades as well, but clearly the market is focused now on fundamentals and how things move from here on. The earnings growth and the earnings trajectory and the numbers to come will play a key role in determining the future course of action that the market really takes from here.


 HDFC Bank has been a very stable company. Quarter after quarter it has given inline set of numbers with very few red flags. Would you believe that is the case in this quarter as well?While I cannot talk specifically on a company, I can give you our understanding of how the consumer retail lending space and how the private sector banking space is really panning out. 

While there has been some moderation in terms of loan growth for the banks that have really reported numbers, the market share shift from the public sector to the private sector or even from the NBFCs to the private sector is continuing. The banks which have reported numbers are clearly growing at a pace faster than the industry and so that is one. 

Secondly, while management commentary has flagged off some risks specifically on the consumer lending side or the unsecured consumer book, the agri book clearly has not led to a significant rise in terms of credit cost as of now. What we are seeing is precautionary in terms of the management commentary and therefore may be higher provisioning in some cases. Having said that, the private sector banking pack as a whole shows clear opportunities here because of two things -- the shift in market share between loans and deposits from one segment of the banking space to the private sector banking space is still continuing. 

These banks are well capitalised and therefore in this kind of a scenario where there are concerns on liquidity, capital is the key and clearly from a balance sheet perspective, these banks are still reporting return ratios which are fairly healthy and these return ratios have not really been impaired in a big way. 

Also one pocket of opportunity that we see here is that a lot of the private sector corporate banks went through a lot of stress over the last three-four years, given their exposure to some of the large corporates. 

However, over the last few years, there have been changes in terms of risk management practices and our belief is as you go into the second half of the year, you will see credit cost starting to normalise and that leading to improvement in terms of their return ratios. While there are certain pockets of concern on the banking and financial services space, specifically on the NBFC and the HFC side, there are still pockets of opportunity within that sector.


United Spirits and Asian Paints results are out. For all means and purposes, these could be considered consumer facing B2C companies. Do you believe it is not done as badly as one would have feared?I would tend to agree with you that while volume growth has come off, but clearly we have been seeing very high volume growth and in this kind of an environment, it was expected that there would be some deceleration and that has really panned out. 

Plus the margins have been positive. Clearly, there is some pricing power and costs have been under control. All of this has led to a better margin profile. The issue with the consumption space is a two-fold one. Commentary on demand still continues to remain slightly muted and valuations are stretched. 

We are approaching the consumption sector in a stock-specific manner. Clearly, there are opportunities in this space where we are see growth continuing as well as valuations being reasonable. Some of these names are clearly featuring in our portfolios but it is a little stock specific, given the fact that valuations are stretched in pockets.


Do you believe that it is the China factor that is the niggling factor for Tata Motors?Again without getting into stock-specific names, our view on auto has been cautious now for a while. We believe there are three-four factors which are contributing to the downturn. One of course is there has been a demand slowdown. Two, There is a rural slowdown given the fact that rural income have not been growing. 

Thirdly the cost of ownership of vehicle has clearly gone up and regulatory changes are resulting in that cost going up further. 

Fourthly, there is this issue of shared mobility and how much impact that is having on demand. The key question is to discuss whether this is a cyclical slowdown in autos that we are seeing or whether this is a slightly more structural slowdown. The answer is still very unclear and as a result of which we are still watching out and are cautious on the segment. 

A few key leading indicators that we will keep in mind while we are approaching the segment is a)to see how discounts are panning out and if there are signs of discounts coming off which means demand is coming back. 

Secondly, inventory levels in the system are still very high and if that starts to moderate again, then there are indicators that demand is coming back but at this point in time, it does look like we could be in for a few more months of weakness. We are still cautious on the sector.


For investors with a longer term time horizon, which sectors should they look at? What looks good from a fundamental perspective?We find that there is a significant amount of opportunity to buy stocks in the mid and smallcap segments. One has to be selective but since the beginning of 2018 till now, the correction in the mid and smallcap space has been very severe and sharp and in fact today the valuations of the midcaps are trading at lower levels than what it was even in 2014. 

As a result, this is possibly an opportune time to look at high quality, high growth midcap stocks with a two to three year kind of a time horizon. However, one has to be very careful when you are doing stock picking clearly look at companies which are growing, which are gaining market share which have cleaned balance sheet and low leverage and which are able to generate high return ratios. However, there are a lot of opportunities. Some of the sectors that we like one is on the capital goods side. Capacity utilisation levels have been inching up and now are close to long- term averages. 

If you look at data in terms of order flows as well, there has been a pick up. While this is not private sector greenfield capex, but clearly capacity augmentation has resulted in order flow improvement which is resulting in some positive up move specifically with the capital goods space so that is one segment that we are watching out for. 

A proxy for capital goods is cement where clearly realisations have been positive. We need to see whether this trend of improved pricing power stays or the kind of price decline that we have seen in the recent past continues or whether the cement companies get back on track and the volume growth also holds up. But cement is a space that we like. 

On the financial side we are positive on the private sector corporate banks where there are clear signs of normalisation of return ratios as well as credit cost which will lead to better profitability and another segment that we like is on the life insurance space where we have clearly seen a trend where there is improvement in terms of growth of new business as well as margins because of the changing mix of the product profile where companies moving more towards protection and annuities which are higher margin products resulting in better profitability. 

While the market is volatile, clearly there are pockets of opportunities specifically in the mid and the smallcap segments. If one is careful and buys good quality companies this would be the time to invest with a two to three year kind of a time horizon.

We would be more bullish on slightly larger cap companies like HCL Tech, Infosys, Mphasis as well. The scale and size would be a kind of a differentiator in this particular kind of an environment, says Abhimanyu Sofat, VP-Research, IIFL. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.


ICICI Bank results were out on Saturday. Other than that, we have been tracking a whole host of names in the broader market that has seen some buying interest like Torrent Pharma, SPARC, IGL. What is going to be on your radar?Broadly ICICI Bank numbers, on the asset quality side, are well in line with expectations. Going forward, ICICI should continue to do pretty well in terms of what could be the upside in the stock. We believe it could go to a level of around Rs 490 odd from current level, giving a 1.8 time price to book to the core earnings as well as adding up subsidy valuations at a 20% discount. 

However, one concern that one sees in their result is that a lot of delinquencies seems to be happening in the Kisan Credit Card. The retail bad loans number has gone from 1.1% to 2%. Looking at the numbers that have come from Maruti or Bajaj Auto or even Havells, it seems to me that the rural seems to be slowing down quite drastically over the last couple of months. That is a big worry of concern with regard to slowdown going forward. 

As far as the broader market is concerned, clearly stocks like Torrent Pharma which you talked about are quite decent, despite some one-off challenges that the company has faced recently. We continue to remain quite positive on that and still believe that from here, you can get a 20% upside in case of Torrent Pharma because if you look at how they have done the Unichem acquisition or grown their domestic business, clearly there is a significant growth opportunity, especially in FY21 for the company.


What is your view on midcap IT companies? Could rising cost as well the slowdown in BFSI be a point of concern for some of the midcap IT companies?Yes, absolutely. Be it Cyient or Persistent, clearly there have been challenges in terms of how growth is going to come going forward. The annual contract value for the overall industry for this year is expected to come down to around 5% growth. We would be more bullish on slightly larger cap companies like HCL Tech, Infosys, Mphasis as well. The scale and size would be a kind of a differentiator in this particular kind of an environment. Most of the companies are transforming on a digital side but on the core earnings side, in core portfolios, we clearly see some headwinds for the sector and for that reason it make sense to be with some of these companies where growth continues to be quite decent.


The Finance Minister has said in an interview with ET that she did not see it as a liquidity crisis as such, but more a problem of lack of lending to legit or correct customers, alluding to the fact that there is a hesitancy to lend. What do you make of some of these comments that came in over the weekend?For sure, if the finance minister does meet these FPIs and gives a way out for them because changing from a trust to corporate structure is not that easy for all of them. One should remember that some of these guys have multi-country operations and for them to do certain changes just to invest in a particular market, is quite tough to do. 

If there are some changes, I am sure it will be welcomed by the market and what they have said over the weekend should be taken positively. With regard to funding, clearly there is some improvement in the system with regard to NBFCs as well. 

The challenge is that overall, in which market should one invest? Today banks have an issue with regard to CASA. Most of them are dependent on term deposits. The kind of NIM expansion which should have happened for banks is clearly not happening and the overall system where the velocity of money seems to have drastically come down because there is hardly any movement of money from one instrument to another. 

Overall if the finance minister does do that change and we do see significant cutting of interest rates going forward because our real interest rates are significantly higher than what the world is at. We are at more than 40% negative interest rate globally. If there is that change in terms of monetary policy as well as financial policy with regard to lower taxation, market recovery is bound to happen because there is money sitting on the sidelines waiting to be invested. It just needs some kind of sentimental booster from the market.


Asian Paints saw some great movement last week on the back of continued delivery on earnings. What is your view on Asian Paints currently?Asian Paints was one of the few companies which clearly is telling the markets that despite the kind of slowdown that most of the other guys are talking, they have not witnessed any major slowdown in terms of volume growth. Going forward, we believe Asian Paints will continue to get these premium valuations. If you want to look at some other stock which is slightly less expensive than Asian Paints, Berger Paint could be an interesting buy. 

The earnings there is expected to grow at around 18% CAGR, at a multiple of around 44 or so, which from a traditional mindset is obviously high but considering that it is better to look at margin of safety in the market at this particular juncture, Berger Paint should also do well and overall the commodity price is also a quite benign for the sector. We are quite hopeful for the paint sector, especially companies like Berger Paints and Asian Paints.

NEW DELHI: Friday’s gains in equities proved to be shortlived as equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty on Monday resumed their downward movement, falling up to 0.84 per cent.

Weak Asian markets combined with continuous outflow of foreign funds weighed on investor sentiment. “The market started the week on the feeble note and lost nearly one per cent. Weak Asian markets combined with continuous outflow of the foreign funds are weighing on sentiment. The market is largely focusing on weak domestic sentiment while global cues remain mixed,” said Ajit Mishra, VP-Research, Religare Broking.

Investors stayed away from riskier equities, awaiting anxiously for the Fed outcome on Wednesday. Uninspiring earnings and lack of positive triggers continued to keep risk appetite low. 

Here is a breakdown of the key highlights of Monday's session. Take a look:


400 stocks plumb 52-week lowsAs many as 405 stocks, including Bajaj Auto, Tata Steel, Tata Motors, Maruti Suzuki India, Hero MotoCorp, Ashok Leyland and EID Parry (India), plumb 52-week lows on BSE. On the other hand, Asian Paints, Adhunik Industries, Banas Finance, Kratos Energy & Infrastructure, Mac Hotels and Procter & Gamble Health were among the 26 stocks that hit 52-week highs.


Upper & lower circuitsIndiabulls Integrated Services, Cox & Kings, Unitech, Essar Shipping, 5paisa Capital and SORIL Infra Resources were among the 242 stocks that hit their lower circuits. On the other hand, 118 stocks, including Jubilant Industries, Astec Lifesciences, Mangalam Drugs & Organics, 63 Moons Technologies, Electrotherm (India), HOV Services and Manaksia Steels, hit upper circuits.


Rs 1.36 lakh crore gone in a dayMonday's losses in equities dragged the overall market capitalisation of BSE-listed firms to Rs 1,42,45,433.92 crore from Rs 1,43,82,243.21 crore on Friday, making investors poorer by Rs 1.36 lakh crore in a single day!


Above & below 200-DMAsLarsen & Toubro, NTPC, Voltamp Transformers, NIIT Technologies, Mahindra Lifespace Developers, India Cements, Bank of Maharashtra, Adani Transmission and Max Financial Services were among the stocks that witnessed negative breakouts and traded below their 200-DMAs. However, JSW Energy, Grindwell Norto and Jubilant Industries were among those who traded above 200-DMAs.


74 stocks show potential for riseMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 74 counters on BSE, signalling these stocks may witness gains in the coming sessions. Among those stocks were Suzlon Energy, TCS, Mindtree, GHCL, HCL Technologies, Deepak Fertilisers, Binani Industries and Varun Beverages. On the other hand, Vedanta, HDFC Life Insurance, Power Grid Corporation, Ambuja Cements, Hindustan Unilever and PVR were among the 56 stocks that showed bearish crossovers.


140 stocks now oversold Momentum oscillator Relative Strength Index, or RSI, showed 140 stocks, including Ballarpur Industries, Vodafone Idea, Tejas Networks, RBL Bank, HCC, Marksans Pharma and Tata Elxsi, in the oversold zone on BSE. On the other hand, VR Films & Studios, Goenka Business, Yashraj Containeurs, EIS and Mandhana Industries were among the 18 stocks that entered the overbought zone.


Auto top sectoral loserBSE Auto, with a loss of 3.55 per cent, finished as the top loser among the sectoral indices on BSE after the government proposed to hike registration cost on new vehicles. The index ended with all components in the red, with Tata Motors (down 6.52 per cent), Apollo Tyres (down 6 per cent), Bajaj Auto (down 4.99 per cent), Eicher Motors (down 4.81 per cent) and Motherson Sumi Systems (down 4.34 per cent) as the top losers. Maruti's poor Q1 numbers also aggravated a selloff in shares of auto companies which have been grappling to cope with a slump in demand in the wake of liquidity crunch in the financial space, weak monsoon and changes in emission and safety norms. 


Vodafone Idea plunges 27%Shares of Vodafone Idea plunged 26.81 per cent to close the day at Rs 6.77 after weak results for the fiscal first quarter, which prompted analysts to fear that the telco could rapidly be relegated to a regional player if it fails to grow revenue in the coming quarters. 


Maruti shares down 4%Shares of Maruti Suzuki closed 4.26 per cent down at Rs 5,558.05 today. India’s largest carmaker on Friday reported a 27.3 per cent year-on-year (YoY) drop in net profit at Rs 1,435.50 crore for June quarter on weak volumes and higher depreciation expenses. While the company’s slump in profit was broadly on the expected lines, projected near-term pressure on volumes and demand has prompted analysts to turn cautious on the stock. 


ICICI Bank climbs 3%Shares of ICICI Bank ended 3.32 per cent higher at Rs 429.30 after the lender’s June quarter earnings impressed investors on Dalal Street. Brokerages say the scrip has potential to rally 25-50 per cent in next one year, as incremental stress at the second-largest private bank moderates with the shrinkage of the pool of low-rated corporate exposure. 


DRL declines ahead of earningsShares of Dr Reddy’s Laboratories (DRL) closed 1.92 per cent down at Rs 2,652.55 ahead of its June quarter numbers. Post the market hours, the company said its consolidated profit after tax (PAT) for the June quarter climbed 45 per cent on year-on-year (YoY) basis to Rs 662.80 crore compared with Rs 456.10 crore in the same quarter last year. On a sequential basis, the profit surged 53 per cent.

I do not see Sebi planning to put a cap on broker fees in PMS and AIF as a negative because the pricing and the disclosure in some of the products is not necessarily the best in terms of practices. That may be good for the industry, says Hemang Jani, Senior Vice President, Sharekhan. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.

We are already grappling with the consistent sell-off from the FPI fraternity right after the budget. Now it seems the regulator may be tightening its noose on PMS as well as AIFs. It appears to be bad news overall for the markets. There does not seem to be any glimmer of hope anywhere in sight?I agree with the first part that there has been relentless selling by the FIIs and FPIs and as a result, we have seen a huge underperformance by the Indian market the whole of the year and more so after the budget. But the fact that the regulator is looking at some kind of norms or the current practices being followed by the participants in the PMS or the other structures which are available in the market, is not necessarily bad news. 

We have seen time and again that for mutual funds and for any other products in the market. It is the job of the regulator to look at the practices and take the feedback and put in place a mechanism which is in the interest of the investors. I do not necessarily see that as a negative because the pricing and the disclosure in some of the products is not necessarily the best in terms of practices. So, that may be good for the industry. I do not think we should read too much negative into it.


Would FIIs still think midcaps are expensive? Back home, everyone is hunting for value and are yet incredibly risk averse. Where would you be looking at in the midcap universe?Some of the small companies in the cement space definitely look interesting because that space is looking pretty good, particularly in terms of pricing and the fact that you will have some kind of an improvement post monsoon in terms of dispatches. 

JK Lakshmi and Ramco Cement are some of the stocks that one can really look at because there is a lot of uncertainty about earnings in many sectors and there are a few sectors like cement or may be some of the private sector banks and may be a couple of consumption names like HUL where the volume growth was about 5% odd in the most challenging environment and of course Asian Paints. 

The companies which are performing in this environment are the ones the investors should bet on versus the companies where the prices have corrected but one is really not sure about the business and where the debt levels are pretty high.


Apart from Axis Bank, Tech Mahindra is also slated to come out with its numbers today, What kind of commentary are you expecting and how have you read into the kind of Q1 report card that we have seen so far from the IT majors?Typically, this is a subdued quarter for the IT companies in general and in Tech Mahindra, we have seen that the guidance which they had given, both for telecom as well as enterprise solution, was not good. They had tweaked the enterprise business part a bit and the sense that we are getting is that in terms of revenue there could be a 1% dip there. Even the margins could dip by about 160 bps. Typically, Tech Mahindra margins have been relatively lower compared to the general IT services industry. So, net-net, in terms of expectations, they are pretty muted.

The only thing that people would be watching out for is whether there is going to be any kind of a clarity or colour in terms of the overall growth in the telecom space that one is really looking at and what kind of margins can one expect on a sustainable basis. Though in terms of valuation, the stock looks pretty attractive but in terms of growth, the performance may remain muted.


How you are approaching the telecom space? Is it Bharti versus Idea or it is an avoid for both?Overall, things are looking quite tough for the incumbent telecom companies as the operating performance has been extremely weak with high debt levels. More importantly, for any capex they need to do -- whether 5G or for the normal -- it is going to be quite tough. We have been liking Bharti for the fact that now that Rel Jio is already there and that entire competitive intensity is likely to come off.

You might see a bit of price stability but that is taking a while. Our sense is that if you have a one or two year kind of view, Bharti appears to be much better in terms of the balance sheet strength and the overall operating performance that they have. Idea definitely we would avoid at this point of time and more importantly if you see the actual performances in terms of call drops, etc, the network issues that are there it is pathetic in terms of servicing. It would take a while for the telecom companies to show up in terms of better investor sentiment.


 The preferred bets within real estate are Mumbai specific plays like Godrej Properties or Oberoi Realty. At a time when you are seeing real estate in doldrums and it seems that the pain is going to last for some more time to come, is this a good time to buy into DLF? They seem to be ahead of the curve when it comes to deleveraging their balance sheet?I agree on the deleveraging part. DLF has taken some steps and given the fact that the commercial side of the business, the lease rentals, have been good and we had some kind of deals where REITs were launched. These are the positives for DLF but given the overall environment that we have in our economy today, though interest rates are falling, the appetite to buy more into real estate is still not there.

For DLF, on the enterprise level and at the company level, the debt is still pretty high. Unless we see some kind of stability in the residential part of the business, it would be hard to make out a case for buying into a stock like DLF. Yes, because of the lower interest rates, if somebody wants to buy some of the real estate players, maybe some of the better ones like Godrej, etc, one can really look at it but overall we would definitely stay away from the sector for a while.


Would there be any concerns you have on the fundamentals of the Grasim stock apart from the fact that we have seen that rub off price drop yesterday.The structure of Grasim is such that, there is UltraTech and more importantly the remainder of the Idea stake. That could become a pain point for Grasim and the rest of their other commodity businesses like sponge iron and a couple of chemical businesses. 

I do not think there is too much of an issue. But because of the holding company nature and the investment that they have in the telecom, there is some kind of an issue going on in terms of the derating. That could have led to a weakness. On an overall basis, Grasim continues to look quite okay because the UltraTech part of the business where they have significant stake is shaping up well and the other businesses are also quite stable. I continue to have a positive bias on Grasim. Yesterday’s selloff could be either technical or with respect to their stake in the Idea I think.


What you are expecting from Axis Bank’s numbers this time around?In terms of the numbers, the loan growth could be in the range of about 15% to 16%. The key moniterables for Axis Bank could be the slippages because last time around the slippages were somewhere in the range of about Rs 3,000 crore on a total watch list of about Rs 9,500-10,000 crore. The sense that we are getting is that the slippages could be somewhere in that range about Rs 2,800-3,500 crore. 

Fillers that we are getting is that the gross NPL in terms of percentage could be a bit higher versus the last quarter at about Rs 5.7-5.8 crore. So there might be a bit of a negative surprise in terms of the slippages and gross NPL. The loan growth part should be okay and there might be a bit of a negative reaction when these numbers are announced by Axis Bank. Within the banking space, ICICI Bank definitely stands out vis-à-vis some of the other banks.


 What about Dr Reddy’s? How do you read into the kind of quarter that the company has delivered and the kind of management commentary that has come about?The numbers appear definitely subdued. The fact that some of their key products have got pushed into 2020 again because of some regulatory issues is not great news. The only positive takeaway could be that the generic business in the US is stabilising and there was a bit of a growth over there but the rest of the markets -- be it India or some of the other markets there -- has not been that great outcome as far as the Dr Reddy is concerned.

It would take time for some of these companies to come out with a stronger set of numbers given the environment that we are into both India and other markets. Within the pharma space, we like Divi’s Lab and Cipla because performance wise, these two companies are better placed.


What do you think about Zee in light of the fact that a deal could be imminent any time now and earnings this time are pretty much intact as well?It remains to be seen what kind of structure they are looking at and what kind of valuation they are going to get for the overall broadcasting part of the business that they have. The quarterly numbers for Zee have been quite good, particularly on the subscription side of it. One would really want to know what kind of overall structure they are looking at because both on the broadcasting and on the digital part of it, some clarity is required in terms of the thought process and plan that they have. 

Also one of the reasons why Zee was under tremendous pressure was that the debt level at the enterprise level was somewhere in the range of about Rs 13,000 odd crore. Post this deal, what kind of repayment are they looking at and what kind of debt level would they be comfortable with in the balance sheet is something that one would be watching out for. We also hear that for some of the group companies where Zee has a stake, there could be some kind of deal involving those also. So, that is something that could bring about some kind of some of parts valuation aspect for Zee. 

Overall, Zee remains quite interesting at this point of time because just a couple of days are left in terms of the announcement that the management made. So, depending upon the deal there might be some action in Zee at this point of time.

The underlying economy is still quite strong and the double digit growth rates will come back very soon -- if not in the current quarter, definitely in the next two quarters, says Dilip Piramal, Chairman, VIP Industries. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.


You have seen a strong double digit growth for eight quarters. You revenue growth is seeing a little bit of a struggle. What are some of the factors that are putting pressure on growth currently?There is no doubt that the Indian economy has slowed down in the last quarter of 2018-19 and there was an impact on sales. In fact, if I compare our sales growth to many other companies, which have just announced their results, we are doing quite good and that is the response we got from our stock analysts meet yesterday. So we are quite satisfied. We have had a good quarter looking at the circumstances and growth has come down. But the underlying economy is still quite strong and the double digit growth rates will come back very soon -- if not in the current quarter, definitely in the next two quarters. I am quite optimistic.


What is your volume growth at this time and how much is it that you are pencilling in for the future ahead? Can you cross the volume growth that you have been clocking till now and can you maintain those kind of growth levels for FY20?We have had 7% volume growth as against 9% value growth. In the same period last year, we had more than 25% sales and volume growth. I am optimistic but it is very difficult to forecast what has happened because the variances have been quite large, from 25% we have come down to 9%. So let us see.


Analysts say the product mix has been hurting you. Has there been a change there? What is the growth seen in entry level brands versus that seen in higher end products?We had some very severe competition last year in the product mix, especially at the lower level because some of the players had not fully entered that market. Our smaller player, Safari, is mainly in the economy segment but the other players were not there and they had made a strong presence there. So there was intense competition but the product mix is very healthy. 

In fact, we have a terrific product mix because we have four brands from Carlton, Skybags, VIP and Aristocrat and all our brands are doing quite well. In fact, that product mix is our strength. Our new products have been very well received and they have been well priced also. That is why our margins have come back now to last year’s levels. On the whole we are quite satisfied.


What is the scenario on the input cost front? Is there any pressure there on raw material prices? No, not really, because China buying has been very good. China is under great pressure from the US and so we are in a position to negotiate better rates. The rupee is also much stronger as compared to the 73 and 74 rupees a dollar we were looking at about six months ago. Now it has come down to less than Rs 69. So, we have relief on both the rupee dollar rate as well as on the actual buying prices from China. 

Our sourcing both in India and in Bangladesh also is quite good. There is not much pressure from cost at the moment. It was so in October-December last year but things are much better now.


 Could you elaborate a little on that? Have you managed to normalise the excess inventory imported from China and what is your current inventory level?
Our inventory levels are still quite high but we are regulating that and in the next two quarters, we will get back to normal. They had gone up quite substantially in March, when we have our peak inventory because April to June is our largest quarter and this ordering in China has to be done in October and the slowdown came after that, from January. From January to June, the sales were not growing at that 25% rate of growth. Inventories have been a bit high but by December, they should come back to normal levels.


With the increase in competition, has the price hike that you took in Q4 impacted demand? What about your outlook on your market share?There is no increase in competition. There are three big players and our market share is slightly above 50%. 


What can we expect from VIP going forward? What is the outlook for FY20?The main thing is at what rate should we grow because our growth margins are quite high. The higher the rate of growth, the better the impact on the profits. It is very difficult at this time to predict exactly how the rate of growth will be. We have had 9% in the first quarter which is quite good because many leading companies except for Asian Paints, all the results which have been announced, have been around 5%. The automobile industry has had negative growth. In that background, we have done well but it is very difficult to forecast whether we will have 20% growth or 15% or 10%. We just have to wait and see.

There has been a capitulation of the market and I am not sure whether this is a factor, but I think psychologically investors are giving up, says
 Ajay Srivastava, CEO, 
Dimensions Corporate. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.


We are attributing the downfall to a number of factors, but what do you think is spooking the markets the most?It is a simple equation of when a demand slowdown of this magnitude takes place and still there are negative policy disruptions like the EV policy, then obviously hope is lost, firstly because of the demand slowdown. Second is an active policy framework to address it. When the market finds that instead of a positive framework, it is negative, then you give up hope. What basically is happening now is people are giving up hope. So far we were trading with hope of lots of things going to happen and so on. But we have reached a point where people are just giving up. It is a capitulation of the market and I am not sure whether this is a factor, but I think psychologically investors are giving up. 


Each company we talk to, seems clueless about when and how this economic recovery is going to play out. Do you think it is going to be pretty much the state of the market as well? Is the pain going to be longer lasting and are we not going to stop sub-11K mark for the Nifty?Actually that is why I said that in the policy framework we see today, we do not understand that instead of a supportive policy, it is all negative. Look at the NHB guidelines of the subvention schemes that came out of the blue in a real estate market which is crying for attention. I do not blame the industrialists. They do not know what is happening. But I can tell you one thing. Investors know what is happening and they are voting with their demat statements. They are voting with their sells right now. They are voting with the short. Investors are very clear. 

Even industrialists are not that clear because perhaps they want to be polite and cannot be negative about their companies too much. But the fact remains that we are looking for a much-much bigger slowdown and impact that will ultimately come on to the banks. The bank lending and recovering will very soon become a problem area. If you cannot sell, how do you pay the loan? As simple as that. There needs to be a very strong policy between RBI and the government. And everybody has to come out and stop negative policy formation -- NHB, EV, etc. It just has to stop before you can get some confidence back in the system. Having said that, let me go to the other side of the argument. Lots of very good companies are now going very cheap. If you are not an investor, if you have never been in the market, if you have not seen mayhem in your equity accounts, I think you have got to be ready with a cheque book to buy some very good stocks that are now available in the market. I think you are reaching a point where if you are not over invested in the market, you could be on the buying side in a matter of days.


The list is so selective. Just day before you had ICICI Bank which impressed the street, but the twin Axis that everyone was betting on has actually disappointed with higher provisioning and slippages.At some point you have got to relate the value and the price of the shares to what intrinsically is going to be the worst case scenario for these companies. You are right, they may face pain over a certain period of time. But at the end of the day if you are looking at a longer-term horizon, they will bounce back. The good part is that the reason they will come in is not because they are doing well. The good part is that they will come in because the smaller banks will be left far behind. If you are an investor and if you have got any small bank in your portfolio, except unless backed by somebody serious, I would say you need to get out of it and get into the larger banks. 

If you have got the problems today with the smaller portfolio, get out. There is a lot of good quality stuff available in the market. Even in this market there are pockets you can buy. I will just give you an example, I am not giving you a recommendation to buy or sell. If you see Ion Exchange for instance, that is a quality stock in a quality industry. It is seeing so much trade now that you can get an opportunity to get into that at 610 if you want to sell at 680, or you get in at 680 wait it out and so on. Go case by case. It is going to be mayhem, but you will find pockets if you look at the multiplex guys. They have corrected substantially. Eventually there will be equilibrium in terms of share price and profitability. So plan your portfolio. These are the times when you really plan your portfolios and buy what you like most. Having said that nothing great will happen in the next three months, but also start planning your portfolio to buy some of these stocks because steep correction gives you chance to get back what you never thought would be possible just about a month back.


If investors are taking out their cheque books, where can they find opportunity even within the broader end of the market?See, it is very simple. You have to go for the large size and for the market leaders. If you go industry to industry, you will find that there are not more than one or two stocks that are the market leaders and are now becoming relatively cheaper. Obviously you will not go for Bajaj twins in terms of the finance because they are really very expensive stocks. You would tend to go for the other ones at some point of time. 

HDFC, HDFC Bank will stabilise and you would want to go back to those kind of stocks. Look at multiplex, as we discussed. If you look at the aviation stocks, you know every industry has one or two leaders, focus your mind there. Let us say people who missed out on buying Asian Paints, it has a stellar record for the last 20 years. If I am not wrong, it consistently rewards shareholders. You might want to start looking at each market leader.

New Delhi: July turned out to be the worst month for Nifty in 17 years. The NSE benchmark is on course to end the month 6 per cent lower, marking its biggest fall monthly drop since 2002.

Market sentiment was hit this month following disappointing announcements in Union Budget amid tepid corporate earnings.

In July 2002, Nifty had registered a 9.35 per cent fall, which was also its biggest fall that year. The index has ended July in the red on five instances in last 17 years. It fell 2.93 per cent in 2011, 0.95 per cent in 2012 and 1.72 per cent in 2013.

FII have sold equities around Rs 12,000 crore this July, leading to major wealth destruction across sectors. Nifty shed over 700 points during the month. The overseas portfolio investors had brought in over Rs 80,000 crore during February-June.

Siddhartha Khemka, Head of Retail Research, Motilal Oswal Financial Services, told ETNow that the income-tax surcharge hurt FPI sentiment, adding to the market’s woes.

The pain is even worse in the broader market. BSE midcap and Smallcap indices fell 8.52 per cent and 11.16 per cent, respectively, during the month.

Within the Nifty pack, 44 stocks eroded investor wealth in July, with Coal India, YES Bank, Titan, Tata Motors, Tata Steel, ONGC, GAIL, Bajaj Finserve, JSW Steel, Grasim and M&M falling up to 21 per cent till July 30.

However, stocks like Zee Entertainment and Asian Paints gained up to 13 per cent to help cushion the fall. Among others, Infosys, Sun Pharma, Kotak Mahindra Bank, Power Grid and Dr Reddy's Labs managed to deliver positive returns to investors.

“Poor Q1 earnings, a slowdown in domestic consumption and the ongoing NBFC crisis have dampened investor sentiments on Dalal Street,” said Hemang Jani, Head of Advisory, Sharekhan by BNP Paribas.

“We are cautious on the NBFC space. Rising credit costs and higher provisioning are likely to impact bottom line and credit growth. As per recent reports and data domestic growth will be weaker over the next 12-18 months,” he said.

Khemka of MOSL said, “The broader market has turned weak mainly because of poor fundamentals. The underlying earnings growth has remained elusive and Q1 numbers have proved to be a dampener for earnings recovery expectations for FY20.”

Jani prefers stocks like Ramco Cement, HUL and Asian Paints which have shown decent growth in a challenging environment.

NEW DELHI: Equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty ended higher on Friday, thanks to gains in shares of heavyweights, including HDFC, Bharti Airtel, TCS, Infosys and Asian Paints.

After plunging about 411 points intraday, Sensex rebounded to end with a gain of 100 points at 37,118.22. Nifty settled 17 points higher at 10,997.35.

However, market breadth remained tilted towards the bears as 1,362 stocks declined against 1,097 that logged gains on BSE.

While some short-covering might have lifted the market, the sentiment was influenced after media reports suggested that the government was considering ways to check the outflow of foreign funds from Indian market.

There were hopes that the government may exempt FPIs from the tax surcharge and also do away with the proposal of raising the minimum public shareholding in listed companies to 35 per cent from 25 per cent.

"Indian market recovered in the second half of the trading day on optimism that the government is mulling over exempting FPI from super-rich surcharges. Additionally, better domestic macros like GST collection, PMI and Monsoon forecast in August provided relief that the economy will improve by the second half of FY20," said Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services.

We walk you through the key highlights of Friday's session:


Over 600 stocks hit 52-week lows
As many as 609 stocks, including ITC, Tata Motors, Tata Steel, Vedanta, Hindalco, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Exide Industries, Escorts and DB Corp, hit 52-week lows on BSE. On the other hand, Asian Paints, Radhagobind Commercial, SSPN Finance, Mac Hotels and Joy Realty were among the 18 stocks that hit 52-week highs.


HDFC jumps 2% on Q1 nos
After five consecutive days of losses, shares of mortgage lender HDFC closed 1.75 per cent higher at Rs 2,124.10 after it reported a 46 per cent year-on-year (YoY) jump in standalone profit at Rs 3,203 crore for the June quarter. The housing finance firm had posted Rs 2,190 crore profit in the corresponding quarter last year. 


SBI falls 3%
Shares of State Bank of India ended the day with a loss of 2.76 per cent at Rs 308.45 even as it reported a net profit of Rs 2,312.20 crore for the June quarter compared with a loss of Rs 4,875.85 crore in the corresponding quarter last year. 


Bharti Airtel jumps 6%
Shares in Bharti Airtel surged 6 per cent to close at Rs 343.45 after its India mobile services continued to show signs of a recovery in the first quarter of the current fiscal with average revenue per user (Arpu) moving up sequentially for the second straight three-month period. 


ITC slips ahead of Q1 nos
Shares of ITC closed 1.12 per cent lower at Rs 264.60 ahead of its June quarter numbers. Analysts expect the company may report a price hike-led 10-14 per cent rise in year-on-year (YoY) profit for the June quarter even as volume growth coming in at 3-5 per cent due to higher base-year effect. 


JK Tyre plunges 14%

NEW DELHI: Equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty reversed early losses to end in the green in a volatile trading session on Friday as media reports suggested that Finance Ministry and PMO held discussions over suggestions and submissions by foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) regarding the surcharge issue. 

According to reports, the PMO took stock of the tax surcharge and its impact on the stock market and FPIs. FPIs have sought a roll back of surcharge as a confidence boosting signal from the Modi government. 

Indian government is likely to put a plan to raise the minimum public shareholding in listed companies to 35 per cent from 25 per cent on hold , Reuters reported quoting sources.

"The government is also looking for ways to ease concerns of foreign portfolio investors that have pulled out of Indian equity markets after a budget announcement of higher taxes for individuals and trusts earning more than 20 million rupees a year," the source added. 

Earlier in the day, the benchmarks witnessed heavy selling pressure after US President Donald Trump's decision to impose new tariffs on Chinese goods triggered fresh fears among investors. US President Donald Trump threatened to impose more tariffs on China, this time a 10 per cent of $300 billion in Chinese imports from September 1. Moody's said the new tariffs would weigh on the global economy at a time when growth is already slowing in the US, China and eurozone.

Analysts said markets may continue to remain on the weaker side due to negative global cues, mixed corporate earnings, slowdown in domestic consumption and the ongoing liquidity crisis in the NBFC space. Analysts expect volatility to persist as the market is expected to be largely driven by the ongoing quarterly earnings.

The markets were supported by auto and telecom stocks while Metal, Power and Realty indices capped the gains.

Analyst View

NEW DELHI: Indian equities continued their downward journey as headline indices Sensex and Nifty incurred strong losses in opening deals on Friday. 

The selloff aggravated after US President Donald Trump threatened to impose more tariffs on China, this time a 10 per cent of $300 billion in Chinese imports from September 1.

Global stocks took another beating with investors offloading riskier equities and piling into safe-haven assets.

In the opening deals, Sensex plunged over 400 points, while Nifty slipped towards 10,850.

On Thursday, Nifty closed below 11,000 points for the first time in five months after the US Federal Reserve dashed market expectations of a lengthy rate-cut cycle. 

Market observers say the impact of Budget on investor sentiment still continues. Moreover, subdued quarterly earnings and clear signs of an economic slowdown are serious concerns.

Sensex and Nifty have come off 8 per cent and 9 per cent, respectively, from their all-time highs, hit early June, 2019. Since the Budget day on July 5, 2019, investors have lost 13.70 lakh crore on BSE. 


Factors that spooked markets:
Trump launches fresh salvo against China: While the trade negotiation between the US and China is lost in the midway, the US President Donald Trump said he would slap a 10 per cent tariff on the remaining $300 billion of Chinese imports starting September 1. This sent shivers down investor's spine across the globe. Asian stocks plummeted as investors rushed towards safe-haven assets. 


Fed commentary dashed hopes:The US Fed reduced the key interest rate by 25-basis-point but poured cold water on market expectations of a lengthy easing cycle. Powell characterised the rate cut as a mid-cycle adjustment to policy, citing signs of a global slowdown, simmering US trade tensions and a desire to boost too-low inflation. Markets took that as a sign that sharp further cuts were not imminent, Reuters reported. 


Deteriorating macros:India’s core sector growth slumped to its lowest in more than four years in June, reflecting the economic slowdown and the lack of pickup in investment. The index of eight core industries rose 0.2 per cent in June, down from 4.3 per cent in May and 7.8 per cent in the year-earlier, data released by the government showed, marking the slowest increase since the 0.5 per cent contraction in April 2015. India’s fiscal deficit in first quarter ended June hit 61.4 per cent of the budgeted target for the current fiscal, government data showed last Wednesday. The deficit was 68.7 per cent in the year-earlier period. 


Sustained capital outflow:The market has been witnessing sustained capital outflow after the Finance Minister proposed a tax surcharge on super-rich in Budget 2019. Since the Budget day on July 5, 2019, investors have lost 13.70 lakh crore on BSE. As per data available with NSDL, foreign investors took away Rs 3,003 crore from Indian financial market during the month of July. Foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) were sellers of domestic stocks to the tune of Rs 1,057 crore on Thursday, data available with NSE suggested. DIIs were net buyers to the tune of Rs 561 crore, data suggests. 


Poor auto sales numbersOne of the major signs of the health of the economy, the auto sales numbers, have painted a grim picture. Maruti Suzuki India (MSI) reported a 33.5 per cent decline in total sales at 1,09,264 units in July, while M&M reported a 15 per cent fall in total sales to 40,142 units. Bajaj Auto reported a 5 per cent fall in total sales at 3,81,530 units in July, 2019. Such subdued sets of data further roiled the market sentiment.


Market at a glance:
In the 30-pack Sensex, only three stocks - Bharti Airtel, Asian Paints and Infosys were up.


Hero MotoCorp, HDFC, Bajaj Auto, ONGC and ICICI Bank were among the top losers in the Sensex index, falling up to 3 per cent.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 3 were up and 47 were down.

Midcaps and smallcaps continued reeling under selling pressure as their sectoral indices on BSE fell over 1 per cent. 

Barring telecom, all sectoral indices on the BSE were in the red. Gains in shares of Bharti Airtel (up 3.46 per cent), Optiemus Infracom (up 2.07 per cent) and Sterlite Technologies (up 0.17 per cent) lifted the telecom pack up even as 10 out of total 13 components of the index were down.

Do not look at short-term factors, sentiment, earnings, flows. You cannot really make money by focussing on those sorts of factors on any consistent basis, says Saurabh Mukherjea, Founder and Chief Investment Officer, Marcellus Investment. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW. Mukherjee says his focus has always been on companies with clean accounts, essential products and monopoly franchises. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.

What is your take on the fact that after today’s fall, sub that 10,900 mark, we have erased all of our 2019 gains and the Nifty has turned negative for 2019 for real?I have to confess that none of us at Marcellus really spend that much time figuring out what the market outlook is, what is going to happen next week or next month. We have never been. Our focus consistently has been to analyse and look for companies whose governance is good, accounting is actually bona fide, genuine accounts, companies who sell essential products and have monopoly franchises there in. 

So clean accounts, essential products, monopoly franchises and that is what we spend all our time doing. Honestly, we really have very little interest in knowing what the sentiment is today or what it will be tomorrow morning that sort of question is probably best asked to other punters who try to do short-term trading. 

Our emphasis has been to look after the 500 families whose wealth that we manage, to look after the wealth by focussing on consistent compounders, high class companies, say an Asian Paints or HDFC Bank or say Dr Lal PathLabs, companies that we own personally and that is it inside the 500 portfolios that we manage for family offices across the country.


One of the key issues has been that FIIs have been consistent sellers and have accelerated the selling post budget. What do you think can be done to bring FIIs back?It is important that there is no knee-jerk reaction to this. Obviously whatever has happened has happened, we are a large economy, one of the six, seven large economies in the world and I am sure the government did whatever it did on 5th July with the best intentions. There has been an inadvertent consequence, which is that some of the FIIs who have trust structures have ended with a higher tax rate than they or the government had bargained for. 

I think remedial measures can be found and it does not necessarily mean reversing the tax rate. A more liberal FII regime which allows foreign investors to invest more easily in India will lead to them coming in. I was in America 10 days ago talking to some of the pension funds and endowments who are discussing whether they will give us some money to invest and their view was that this remains one of the most attractive economies in the world to invest in. So there is an underlying foreign investor desire to invest in the Indian stock market. 

I am sure if the government comes up with a couple of measures with SEBI to make it easier for foreign money to come into India, the FII flows will return in due course. But again, one should not be trying to second guess FII flows or DII flows. If you try to second guess these sorts of things and make investments therein, it is a very dicey way to think about stock market investing.


How would you look at the earnings season because after all earnings will decide where the prices go?It has been very similar to the earnings seasons we have seen for the last 30 quarters odd in our country. If you do not have a capex cycle you are not going to see anything dramatically different in the earnings season. 

I am not so sure again why people get worked up every time the quarterly earnings season comes around. The economy has been in slow motion mode for six, seven years now and therefore in that context, it is a little challenging for companies to show decent earnings growth. 

There is obviously some companies of the ilk of Pidilite or Kotak Bank or a HDFC Bank, which can consistently chug out good numbers but their ability to chug out good numbers has been proven a long time ago. You and I do not need to wait for the next earnings season to assess that a Pidilite or a Dr Lal Path Labs will consistently grind out good results, that is a well established fact. 

What I am trying to repeatedly highlight is do not look at short term factors, sentiment, earnings, flows you cannot really make money by focussing on those sorts of factors on any consistent basis.

NEW DELHI: The domestic equity market had a zigzag show on Monday amid signs of further escalation in the trade war, a steep fall in the yuan, uncertainty over a major law change on Kashmir and weakness in the rupee. 

China’s yuan hit its lowest level in almost 11 years, triggering a sharp drop in emerging market currencies. At the time of writing of this report, the rupee traded 90 paise down at 70.49 against the US dollar.

“Weak global sentiment was the top trigger behind Monday’s market fall. It seems the trade war is not going to end anytime soon,” said Pankaj Pandey, Head of Research at ICICIdirect.

Losses in heavyweights from bank, NBFC, energy, auto and metal sectors dragged Sensex by 418 points, or 1.13 per cent, to 36,699. Nifty finished at 10,862, down 135 points or 1.23 per cent.

“The ongoing turmoil in Kashmir may further induce volatility in the market. Escalating trade tensions between the US and China will keep market participants on the edge and cause weakness in oil prices as well as the currency,” said Ajit Mishra, VP- Research, Religare Broking.
