Excelling in selling and distribution of consumer products, fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) companies have time and again found it tough to crack the consumer services market. Companies that have ventured in the services business have not been able to make it a significant contributor to their overall revenues and bottomline, despite having a presence in it for over a decade.


The performance of the decadeold laundry services of Jyothy Laboratories has deteriorated in recent years, even as the company has put in more money in the business in the past two years. The business incurred a loss in each of the past two financial years.

Kaya, a skincare business, has been loss-making for the past three years. The skin clinic business was demerged from Marico in 2013-14. The Kaya stock has lost three-fourths of its value since its listing on the bourses in 2015. Last year, the company shifted its emphasis from capital-intensive formats, such as own stores, shop-in-shops, to a widespread distribution network across general and modern trade channels.


ET Bureau
Decorative paints company Asian Paints entered the home improvement segment through acquisition of Sleek Group in 2013 and bathroom fitting business Ess the following year. However, the businesses continue to remain loss-making more than five years later.

In the second quarter earnings call, the company’s management said that both the segments within the home improvement business faced challenges given the slowdown in the real estate construction sector. However, both the businesses registered good growth with continuing focus on network expansion.

With Pureit, HUL made an entry into in-home water purification service in 2008. However, over a decade since its launch, the company is still trying to get its strategy right. It is currently realigning its portfolio strategy towards premium devices.

Investors of FMCG companies need to be wary when their companies expand into service-oriented businesses. Deep pockets and strong brand equity in consumer goods do not necessarily translate into success in the service business.

“Services business requires a different mindset. Unlike in case of products, the companies do not have total control on the last-mile delivery of the service”, said Abneesh Roy, research analyst at Edelweiss Securities.

Some of the stocks and sectors are at multi-year lows; in terms of valuations, they have very attractive dividend yields and those are some of the themes that we like, says Amit Khurana, Head of Equities & Research, Dolat Capital Market. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.



How would you slice and dice the consumption basket? What would you be looking at-- staples or discretionaries? Also, keeping valuations in mind, where would you go hunting within that basket?We have been favouring discretionary over staples for some time now and within discretionary, we are preferring the names which have had a better ability to clear up the inventory. Voltas comes into our preferred picks play. One of the few companies which did not have to take a price cut while the market was slowing down and they were able to clear off the inventory quite a bit without having to compromise on the margins or pricing. 

Among staples, the valuations are too rich. While we are not negative on the models themselves, but the price that you are paying, in some cases, seems to be ridiculously high. We are not comfortable with that as a segment. Within discretionary, the other segment which we liked was paints which has very significant tailwinds because of lower raw material costs which played out in the second quarter. 

Maybe some spill-over effect is likely in this quarter as well. But, we are through the peak of the volume trajectory for the year and therefore at best, one would expect these stocks to sustain. But again, one of the players is quite richly valued. We preferred Asian Paints versus Berger Paints in that context. But overall, our take is that the next couple of quarters will probably see these stocks meander around and not do too much. From a return perspective, we are not very bullish on consumer as a category.


What do you think the markets are likely to witness in 2020? How do you look at the polarisation going ahead in the next year?That is something that we have been trying to view for the last so many weeks. Our take is that 2020, from an Indian perspective, could be a tale of two halves. The first half will probably confirm that there is a bottoming out of the overall economy and the valuations in the midcap and smaller cap space. Probably, if we get better visibility going into the second half of CY2020, you will see a build up of premium in some of those names and sectors. 

Having said that, there are some very interesting aspects also as we go into the New Year. One of the things we are really looking at is the deep polarisation in the market. Very rarely have markets been so dichotomous. We believe there will be a trigger over a period of time to unwind this situation because you cannot always have 15-20 stocks driving the market. There will be a broadening, driven by the visibility from bottoming out of the broader economy and recovery of the earnings for the beaten down names. That is the broader hypothesis we are going around with. Some of the stocks and sectors are at multi-year lows; in terms of valuations, they have very attractive dividend yields and those are some of the themes that we like.


What about healthcare and I am not talking about pure play pharma universe here? What about the allied spaces-- labs, diagnostics as well as the hospital pockets? Some of those stocks have given handsome returns in 2019. Do you like anything here?We do not have formal ratings. I am a bit surprised by the way some of the stocks have performed and got re-rated. It did come as a positive surprise. But there were more stock specific factors, especially the balance sheet deleveraging which a couple of companies did and then the return of volume growth in some of these models which were otherwise getting impacted because of pricing and volume pressures. 

This year, they have been able to recover in all those parameters and that really led to a significant re-rating in the market. We probably missed out on that. We did not expect such a major re-rating for those stocks and a major recovery in the earnings trajectory for some of those names.


You have mentioned earlier that you were looking at the broader market. Within that, would you suggest going extremely stock specific, given that we have seen so many of these stocks beaten down? Are there particular themes that you would pick up?We are backing up a few macro themes. Names which are quite beaten down, especially the PSU pack. Some of the public sector units ex the banks, are quoting at fairly attractive dividend yields. They are quoting at almost one time price to book. That is one of the pockets that we are looking at to make an allocation. 

They may sound a little defensive and low beta names but we believe that the environment we are in, it makes sense to have a fair allocation on those because there is very low downside risk but also from a portfolio stability perspective. these names will hold on to the portfolio for any untoward event. That is one theme that we are backing up. 

We have preferred picks from BFSI space in our portfolio and our argument is simple: as long as there is delivery, there is visibility of earnings and better risk management in those models, we do not mind paying premium for those.

The second one will possibly play out quite remarkably in the next couple of quarters, thanks to the operating leverage for some of the names. These will be the companies which have an exposure to debt, but are not over leveraged. These have a healthy balance sheet and a fairly healthy debt to equity ratios. 

We believe there will be a major pass through of the interest rate reductions over the next couple of quarters. While the RBI has not cut rates in the last cycle and the odds are still split on whether we will get a rate cut in February review, we believe that the ability of banks to pass on the rate cuts over the next couple of quarters will be far more pronounced. That will have a material impact on some of these sectors which will get a tailwind because of lower interest costs over the next 12 to 18 months. We believe this will start playing out in the next couple of quarters and those names are also on our radar. 

The third theme, which is more sector specific, is telecom. While it seems to have become a consensus now and some money is already made, we still believe there is enough tailwind to play out in the sector and we prefer Bharti as the preferred play to take an exposure on this sector. Reason: There is a much better pricing discipline from the players and there is a far more pronounced support from the government to ensure that there is a three-player market and the price hikes go through. 

We are also expecting a significant policy support from the government in terms of how it would like the companies to pay up on the dues. We believe there is still money to be made on telecom and CY20 and this could be one of the themes to back up for. 


What is your view on the banking pack? While some are trading at one-time price to book, there are also names which are trading at three-four times. Those are typically private sector banks. We have preferred picks from BFSI space in our portfolio and our argument is simple: as long as there is delivery, there is visibility of earnings and better risk management in those models, we do not mind paying premium for those. 

Amongst the PSU banks, we have backed up SBI through the CY19 and that continues to be the only PSU bank that we like. 

From a broader perspective, there is going to be a significant change in the way the models are operating and the way the banks will behave. The gains from NBFCs to banks are yet to play out and we would expect that to be take place over the next couple of years. Therefore, we are preferring some of the private sector banks.


What is your take on commodity plays like metals and steel makers in particular?Metals have been showing a pretty positive uptrend but in our recent sort of interaction across the industry, the price hikes do not seem to be sustaining that well. We did see some price hikes getting absorbed and then the discounting came back into the market. 

So from a fundamental perspective, I am not very sure whether this is the right time to go aggressively long. But having said that, the global news flow seems to be far more sort of positive to support this trend.

We will probably see this sector and stocks sustaining these levels, but purely from a domestic perspective, we are not finding evidence of a very major uptick in volumes or pricing as yet. I would reserve my judgment on that.
